post_copy: Stop copying Figma , Notion , and HubSpot What works for â‚¬500M+ ARR companies will kill your startup at â‚¬0-1M. Hereâ€™s what they do â€” and what you should do instead ğŸ‘‡ âŒ Run multiple motions (PLG + SLG) âœ… Pick one motion & nail it before layering others --> Large companies can afford to run Product-Led and Sales-Led motions simultaneously because they have resources and mature data to support both - you don't. âŒ Serve multiple ICPs âœ… Focus on one ideal ICP --> big SaaS can target different customer segments without losing focus or efficiency - you can't. âŒ Cover multiple use cases âœ… Solve one painful problem --> covering multiple use cases dilutes your focus, spreads your product and messaging too thin, and makes it very hard to achieve productâ€“market fit fast. Each use case usually means a different pain point, buying trigger, and sales motion. âŒ Active on every channel âœ… Master 1â€“2 channels --> Concentrate efforts on the one or two channels that deliver consistent results before expanding. âŒ Complex pricing (feature gating, multiple value metrics) âœ… Keep it simple (one value metric, no feature gating if possible) --> You donâ€™t have enough customer data or usage patterns to design smart feature gating or multi-metric pricing. Complex models only create friction in buying and learning. Your goal isnâ€™t to optimize margins, itâ€™s to validate willingness to pay and shorten the sales cycle. Treat pricing as an iterative feedback loop âŒ Heavy demand gen âœ… Focus on demand capture --> Instead of creating new demand, capture existing intent where your ideal customers are already looking âŒ Lot of TOFU content âœ… Focus on high intent BOFU content --> BOFU content (case studies, comparison pages, Best of listicles) speaks directly to prospects who already feel the pain and are ready to buy. Your priority is capturing existing demand, not educating the entire market. âŒ Specialized GTM teams âœ… Founder-Led Sales --> One founder must lead sales to learn customer pain, refine ICP & messaging, and prove repeatability. âŒ Big brand plays (Events, Creative Campaigns, PR...) âœ… Focus on social proof (case studies) and founder brand --> Leverage testimonials and the founderâ€™s credibility to build trust. ğŸ‘‰ What else?

5 CRM tactics that you can implement in <1 hour that can bring you ton of value â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬. Here's the changes you should be making 1ï¸âƒ£ Add a self-reported attribution field 2ï¸âƒ£ Add a lost reason dropdown (instead of text field) + additional text field info 3ï¸âƒ£ Add a â€˜contract start dateâ€™ as a new property 4ï¸âƒ£ Make these fields mandatory: -> Contract start date: When deal is won -> Lost reason dropdown + text info: When deal is lost 5ï¸âƒ£ Add deal tags to mark deals that stalled + have no upcoming task 6ï¸âƒ£ Adapt the deal stage probabilities for better/more realistic pipeline forecasts Your CRM data can be a gold mine of insights IF you can leverage the data well. These are the exact changes I recommended to a founder I'm advising. Let me know if you implement these too.

Running GTM without a system is like running product without a roadmap. Douwe Wester ğŸŸ¢ ğŸ‘‰ calls this The GTM OS â†’ the one-page operating system founders can use to align strategy, marketing, sales, and CS. Most teams try to fix GTM by adding more activity: â†’ More outbound â†’ More content â†’ More CSMs But without a system, all of it runs in different directions. Here's how The GTM OS works: Start at the top: â†³ Look at your top 20% customers â†³ Run win/loss, SPICED, pipeline data â†³ Analyze market shifts and competitor plays Then build your profile: â†³ What does your real ICP look like? â†³ Whatâ€™s their journey? â†³ Who are you actually winning with? Now clarify your value: â†³ What are you really selling? â†³ How does your pricing support that? â†³ Can your team say it the same way? Only then do we activate the tactics: â†³ Marketing that speaks to the real buyer â†³ Sales that qualifies, not guesses â†³ CS that drives success, not churn prevention When itâ€™s all on one page, the chaos disappears. You stop firefighting and start compounding. Thatâ€™s what The GTM OS does. No fluff. Just structure. ğŸ‘‡ Steal it. Special thanks to Douwe for inspiration for the post as well as the concept of GTM OS.

How to price my new AI product or my AI-feature add-on? In times of 'fast-fashion' of SaaS, differentiation becomes key. I expect 3 things becoming key for early-stage founders to stand out: 1) starting with a highly specialized usecase/workflow 2) GTM execution is key (otherwise no one will use your product) 3) Brand and trust become key --> I try this product as I like the brand, trust the founder... But especially with AI products, pricing is relevant. Because the cost side can become very expensive. And people are mostly unaware of what the product is capable. So they are more sceptical. This is why we also see a shift towards 'outcome' pricing. Maybe in the feature even ROI-based? 5,000+ SaaS GTM leaders enjoyed our Ultimate SaaS Pricing Page Guide. Now Rob Litterst and I turned it into a 35-page masterclass ğŸ‘‡

Your pricing page can do two things for your prospects - âœ… Convert their interest to action, or âŒ Confuse them and send them to a competitor. The best pricing pages aren't the most creative â€“ they're the clearest. They meet visitor expectations while providing enough context to help someone confidently choose the right plan. Here are the 4 key sections of the perfect pricing page - 1ï¸âƒ£ Hero -> This hero section is meant for a more down-funnel visit. Because of this, you don't need to talk about your company much here. -> You need to tell them more about how they can get started with your product, how they can scale, etc. 2ï¸âƒ£ Pricing Menu -> The Pricing Menu is the most important section of a pricing page. -> The goal is to show people the key levers and the key differentiators between plans that might determine which one theyâ€™re a fit for. 3ï¸âƒ£ Feature Comparison Table -> The feature comparison table acts as the second line of fire. -> If there are answers that visitors can't get from the main menu, like specific features or usage limits, that's what the feature comparison table is for. 4ï¸âƒ£ FAQ -> This should act as your final line of defense before somebody gets in touch with sales. -> If there's anything left over that needs to be answered after the pricing menu and the feature comparison section, thatâ€™s what the FAQ section is for. Check out the detailed components of each section belowâ¬‡ï¸ ---- PS: Rob Litterst and I have come up with the Ultimate Guide to SaaS Pricing Page, where we cover all these concepts in detail. Check it out on mrrunlocked.com if you want to know more.

I reviewed 100+ SaaS pricing pages over the last years. Your pricing menu needs to do only one thing. Help your visitors understand how much it is going to cost them. Your job is to find the best way to communicate this information to them. Here are the 6 main elements of a good pricing menu - 1ï¸âƒ£ Pricing Modality â†’ How you charge. Options include - Flat Fees (e.g. 50â‚¬/month), - Licenses (e.g. 50â‚¬/month/user), - Usage-Based (e.g. 0,1â‚¬ per contact), - Credits (e.g. 100â‚¬ for 1000 credits), or a combination. 2ï¸âƒ£ Pricing Metrics (aka. value metric) â†’ The unit(s) you charge for (e.g., Users, GPUs, APIs, etc). 3ï¸âƒ£ Value Ladder (aka. feature gating) â†’ How value scales (e.g., collaboration, automation, governance, etc). Usually, thereâ€™s a feature â€œthemeâ€ that scales the value of a product. 4ï¸âƒ£ Packaging â†’ How you organize your modality, metrics, and features into bundles, usually as discrete tiers. ğŸ’¡Though some companies donâ€™t do this, and go with â€˜pay as you goâ€™ or Ã  la carte packaging. 5ï¸âƒ£ Price â†’ How much each option costs, and the billing period. 6ï¸âƒ£ Call to Action â†’ What visitors should do next. Usually, either get started, free trial, request a demo, or contact sales. These concepts might sound way more complicated than they actually are. But remember, you want to make the pricing menu such that it helps a visitor quickly understand how your pricing strategy works. ------ Btw, Rob Litterst and I have come up with the Ultimate Guide to SaaS Pricing Page. Head over to mrrunlocked.com if you want to learn how to create the perfect pricing page for your SaaS.

Not every LinkedIn post performs the same. But some formats consistently drive reach, saves, and DMs. Here are the 7 post formats that work best for B2B founders ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ â€˜How toâ€™ posts -> Actionable guides that give readers a clear next step. ->Think playbooks, frameworks, or â€œdo this in 5 steps.â€ 2ï¸âƒ£ â€˜Problemâ€™ posts -> Call out a painful challenge your ICP faces. -> Show you understand their world before offering a solution. 3ï¸âƒ£ â€˜Status Quo & ICPâ€™ posts -> Highlight why the default way is broken and who your product is really for. 4ï¸âƒ£ â€˜Tips/Learningsâ€™ posts -> Short, experience-backed lessons. -> This works best when you tie it to real mistakes, experiments, or client work. 5ï¸âƒ£ â€˜Build in publicâ€™ / Product Marketing posts -> Share what youâ€™re building, why, and the thinking behind it. -> These create buy-in and trust before you even launch. 6ï¸âƒ£ â€˜Market Insightsâ€™ & Listicle posts -> Bundle multiple insights from your day to day observations 7ï¸âƒ£ Social Proof posts -> Case studies, testimonials, milestones. -> Give people a reason to trust you. 8ï¸âƒ£ FAQ & Objections posts -> Address common doubts head-on. -> If you answer objections in public, your sales calls get easier. Drop a "LinkedIn" in the comments if you'd like templates for each of these post formats.

One clear GTM motion beats five half-baked experiments. Signs you are chasing too many ICPs at once: -> Forecasts look inflated because every deal looks â€œpossibleâ€ -> Reps spend more time rewriting messaging than actually selling -> Marketing runs broad campaigns that generate interest but no intent -> Product shifts priorities every quarter to please too many personas On the surface, it looks like activity. In reality, it is a stall-out. Durable teams make the hard choice: one ICP, one motion, one playbook. That does not mean you ignore optionality forever. It means you prove one motion works end to end before adding the next. Think of it like this, Your (single) ICP today brings you to your next milestone. Once you hit the next milestone, you can revisit your ICP. What does one clear motion look like? -> ICP definition that explains why your best customers buy and expand -> Messaging sharp enough for every rep to run without guesswork -> Playbooks that cover the entire buyer journey from first touch to renewal -> Metrics that show repeatability instead of experiments One motion creates clarity. Five half-baked experiments create chaos. Which one are you running? PS: How cool is this visual? Credit goes to Douwe Wester ğŸŸ¢ ğŸ‘‰ for inspiring this post and creating this visual!

Last week, I discussed a new sales compensation plan with a SaaS founder. The team is 3 AEs. Currently, there is no formal quota system in place. I took some notes to prepare for the session ğŸ‘‡ A good compensation plans start with 3 things: 1) On target earnings (OTE) - e.g. 150kâ‚¬ per year 2) A split of base salary vs. variable bonus - e.g. 60/40 3) Quota to OTE ratio - e.g. a 4x So let's make this practical. You want your AE to earn 150k on target. With a 60/40 split and a 4x ratio, you will end up with: 90kâ‚¬ base salary 60kâ‚¬ bonus 4x 150kâ‚¬ = 600kâ‚¬ Quota Your AE needs to close 600kâ‚¬ in revenue for a 100% quota attainment. With a 20kâ‚¬ ACV, this means roughly 30 won deals per year. To make the model fair and attractive, I would recommend: --> Quarterly Quota (e.g. 150kâ‚¬ per quarter) --> with quarterly payouts --> lower threshold (e.g. 30% or less, 0% commission) --> Uncapped (meaning if they close more, there is no maximum) --> Accelerator to incentivize overperformance (e.g. 15% instead of 10%) Don't forget to acknowledge the ramp-up phase of new hires. A practical tip: Give them between 50-100% of quota attainment during onboarding. Curious, what do you see in the market right now? Dominic Blank Machiel Kunst Alexander Dosse

Most SaaS founders skip the fundamentals and wonder why they're stuck in the 0-1mil ARR stage. I've worked with 25+ early-stage founders. The ones who hit â‚¬1M ARR fastest have these 7 foundations in place - 1. ICP (Ideal Customer Profile) Know your perfect customers, the ones who really benefit from your product. You can't sell to everyone. 2. Positioning Know your category and why your product stands out in that category. 3. Messaging Turn your positioning into customer-facing words that actually resonate. This becomes the foundation for all your sales & marketing. 4. GTM Channels The bridge between messaging and your ICP. Pick 1-2 channels. Master them before adding more. 5. Pricing What is the right value metric for your product? Keep it iterative. Perfect pricing comes later. 6. Sales Motion How you serve clients: Product-led vs. Sales-led vs. hybrid. Choose one dominant motion early. Don't do both in parallel. 7. Buyer Journey Map how prospects move from awareness to customer onboarding. Each stage needs intentional design. If there's one golden rule I want you to know, it's that GTM Foundations come before tactics. Have these in place and watch your startup grow. Which foundation is your biggest challenge right now? Your first 10 / 100 customers are unfortunately not your ICP. They are your ECPs (Early Customer Profile). Here's why.. These are customers you landed when you're in hustle mode. You're practically throwing everything at the wall, hoping something sticks. They aren't customers you achieve through a repeatable process. Usually your early customers are heterogen. Different company types Different personas Different usecases You can't grow serving all of them. You need to niche down. Eventually, you need to pause hustle mode and get to your ICP. How do you do this? Check out the 3-step process below. P.S. Daniel Zsolt RÃ©nyi and I wrote a top-performing guide on mrrunlocked.com on this.

Most founders think 0-1 mil ARR is one stage. Wrong. The journey from â‚¬0 to â‚¬1M ARR has 3 distinct stages. Here's the real roadmap: Stage 1: Hustle Mode You're landing your first 10-100 customers by running tests, experimenting, and figuring out what works. Key milestone: Problem-Solution Fit Stage 2: Focus Mode Here, you scale beyond your early customers to get to your ideal customers. The goal is to focus on 1 ICP, 1 use case, 1-2 channels. Key milestone: GTM Fit If you've crossed these two stages, you've hit Product-Market Fit. Stage 3: Expansion Mode (â‚¬1M+) Here, you can choose your expansion path to go beyond 1mil ARR - Vertical: Same ICP, new use cases - Horizontal: Same use case, new ICPs - Double down: Scale what's working Key milestone: Scale The formula: Problem-Solution Fit + GTM Fit = Product-Market Fit A lot of founders skip Stage 2 and in the process, never get to stage 3. They go from hustle mode straight to "let's scale everything." Understand these stages and map where you are currently. That's the best way to scale from 0-1mill ARR. If you want to know more about how to build these stages, check the link in the comments

If you're selling to everyone, you're selling to noone. Most SaaS founders fail because they try to sell to everyone. But the math is simple.. 10% of a â‚¬100M niche = â‚¬10M 1% of a â‚¬1B market = â‚¬10M Same revenue. But completely different difficulty level. When you niche down, everything clicks: âœ… Your marketing message becomes crystal clear âœ… Your sales team becomes highly efficient âœ… Your product roadmap gets laser-focused âœ… Your customer success becomes predictable âœ… Your referrals start flowing naturally Infact, something similar happened at Ayunis / Locaboo They had closed 100 customers, but still struggled because they were serving multiple use-cases. Once we drilled down into one specific segment with clear criteria (industry, company size, use case), everything accelerated. Your ICP today brings you to your next milestone. But to get there, dominate your niche.

I don't think enough founders are doing "comment below" LinkedIn posts. And it's costing them lots of leads. You might think they are overdone.. But the truth is, they still work and are a great indicator of intent from your ICP. Here's how you can use them to get leads - âœ… Choose a topic relevant to your ICP âœ… Create a solid resource to educate the ICP on that topic âœ… Create a LinkedIn post teasing the resource âœ… Ask people to comment for the full version âœ… Share with whoever comments via DM âœ… Follow up with additional value, not sales pitches It's one of the smoothest conversation starters plus, a great way to add value to your ICP without even selling your product. A few things that I realized recently... 1. 'AI agents for X' Everyone is 'ai-powered' or the 'new agent for X'. And adding 'ai-powered' to your messaging doesn't replace the hard positioning work you need to do. Explain in easy words: --> what your product does --> for who it's most valuable --> What benefits they have from using it 2. Go from 0 to scalable Don't try to go from nothing to finding the 'scalable' growth channels. Why not start to go from 0 to 1 client. Then from 1 to 10 Then from 10 to 100. Still the most effective ways are 'hard work' here. I mean: - ask your network for intros - reach out manually to high fit ICPs - write hand-written high value content - do high quality BOFU content - Ask for referrals from your first customers You get the point. 3. Adding a lot of features Because shipping new features get easier, founders tend to build a lot. I believe it's still best to do 1 usecase very good. Focus on this one usecase. Only build the best 'features' for this 1 usecase. Don't dilute to early. Even if you can 'easily' build all of this. Because market 'all these features' is hard. What have you seen the last months?

I had 2 great days Bits & Pretzels . Here are my top 2 learnings ğŸ‘‡ 1. Meeting people IRL is great Being solopreneur means being alone most of the time in my home office. Events are a great way to 'get out'. Came back energized. 2. Booth are like homepages I've probably read all 100+ startup booths. Besides the fact that every company is now 'ai-powered' and building the next 'AI agents for X' Most companies can't explain in 2-3 sentences what they do. I read their roll ups and short description. And in 50%+ I was not sure what they do. Fun fact: It's the same with most homepages. And this is not a copy problem. It's a foundamental GTM problem. Unclear positioning. Unclear ICP. Unclear messaging. Special thanks to Ayunis / Locaboo team for this nice gift. After successfully working with them for 2+ years, I got a special present from day - Bits and pretzel ticket. ğŸ¥³ Now I'm really looking forward catching up with lots of interesting SaaS founders that I met. It was great meeting all of you in person again Kevin Merken Lukas Koppitz Manuel Hartmann Jonathan M. Gregory Moritz Weiss Florian Herschke Tobias Giesen P.S. Next time doing selfies with everyone would be good :)

The first month working with a new founder is always special. --> Need to deep dive into a new market --> Need to analyze their GTM status quo --> Get to know each other Yes every founder is a different person ğŸ˜œ --> Need to learn their speed of execution The first 2 sprints are over. First wins are implemented. The first month of my 6-month advisory is always kind of a 'pilot' month for both sides. Because I offer a no risk guarantee. Meaning founders can decide after the first month if they want to continue working with me. And yes, also I decided of it's a good fit. So getting good feedback after the first month feels good. How is the feeling for you working with new clients? P.S. I do have 1 free spot starting in January.

Great first day at Bits & Pretzels today Side note: Your booth at events is almost a small GTM strategy, why? ğŸ‘‡ Being a solopreneur means being alone at home most of the time. 2 reason why I decided to join more in-person events again. 1)As a remote solopreneur meeting people in person is always special. I do like my home office set up and working with founders across europe, but ofc it sometimes feel â€œlonelyâ€ 2) New inspirations After every event I have a full list of notes with new ideas and great insights. Was great catching up with familiar faces, friends, ex-collegues, partners, existing and potential new customers. Kevin Merken Lukas Koppitz BjÃ¶rn W. SchÃ¤fer Manuel Hartmann Daniel Gamber and many more. Tomorrow is the second day. Who's also there and up for a coffee? P.S. Congrats to Parabella Analytics for a great roll up! Your booth is a 'short GTM strategy' - you need to explain your product in a few words. What is your product, who's your ICP, short and clear messaging. What's your CTA? I've checked a lot of roll-ups - and a lot leave me back with questions on what they actually do.
From founder-led sales to hiring your first GTM hire. 9 common mistakes and how to avoid them ğŸ‘‡

Most founders struggle to get to PMF. Knowing what's needed is half the battle. It's a simple formula. To PMF. You need to work on 1ï¸âƒ£ Ideal Customer Profile 2ï¸âƒ£ Positioning 3ï¸âƒ£ Value Proposition & Messaging 4ï¸âƒ£ GTM Collaterals 5ï¸âƒ£ Pricing 6ï¸âƒ£ Sales Motion 7ï¸âƒ£ CRM & Tracking 8ï¸âƒ£ Forecasting & Planning 9ï¸âƒ£ Internal Operating Systems ğŸ”Ÿ Channels Check out the visual below to see what exactly you need to tick off within each of these components ğŸ‘‡ P.S. Every early-stage founder should do sales. Even if you never plan to hire a sales team. Even if your endgame is fully PLG. Here's why ğŸ’¡It's the best validation of your GTM Foundations. The biggest downside of PLG is that people sign up, but you never get to talk to them. You never really know why they are (not) converting. Is your onboarding flow bad? Is your product not up to the mark? Is your pricing bad? When you jump on demos and have calls with prospects, you can validate that much faster. So even if your ACV is low, founders need to sell in the early days.

No channel is dead in 2025. Or ever. But, every channel sure feels crowded. So the question isn't what's dead, it's how how do you stand out? AI has made it easy to spin up content, ads, or outreach campaigns. But hereâ€™s the nuance: âŒ It doesnâ€™t mean â€œevery channel is dead.â€ âœ… It does mean you need more channel expertise to win. A founder today canâ€™t just â€œtry LinkedInâ€ or â€œtest cold email.â€ You need to go deeper. -> What are best practices in this channel? -> How do you run structured experiments? -> Who brings the expertise you lack? Some channels are worth betting on as primary (Founder Brand, Network Sales, BOFU content). Others play better as secondary (Partnerships, Paid Social). Either way, you need to be better than average to stand out. My take: Every channel can work in 2025, but it costs more grit, focus, and expertise than it did 2 years ago.

We are already halfway through H2 2025, but you can still apply some of the tactics in Q4ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Customer Success Story campaign -> Drop case studies into outbound, newsletters, and re-activation plays. -> They build trust and help prospects picture themselves in the success story. 2ï¸âƒ£ Clickable logo carousel -> Make each homepage logo link to a case study. -> You turn static social proof into a conversion asset. 3ï¸âƒ£ Co-marketing with integration partners -> Host webinars, blog posts, or landing pages together. -> Itâ€™s the fastest way to borrow credibility and reach new audiences. 4ï¸âƒ£ Customer referral program -> Ask for referrals in every CS and sales call. -> Warm intros consistently outperform cold outbound. 5ï¸âƒ£ Partner referral program -> Incentivize consultants, agencies, or creators to refer you. 6ï¸âƒ£ Public template library -> Publish plug-and-play templates tied to your product. -> These rank in Google, drive sign-ups, and reduce activation friction. 7ï¸âƒ£ â€œUpgrade to yearlyâ€ banner -> Add an in-product prompt for annual plans. -> Show the cost savings in signing up for an annual plan 8ï¸âƒ£ Competitor hub -> Build one page with â€œX vs Yâ€, alternatives, and best-of lists. -> If buyers are comparing, it's better they read it on your site. 9ï¸âƒ£ BOFU keyword social listening -> Monitor buying-intent phrases on Reddit & LinkedIn. -> Jump in with value-added comments when needed. ğŸ”Ÿ Warm outreach to visitors & engagers -> Track who hits your site or engages on LinkedIn. -> Reaching out while intent is fresh massively increases reply rates. What's one tactic you're doubling down on?

10 fundraising errors that kill deals before they start ğŸ‘‡ âŒ Mistake #1: Pitching too early Lack of proof points = Lack of credibility âœ… Wait until you have real proof points âŒ Mistake #2: Too many iterations Pivoting during fundraising screams "we don't know what we're doing" âœ… Lock in your narrative before going to market âŒ Mistake #3: Founding team changes during the process Team changes = instant red flag âœ… Resolve team issues before raising âŒ Mistake #4: Overpromising projections If you don't follow through, it kills your credibility. âœ… Be realistic with forecasts âŒ Mistake #5: Running a messy process Dragging it out for 12+ months means lost momentum âœ… Set clear timelines and stick to them âŒ Mistake #6: Raising without a plan Fundraising just for runway isn't enough. âœ… Have crystal-clear use of funds âŒ Mistake #7: Not understanding investor expectations âœ… Research fund size, check sizes, and returner expectations âŒ Mistake #8: Spray and pray outreach Generic emails show a lack of preparation âœ… Personalize every single outreach âŒ Mistake #9: Starting too late Less time forces you to take desperate decisions âœ… Start 6-9 months before you need capital âŒ Mistake #10: Fluff-heavy pitch decks Jargon doesn't impress investors âœ… Focus on the crucial information only The founders who avoid these mistakes raise faster, on better terms and from the right investors. Together with Julius GÃ¶llner and Marc Penkala I break down everything about startup fundraising in the latest episode of MRR Unlocked. Adam Robinson has spoken a lot about venture capital vs bootstrapping. But those aren't your only options. If you decide to fundraise, you have 5 distinct funding paths to choose from Each serves different stages and goals. It's what I call the funding journey. 1ï¸âƒ£ Family & Friends (<â‚¬250k) â†’ Best for: Pre-revenue, idea-stage â†’ Reality: Quick cash from trusted networks 2ï¸âƒ£ Angels & Syndicates (â‚¬10k-â‚¬250k) â†’ Best for: Early traction, need smart money â†’ Pro tip: Target angels who've built in your space 3ï¸âƒ£ Accelerators (â‚¬100k-â‚¬250k for 6-10% equity) â†’ Best for: First-time founders needing guidance â†’ Bonus: Access to investor networks Examples: Y Combinator or Techstars 4ï¸âƒ£ Venture Capital (â‚¬100k-â‚¬1M+) â†’ Best for: Large TAM, high-growth potential â†’ Warning: Requires 100x return potential 5ï¸âƒ£ Non-dilutive Grants (â‚¬0 equity) â†’ Best for: Deep-tech, R&D heavy startups â†’ Downside: Paperwork hell There is no one-size-fits-all when it comes to fundraising. Choose what makes the most sense for you, based on your stage, funding requirements, and business requirements (network, guidance, etc.) Let us know your thoughts ğŸ‘‡

"We closed our first 10 customers through my network â€” is that repeatable?â€ âœ… Yes. But only if you treat your network like a growth channel. There are 2 parts to it: 1ï¸âƒ£ Keep building your own network -> Every conversation, every event, every post is a potential touchpoint. -> If you invest consistently, your network compounds â€” and you can sell through it forever. 2ï¸âƒ£ Leverage your team's network -> When you hire, you donâ€™t just get skills. You also get access to the relationships theyâ€™ve built over years. -> Thatâ€™s another network multiplier. So yes, â€œnetwork salesâ€ is repeatable. So let's talk numbers. Imagine you talk to 5 people every week. And you build the muscle to ask them for referrals / warm intros. To people that fit your ICP. And 20% do this. Introduce you to 2 people. So 5 conversations bring you another 2 meetings. This becomes a growth loop. And yes, you can 'multiply' this by adding your team :) But it only scales with how intentional you are about growing and building it. ğŸ‘‡ Do you use network sales / warm intros? P.S. I've done it in the beginning of my solopreneurship and somehow stopped it. But start doing it again :)

It's exciting to launch new channels. But what is more important is closing existing channels. Or at least pausing them. For context, When you're in the super early stages of 0-1mil, you're throwing everything that the wall to see what sticks. âœ…This is "Hustle Mode" (0-100K) Multiple channels, ads, LinkedIn, referrals, partnerships, etc. The whole point of this stage is to test and see what works best for you. But as you scale, you need to shift your focus only to channels that work. Each channel requires its own set of GTM planning, resources, time. âœ…This is "Focus Mode" (100K - 1Mil) Here's its time to focus on ideally - 1 ICP - 1 use-cases - 1/2 channels As soon as you see a winner emerge in hustle mode, a channel that works for you, it's time to focus and go all in on that channel.

Using others' networks for your SaaS. That is literally what referrals are. So if you are not doing this already, now is a great time to start. Here are 3 LinkedIn referral playbooks you can start using right away 1ï¸âƒ£ Getting referrals from sales conversations - Use every touchpoint with a prospect/customer to get warm intros. - These are slightly tricky and depend totally on how you ask for it. 2ï¸âƒ£ Getting referrals/intros from your network - Tap into your closed group network of investors, employees, partners, friends - See who else from their network can be an ICP for you. - If you find relevant people, ask your closed group for referrals. 3ï¸âƒ£ Getting referrals/intros from existing customers - Filter your customers' connections for ICP and ask for potential intros. - You can literally make customer success your #1 referral engine See how you can execute each of these playbooks belowğŸ‘‡ P.S. Please, please, I always hope that demos are No Feature F**** They are your best opportunity to (dis)qualify your prospects. So here's what a great discovery call looks like. Ask questions about 1ï¸âƒ£ Your ICP - Their role, responsibilities, current priorities 2ï¸âƒ£ Current situation - How are they currently dealing with the challenge 3ï¸âƒ£ Pain point/problem - What challenges are they currently facing 4ï¸âƒ£ Urgency - Why is it important to solve the problem now 6ï¸âƒ£ Decision process & stakeholders - Who will be involved in the next steps 7ï¸âƒ£ Competition - What other options are they considering Pro Tip: Capture and analyze your sales call recordings. There is no excuse not to do this; the learnings from these calls are gold. PS: Had a fun banter on this with Daniel Zsolt RÃ©nyi .

Clay has made "GTM Engineer" the coolest hire in tech. But, do you really need a GTM Engineer in the 0 to 1 stage? My answer is a big NO.. 0-1 is about building a repeatable sales process. And it's your job as a founder to build it. You need to: -> Find your ICP -> Validate messaging that converts -> Find channels that work -> Build your GTM Foundation A GTM engineer excels at optimizing funnels, automating sequences, and scaling what already works. But they can't discover what works in the first place. That requires founders to get their hands dirty and be in the trenches. So yes, I wouldn't recommend hiring a GTM engineer in the 0 to 1 stage. But once you've identified repeatability and proven what works? A GTM engineer can be a game-changing hire. Shoutout to my buddy Matteo who's launching the second cohort of the GTM engineer school. Over 5 weeks, you will learn in live sessions the best hands-on tactics. - How to find, enrich, and outreach to ICP leads with Clay - Create social content with Airops - Use tools like Octave, n8n and more Interested? Drop me a DM. I got 5 special tickets for you. ğŸ‘‰ What's your take?

ICP this, ICP that.. But why do you need an ICP at all? And how do you find your ICP? Let's unpack itğŸ‘‡ It's simple math - Let's say you're targeting a 100Mâ‚¬ market. - If you capture 10% of a niche, that's 10Mâ‚¬. - If you try to capture 1% of a 1Bâ‚¬ market, that's also 10Mâ‚¬ But every founder knows that capturing 10% of a focused market is WAY easier than capturing 1% of a broad market. Trying to sell to everyone who'll pay is the slowest path to 1â‚¬M, or at least the slowest to 10â‚¬M ARR. Why? Each customer segment you serve requires its own GTM Foundations. Also, every time you add a new segment, you build a new GTM motion. âŒ Different content âŒ Different channels âŒ Different sales approaches âŒ Different success metrics And the truth is, your small team can't execute multiple GTM motions effectively. Here's how you can effectively validate your ICP 1ï¸âƒ£ Collect data of your customers 2ï¸âƒ£ Break down your customer base into segments and 3ï¸âƒ£ Analyze them against metrics that are indicators of â€˜better fitâ€™ See how you can do it step by step below.

Is AI making GTM easier or harder? I haven't spoken a lot about AI in GTM. But here's my honest take. Most founders are using AI the wrong way in their GTM. They're asking ChatGPT to create posts from scratch, hoping they work. I've seen a lot of founders do this ğŸ‘‡ âŒ "Create my messaging strategy" âŒ "Generate my ICP" âŒ "Build my GTM strategy" This is the easiest way to fall flat in your GTM. Instead, use AI as an enabler like this âœ… You create the ICP doc (from real customer conversations) âœ… You build the messaging framework (from market research) âœ… You define the positioning (from competitive analysis) THEN you feed all that context to AI for execution. When you're 0-1, you don't need to scale; you need to learn. A lot. You need to understand your ICP â†’ Why do they actually buy â†’ What are their pain points â†’ What objections keep coming up â†’ How is your market moving Do the learning first. Build the frameworks. Document the insights. THEN let AI help you execute faster. What's your take on AI in GTM?

You follow the standard sales process for B2B SaaS. But it isn't working for you anymore? How do you make it betterğŸ‘‡ Recently, one of the founders in my advisory told me that he was having difficulty following sales process we had drafted for him. ğ—ªğ—µğ˜†? 1ï¸âƒ£ Because the customer wasn't asking for this particular step, so most of the time he'd skip it. 2ï¸âƒ£ He did not have clarity about the exit criteria for each step ğ—¦ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» âœ… We decided to revamp the sales process. âœ… Based on customer interactions, we changed the steps in the process (given what was important for the customer) âœ… We set clear criteria for when to move a deal to the next stage of the process ğ—ğ—²ğ˜† ğ—œğ—»ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µğ˜ Test your sales process. Focus on customer feedback and tweak your process based on what works best. There are lots of articles and resources about the best sales processes. But what works for everyone might not necessarily work for you. Keep customers at the center of your process and choose what's best accordingly. P.S. But don't forget. You need to guide them thorughout the best 'buying process' - you are the expert and know what's the best process for them to buy your tool Have you experienced this before?

Early-stage growth isnâ€™t about â€œscalableâ€ channels. I see founders obsess over SEO, affiliates, or partnerships way too early. These channels can work. Don't get me wrong. But don't skip 'non scalable' channels. They bring you early momentum. 1ï¸âƒ£ Network sales Talk to your network. Itâ€™s manual, yes. Most people hate it, yes. But it works. 2ï¸âƒ£ Referral sales It's all about how you ask for referrals. If you're specific when asking customers for warm intros, asking for names, roles, or companies, this actually helps. 3ï¸âƒ£ Warm Outbound and Social Content Itâ€™s not â€œscalable,â€ but it converts. These arenâ€™t sexy channels. But they are great to kickstart your GTM. Hereâ€™s how I think about channels - âœ… Primary channels What drives your first $1M. Manual, founder-led, close to the customer. âœ… Secondary channels What you layer on later (SEO, affiliates, paid, partnerships) once your positioning and ICP are proven. What channels have worked out for you?

Getting intros from your network is powerful. But I know sometimes itâ€™s getting a bit messy. - Reviewing their network for ICP fits - Asking them for intros - Sending follow ups - Tracking progress â€¦ So I want to know, do you use a dedicated tool for it?

Unpopular opinion: 0 to 1mil ARR is actually 3 different stages. Not 1. Here's how I see it 1ï¸âƒ£ Stage 1: Hustle mode This is the GTM experimentation phase. Your goal is to find the first 10 / 100 customers (depending on your ACV). You will run different tests and do everything to land your first customers. 2ï¸âƒ£ Stage 2: Focus mode I call this GTM Playbook V1. The goal is to go beyond 10 / 100 customers. To achieve this, you need to stop serving multiple segments and channels and focus on the ones that work the best. So, how do you do this? Analyze your early customers (Early Customer Profile) to find your best-fit customers (Ideal Customer Profile) and focus on them till you scale to â‚¬1 million ARR. 3ï¸âƒ£ Stage 3: Expansion mode Here, your goal is to go beyond 1 million ARR. You can do this in three ways - âœ… Vertically - Same target audience (aka. ICP), but new use cases âœ… Horizontally - Same use case, but new target audiences âœ… Continue what you already do if there is a big enough market. Double-down/scale. To get to this stage, your GTM foundations need to be in place. The GTM foundation spread over: GTM Experimentation + GTM Playbook V1 --- P.S. After the 'focus mode' you achieved Product Market Fit. P.P.S Want me to help building your GTM foundation? Send me a DM.

I usually don't do a lot of podcasts, but when Joran Hofman invited me to talk about the 0-1mil ARR playbook, I HAD to do it! One of the things we discussed was the hard, less spoken about truth about just starting your SaaS.. To your first 10K MRR, you NEED to do the non-scalable thingsğŸ‘‡ In the early days, you don't have much to start with. Not a lot of people know about you or your product. So, how do you grow? By doing these 3 non-scalable and hard things. 1ï¸âƒ£ Leveraging your network - Reach out to your old colleagues, SMEs, advisors, investors (if any), to get to your first set of early customers. 2ï¸âƒ£ Spend time on discovery - Talk to as many potential customers as possible (you can do cold outreach here) - Record every call, show them your product, let them use it, and give you feedback. - High chances these will be your early customers 3ï¸âƒ£ Double down on referrals - Once you have early customers, use your conversations and touchpoints with them to ask for referrals. Ask them, "who else do you think can benefit from this?" - Turn customer success into a revenue driver through expansion and referrals ğŸš¨It's not going to be an easy, repeatable process, But you need to put in the reps in the beginning. You need to do what is non-scalable. To scale your SaaS further down the road. What non-scalable channels have you been using for your SaaS? PS: We discussed the 3-step 0-1mil ARR GTM playbook on the episode with lots of truth bombs and actionable insights. Check the link in the comments to get the full episode.

If you're struggling to create the perfect homepage for your SaaS, this one is for youğŸ‘‡ A good homepage should answer these 6 key questions for your visitors - What is the product/service you offer? - What problem does it solve for me? - What can I do with the product? - Who is it for? So often we scroll back and forth to understand what the company really does, cause all they do is talk in vague lingo like "boost revenue" Here are 8 sections that answer all these questions for your SaaS 1ï¸âƒ£ (Sticky) Navigation Bar 2ï¸âƒ£ Hero Section 3ï¸âƒ£ Social Proof 1 4ï¸âƒ£ Problem Section 5ï¸âƒ£ Solution intro + Value Proposition 6ï¸âƒ£ Social Proof 2 7ï¸âƒ£ FAQ Section 8ï¸âƒ£ Main CTA Check out the structure for each of these sections belowğŸ‘‡ P.S. Founders spend a lot of time on designing the deck. Thatâ€™s important for sure. But whatâ€™s even more important is to think about the storyline. This includes ğŸ‘‡ âœ…The order of the slides âœ…The key message on each slide âœ… The transition from one slide to the next one Ask yourself - are you really communicating a story? Here's how you can do it 1ï¸âƒ£Start with a relevant insight - Market shift, new regulation, - What is the resulting problem of that? - How does it impact the customer (negatively) - Why is the current way of working not ideal anymore. All this comes before you pitch your solution. Itâ€™s about setting the stage first. Once you do that, then 2ï¸âƒ£ Introduce your solution. - What is the product and for whom. - What are the 3 core capabilities/features - What are the usecases of the product. After this comes 3ï¸âƒ£ Social proof - You are not the only one. - We already work with X and Y. - They are seeing great results. Now donâ€™t stop here. Add slides that address 4ï¸âƒ£ Main objections - Whatâ€™s the pricing? - How do you integrate with my current tools? - Are data secure? Invest in a good storyline first. Once this is clear, then work on the design.

Someone has to say this (and I might get a lot of flak for saying it), but at the 0-1mil ARR stage, your advisors need to be hands-on. There is no other way. Hear me out I recently came across a startup that works with an advisor through 1-2x sync-up calls per quarter. I get it, advisors are busy too, and different arrangements work for different people. But the 0-1mil ARR stage is as dynamic as it can get. Things change quickly; if you don't make decisions fast enough, you might just get left behind. Agreed, you don't execute. That is the job of the founder and the team. But as an advisor, You need to be in the trenches with the founders. You need to have a pulse on their progress and guide them in executing strategies with less trial and error. High-level advice helps, but at a later stage, when the startup has repeatable motions in place and growth is predictable. Until then, in my opinion, hands-on advisory is the way to go. Founders, advisors, what do you think?

On Sunday Toni Hopponen , the master of landing pages, and I drop a new guide on mrrunlocked.com When youâ€™re just starting, your product is usually focused. It does one or two jobs well. And thatâ€™s exactly how it should be. But as your product grows, so do its capabilities. It starts to solve more problems and cover more use cases. Thatâ€™s when your homepage alone is not enough anymore, and it makes sense to introduce product pages. Your homepage is âŒ NOT a detailed page about how your product works. âŒ Itâ€™s NOT a page purely on 1 specific use case or 1 specific feature. Instead, âœ… Thatâ€™s the job of product pages. You usually find these pages sitting in the nav bar under â€˜productâ€™ or â€˜solutionsâ€™. Usually, you see 3 different types of pages that contain more detailed product information. 1ï¸âƒ£ Feature pages 2ï¸âƒ£ Use-case pages 3ï¸âƒ£ Persona/Teams, Company type / Industry pages Each of these pages has a slightly different focus. âœ… Feature pages and Use-case pages focus on â€˜how it worksâ€™. âœ… Persona/Teams, company type, and industry pages focus on â€˜Who itâ€™s for and how this type of audience benefits from using the productâ€™. Building those product pages comes with a few benefits: 1ï¸âƒ£ Homepage visitors find information that matches their specific needs quickly 2ï¸âƒ£ Sales and support teams share more information about a specific feature in a snackable format 3ï¸âƒ£ Search engines and LLMs understand the core capabilities of your product and recommend your tool in their answers. ğŸ‘‡ Let us know your best product pages in the comments.

If you're stuck in your GTM, the best way out is to run a 360Â° GTM audit. In fact, it's the first thing I do when I onboard founders for my advisory. Here's the exact framework I use, you can use it for your SaaS tooğŸ‘‡ (Take a pen and paper and answer each of these questions) 1ï¸âƒ£ ICP --> Do you have a clear ICP? --> What are the criteria to qualify/disqualify --> How is this applied in lead gen & CRM? --> Do you know how to source/find your ICP? 2ï¸âƒ£ Positioning --> Who is your direct & indirect competition? --> How are you different from them? --> What is your primary competitor (aka. status Quo)? --> What sets you apart from the status quo? --> What's your product category / usecase? 3ï¸âƒ£ Messaging --> How do you communicate what you do and for whom you are doing it? --> How is the messaging applied on homepage, sales deck and emails? 4ï¸âƒ£ Pricing Analyze --> Packaging & Value Metrics --> POC, Free Trials or Freemium --> Pricing terms (contract length, payment schedule, cancellation policy) 5ï¸âƒ£ GTM Motion --> Your GTM motion (product vs sales led) needs to align with your ICP, product category, and pricing strategy. --> If youâ€™re early stage, donâ€™t do both motions in parallel. 6ï¸âƒ£ Sales funnel & forecast Review the last 12 months of performance --> Understand high level the progress over time --> Focus on Leads, MQL, Deals, Customers, â‚¬, conversion rates --> See if you have a Top or Bottom of the Funnel issue If you want me to audit your GTM, send me a DM.

Here's a BIG mistake founders make during early days of growing their SaaS.. ..and it's got nothing to do with the product Founders look to scale without creating standard and repeatable motions within the company. Case in point I was reviewing the CRM (Hubspot) of a founder I'm currently working with and noticed that all 3 account executives had their own fields and properties on Hubspot. Because of this, they were âŒ Not collecting standardized data âŒ Having a tough time extracting insights from the CRM âŒ Lacking a repeatable sales motion This is a recipe for disaster. Instead, you should âœ… Build a standard list of properties âœ… Make sure EVERYONE is capturing info in the same fields. Sometimes, it's not about aiming for massive revamps, but rather correcting these tiny details that affect your growth. What are the most important fields you've been capturing in your Hubspot?

So many founders get this wrong, but hereâ€™s the truth about building your product, You HAVE to talk to potential customers since day 1, even with an imperfect MVP. It's not a one-time exercise. That's where you're wrong. You need to focus on getting feedback as much and as early as possible, to make sure you are working on the right thing. A few ways to do this, 1ï¸âƒ£Have 2-3 calls per day with potential users. --> Take notes from the calls and show them your progress as you build. 2ï¸âƒ£ Have 5-10 people in your "close circle" --> Share your product, vision, ideas, with them, let them try your product and see how it works. --> Iterate based on their feedback. The best way to reach out to them? 1ï¸âƒ£ Warm intros from your network 2ï¸âƒ£ Cold outreach on LinkedIn Donâ€™t wait for perfection. Talk to customers before and while you build. Your future self (and your users) will thank you.

Messaging is often either: âŒ Untested (â€œwe wrote a landing page and hoped it worksâ€), or âŒ Over-optimized at the surface level (button tests, headline swaps) Here are 7 actionable tactics to test your messaging ğŸ‘‡ (Credits to Emma Stratton for the first 5 tactics) 1ï¸âƒ£ â€œWould my customer seriously ever say that?â€ test â†’ Ask yourself: â€œWould my customer ever say that?â€ 2ï¸âƒ£ â€œIs it jargon?â€ test â†’ Ask yourself if the word/phrase is: -meaningful to your audience - universally understood - credibility booster. If your words donâ€™t mark all 3, replace them with a better alternative. 3ï¸âƒ£ â€œHow short should this be?â€ test â†’ You want your message to only include as many words as you need to be understood. Prefer a clear message over a vague message (even if it means more words). 4ï¸âƒ£ "General or specific messagingâ€ test â†’ The right â€˜altitudeâ€™ depends on the stage of awareness of your customers. - Do they already have a solution like yours? - Or never considered something like this? Generally speaking: âœ… The less they are aware, the wider and more generic your messaging should be. âœ… The more they already know, the deeper and more specific your messaging needs to be. 5ï¸âƒ£ â€œIs this even credible?â€ test â†’ Spot words that sound overpromising, or unrealistic. We all know them: â€œTransformâ€, â€œrevolutionizeâ€ â€œsuccess guaranteeâ€...) 6ï¸âƒ£ â€œCan you spot ICP and product category/use case in your homepage hero section?â€ test â†’ If you read the hero section of your website, do you mention specifically â€˜who this is for? (aka. your ICP)â€ and â€œwhat is it? (aka. product category or use case). 7ï¸âƒ£ â€œDoes this survive the elevatorâ€ test â†’ Imagine you have 20 seconds to explain what your product does to a distracted stranger. If your message can't be understood in that window, itâ€™s too complicated. Simplify until itâ€™s crisp, quick, and clear. ğŸ‘‡ Check out the 'message testing' guide that Gab Bujold ğŸ’€ and I dropped on mrrunlocked.com

Your GTM isn't a "set and forget" system. It needs weekly attention. I schedule weekly/bi-weekly syncs with my founders, and here's the exact routine that helps keep them on track 1ï¸âƒ£ Review your numbers - Website traffic - Signups / MQLs - New pipeline - Closed won & lost If you aren't measuring it, you cannot fix it. 2ï¸âƒ£ Talk to customers - At least 1 call/day. Youâ€™ll spot patterns faster, understand your ICP better. 3ï¸âƒ£ Ship 1 piece of content Pick your format - Blog - Case study - Landing page - Loom explainer video - LinkedIn post. Create weekly, it keeps you on top of your ICP's mind. 4ï¸âƒ£ Push customer feedback - Collect objections, questions, and reactions - Post them in Slack (or wherever your team lives). - Work on the feedback to make your product/process better Feedback is free GTM gold. You donâ€™t need a massive team or complex strategy. You need momentum and weekly check-ins to make sure you're on track. What is your weekly GTM routine?

How to 'test' your messaging to find Message-Market FitğŸ‘‡ Message-Market-Fit is âœ… a an enabler of PMF. âœ… part of â€˜GTM-fitâ€™ It's when your messaging immediately clicks with your ideal buyers. â€œGet itâ€. â€œOh, that makes sense. Iâ€™ve needed something like that.â€ In order to get there, you need to test your messaging. Start with your core messaging blocks. Product Category: JTBD (Jobs to Be Done POV (Points of View) Objections Signals Benefits Capabilities & Features Then draw a hypothesis. " We can increase SQL conversion if we lead more with our unique differentiator compared to our competitors" Build different messaging angles that you want to test against each other. Define the required budget. Launch and test until you get enough data. Analyze results to identify your winners. What message variant showed better results. Apply the winner to all your GTM assets. Want to learn more? Today I launch the guide on mrrunlocked.com with the messaging testing expert Gab Bujold ğŸ’€

Founder: "I'm sending connection requests daily on LinkedIn, but it's still not driving any leads/growth for my startup." A founder I'm working with recently launched a LinkedIn Connection Campaign to expand his ICP network. It failed. Why? Those people did not 100% match his target audience. If you aren't reaching the RIGHT people with your LinkedIn connect campaign.. Your campaign is as good as dead. Here's how we fixed his sales navigator list to reach the right people for the campaign ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ­: Account List We created an â€˜account listâ€™ of companies that matched our ICP criteria. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ®: Lead Search We used the account list as a filter to search for relevant leads. This way, we only ended up with âœ… Relevant people âœ… From the right companies If your connections aren't the right fit, Even your ICP related content is going to fall flat. Make it a weekend exercise to audit your connections. Make sure you are only reaching out to the RIGHT people. It's a small hack, but it'll go a long way.

There are a lot of myths for early stage founders, but there's one that keeps tricking founders, And I hope to break it today.. ğŸš¨You don't need the perfect GTM playbook from day 1. Instead, think of it as an iterative process. While 0 to 1 is a big milestone, it comes with not ONE, but THREE different stages 1ï¸âƒ£ Hustle mode 2ï¸âƒ£ Focus Mode (pre-PMF) 3ï¸âƒ£ Expansion Mode (post-PMF) What works for hustle mode, will certainly not work for focus mode and what works for focus mode, will not work for expansion mode. Each of these stages comes with its playbook, strategy, and channels Your growth across these stages is hardly linear. So the best way to approach this is to keep iterating your GTM playbook. Instead of THE perfect ICP, pricing...from day 1, it is okay to aim for âœ…Multiple ICPs over time âœ…Iterative Pricing âœ…Iterative Positioning & Messaging Constantly work on feedback to make these better over time. No pressure to get it right from Day 1. What do you think?

14 actionable tips and tactics for a strong CRM foundation ğŸ‘‡ Don't let your messy CRM (silently) kill your GTM motion before it even gets going. Apply these tactics and you'll have a strong foundation for growth. 1ï¸âƒ£ Define a single source of truth Centralize all prospect, customer, and interaction data in your CRM (e.g., Clarify ). No spreadsheets, no Notion-as-CRM. 2ï¸âƒ£ Track all touchpoints Track every: âœ… Email (sync your Google Account) âœ… Call (integrate your VoIP call or use the built-in call feature) âœ… Meeting (define different meeting types in your CRM, e.g., Discovery Call, Demo, Onboarding...) 3ï¸âƒ£ Use a hard definition for â€˜deal creationâ€™ I see 2 ways that work: - Create a new deal for MQLs or - only for sales-qualified leads (SQL) 4ï¸âƒ£ Set realistic deal stage probabilities (for weighted pipeline forecast) 3 common mistakes: âŒ Not working with deal stage probabilities at all âŒ Way too optimistic deal stage probabilities âŒ Not updating probabilities to â€˜real historicâ€™ data 5ï¸âƒ£ Tag ICP vs Non-ICP Use tags/fields/labels to separate ICPs from noise. âœ… ICP Fit: Tier 1/2/3 or A/BC âœ… ICP Score: 1-10 6ï¸âƒ£ Use â€œClosed Lostâ€ reason dropdowns The most common mistakes are: âŒ only â€˜text fieldsâ€™ to track lost reasons (--> hard to analyze) âŒ not tracking them at all âŒ only tracking â€˜feature-relatedâ€™ reasons I recommend tracking 7 lost reasonsğŸ‘‡ - Decided for competition - Status quo sufficient - Decision delayed - Too expensive / no budget - missing key features - no response - other Learn about the other 8 tactics in the carousel. Demo calls are tricky. You need to make sure the call is not ending in â€˜silenceâ€™ That prospects 'see what they need' to make a decision. Recently, a founder had a demo with a big client with 10+ stakeholders joining on their side. Here's how I advised him to run the call For sure, there are a ton of sales tactics you can apply. But one thing that turns the full conversation from â€˜I need to entertain 60 minâ€™ into â€˜I guide you to take an informed decisionâ€™ is to SET the stage. ğŸ’¡Start the call by asking for expectations, ask what they want from you: â€œNow we have 60 min together, what needs to happen so that you say the call was valuable for us?â€ ğŸ’¡If you donâ€™t get a lot of responses, you can add â€œUsually when I have calls like this with companies of your size, we talk about X, Y Z. This gives them all the information needed to take an informed decision if and how to move forwardâ€ This is a great way to ensure you address any inhibitions that prospects might have about your product. Demo calls have the capacity to make or break your deal. Make sure you make the most out of them. P.S. This was not the first call. So donâ€™t skip discovery calls.

Founders, if you ONLY rely on Hubspot dashboards to track your KPIs you're making a huge mistake. Here's whyğŸ‘‡ Let's be honest, the only time you actively look at dashboards is either - Right before sales, GTM meetings - When something goes wrong By then it's already too late. As a founder, you should ALWAYS have a pulse on your numbers, regardless of meetings or crisis. Here's what I recommend you do 1ï¸âƒ£ Creat a spreadsheet that helps you track KPIs on a weekly and monthly basis. 2ï¸âƒ£ Every week, spend 5 minutes to - Go to your Hubspot (or your go to CRM) - Check your reports - Copy paste the numbers to the spreadsheet. The 5 sections of a great 2-min product demo video. You want to have a light-weight CTA for your website? A CTA for visitors who aren't confident about booking a call yet? That's where 2-min 'product demo videos' can be very powerful. But most of the time, they are boring. âŒ No storytelling âŒ pure feature f***** âŒ No sales story So last week I worked on a new product demo script for one of my GTM advisory clients. Here are the 5 sections that make your video stand out. 1ï¸âƒ£ The Hook --> Describing the â€˜painfulâ€™ reality before using your tool. â€œIf youâ€™re doing X with Y...you're facing problem X and Y..." "You're not alone...that's how most (ICP) felt before..." 2ï¸âƒ£ Intro of solution (high-level) --> Introducing your product as the solution "There's a better way to do X" "Your product enables ICP to do X and Y" 3ï¸âƒ£ How it works --> "Hereâ€™s how it works...." 4ï¸âƒ£ Social proof & benefits --> Reduce risk & increase trust "Over X+ companies already trust (your product)...and achieving awesome results. "Increase of X, decrease of Y..." 5ï¸âƒ£ CTA --> Guide the next steps "Sounds like a good fit? Book your 30-min tailored demo..." It's a transformation story. From 'painful' status quo to 'desired' future. Similar to your website, sales deck, and case studies. What are good product demo videos?

Your messy CRM can (silently) kill your GTM motion before it even gets going. Getting your CRM right from the start sets the foundation for predictable revenue later. Whether you're bootstrapped, pre-seed or seed stage, do your CRM foundation work! Your CRM is the backbone of your sales process. Here are the 10 most common CRM mistakes I see across early-stage SaaS teams. âŒ Mistake 1: Using different tools/documents in parallel to CRM âœ… â†’ Your CRM needs to be your single source of truth (in almost real-time) âŒ Mistake 2: No definitions to create & move deals âœ… â†’ Define clear entry and exit criteria. âŒ Mistake 3: Inefficient work with deal stage probabilities âœ… â†’ Set realistic deal stage probabilities. Review 1x/ quarter. âŒ Mistake 4: Insufficient work with lost reasons âœ… â†’ Use Lost reason dropdowns + additional text field âŒ Mistake 5: Treating the CRM like a storage system, not a sales tool âœ… â†’ Log activities, set tasks, use templates, and review reports. A good CRM setup makes your sales more efficient. âŒ Mistake 6: No clear owner for CRM hygiene âœ… â†’ Create a CRM playbook everyone needs to follow. Define a CRM owner. âŒ Mistake 7: Using too many custom fields too early âœ… â†’ Apply a sales methodology. Review monthly for unused/irrelevant fields. âŒ Mistake 8: Using the same pipeline for new business and expansion âœ… â†’ Set up different pipelines for new business & expansion. âŒ Mistake 9: No activity tracking (calls, emails, meetings) âœ… â†’ Log every customer interaction in your CRM âŒ Mistake 10: Not customizing CRM to your sales motion âœ… â†’ Customize pipeline stages, fields, and workflows to reflect your real process. What's the best way to get brutal, early feedback on your product? It's simple. It only takes 10 minutes. Let people use your product. Prepare a 10-minute loom video where you âœ… Explore the product âœ… Share your experience using the product You can ask your âœ… Advisors âœ… Early potential customers âœ… Investors âœ… Colleagues/team members To share honest feedback on how they use your product and experience it. I have a contrarian take on Product-market fit. Most people believe product-market fit comes first, followed by GTM Fit. For me? It is GTM Fit that gets you to PMF. PMF has two stages, 1ï¸âƒ£ Problem-Solution Fit (Hustle Mode) 2ï¸âƒ£ GTM fit (Focus Mode) Thanks to Anthony Pierri for this definition. If you've been following me for a while, you know what each of these means. So today, I'm going to share with you signals, that indicate you should move on to the next stage 1ï¸âƒ£ From hustle to focus mode - Different ICPs - Different use cases - Different sources & channels, motions - You start seeing clusters of customers sharing common traits, use-cases, or buying behavior Your â€œbetter-fitâ€ indicators pop up consistently - It becomes hard to â€˜scaleâ€™, indicating you need to narrow down 2ï¸âƒ£ From focus to expansion - You've hit 1â‚¬m / clear PMF and are ready to grow vertically, horizontally, or deepen further Which stage are you at currently? PS: BjÃ¶rn W. SchÃ¤fer , do you still believe otherwise?ğŸ˜œ P.P.S Thanks Joran Hofman for having me and the great discussion on your podcast!

When it comes to competition, you can do two things: fear them or face them upfront. Last week, I worked with a founder to build their 'Competitor Content Hub'. Here's our brainstorming process 1ï¸âƒ£ Reasoning (why do we need one?) We all agreed that - There is existing demand for competitive solutions - Prospects shortlist products before buying and compare alternatives - It is a great way to share our unique positioning and educate the buyers Once our 'why' was clear, we set an actionable and tactical goal 2ï¸âƒ£ Goal To build a hub of pages for prospects to compare our direct and indirect competitors. With this goal in mind, here's the structure we decided upon. 3ï¸âƒ£ Structure We aimed to include content about - Our product vs competitor - Competitor vs competitor - 'Best of product categories' listicles Through the process, though, one question kept coming up again and again, "Do we want to hide these pages or make them visible on the website (e.g. in the footer)" According to me, there are pros and cons for both approaches. What do you think? PS: Few companies that do an amazing job with their competitor hub Livestorm Breakcold Cello Senja

Despite having 300+ customers, vchfy GmbH growth was much slower than expected for nearly 3 years David Goy and Torsten Latussek knew the product had value, but several GTM bottlenecks were holding them backğŸ‘‡ ğŸ”´ Vague ICP ğŸ”´ Unclear Positioning that failed to differentiate them from other coupon platforms ğŸ”´ Untypical SaaS Monetization ğŸ”´ Lack of clarity on the best GTM channels ğŸ”´ No repeatability in the sales process Here's how we reset their GTM Foudation 1ï¸âƒ£ ICP Deep Dive: -Analyzed existing customer base to identify best fit customers (ICP) - their criteria, channels, and buyer persona 2ï¸âƒ£ Positioning & Messaging â€“ Developed a clear narrative to explain what Vchfy does, why it matters, and who it's for. "Google top ranking for 'productname + coupon code' with a CI-compliant voucher page on your own domain" 3ï¸âƒ£ Revamped existing GTM assets based on the new messaging and positioning, 4ï¸âƒ£ Social Proof - Created new case studies with best-fit customers to win trust and close deals faster 5ï¸âƒ£ Analyzed sales call recording to restructure how they do discovery and demo calls 6ï¸âƒ£ Started to revamp their new pricing model (new value metric with tiered plans) 7ï¸âƒ£ Made a clear action plan for next steps - New case study and pricing pages - Referral Sales - Testing of demand capture with Google Ads The results? âœ… A well-defined ICP to focus sales and marketing âœ… Clear positioning that differentiates from generic coupon platforms âœ… Revamped homepage, sales deck, and email flows âœ… A new pricing strategy (being tested at the moment) âœ… Better framework for demo and discovery calls âœ… Go-forward plan to grow revenue (channels & tactics) If you're facing similar challenges, drop me a DM.

Free value proposition audit. Drop your 1-sentence value proposition in the comments and I will share a refined version. Few months ago, I asked founders on LinkedIn to comment their one-line value proposition/messaging, and audited it for them. The response was overwhelming, so many of you wanted the audit. Competition is a sensitive topic for most founders. But it doesn't have to be..In fact, I hope you have competition. Here's whyğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Problem validation Founders often ask - "Am I solving a REAL problem that people will pay for?" The fact that others are solving for it too, indicates that the problem is big enough and needs a solution. 2ï¸âƒ£ Educating the market If the market is not yet aware of the problem/solution, your job is to educate them. But if you're the only player, this entire responsibility falls on you. That's a lot of burden during the early days. With competition around, this responsibility is shared! ğ—›ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²'ğ˜€ ğ—ºğ˜† ğ—®ğ—±ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—°ğ—² - If you're in a crowded market, embrace direct competition and position yourself well. If you're in a less crowded space, focus on winning against indirect competitors like status quo or inaction. Face your competition instead of finding a way around it.

I had the pleasure to host a GTM panel discussion and fireside chat at ARRtist on Tour meets GrowthNXT event. My 6 GTM takeaways of the evening. 1ï¸âƒ£ Controversial opinion on the future of cold calls In times of AI SDRs doing cold calls and Apple launching new features to block calls from unknown people. GTM leaders have different opinions on the success of cold calls in the future. Oliver Manojlovic believes cold calls will still be successful in 3 years, while Stefan Bader is a strong believer that this channel will collapse. 2ï¸âƒ£ Betting on multiple motions Almost all guests had the same opinion. To be successful in the future, you need to run multiple motions at the same time. This depends on the stage of the company. I say if you are below 1â‚¬ million ARR, please only run one motion. 3ï¸âƒ£ AI in GTM I asked Georg Okamoto Hartmut Hahn and Oliver Manojlovic what works and what doesn't. And I expected to hear about crazy Clay automations. But they all agree that especially research and internal processes work great. --> Analyzing call performances to uncover hidden patterns --> Database research (find a customer with X and Y attributes) 4ï¸âƒ£ Narrative power makes you a better leader Robin Karakash explained that in times of changes, like cultural pivots, new market entries, and rebrandings, the biggest challenge is NOT a bad strategy or execution. But rather the absence of a shared sensemaking narrative. That's the power of a strong narrative. It was a really inspiring event with lots of GTM insights shared. 5ï¸âƒ£ AI changes the success of GTM channels Melanie Riebel shared how they adapted their channels. From classical SEO to mainly optimizing content for LLMs. And BjÃ¶rn Wisnewski shares his deep diving into his existing customer base to better understand his ICP and shifting more focus to digital channels (more inside sales on top of field sales). 6ï¸âƒ£ Human-centered channels work Micro events, partnerships, and influencers are channels that work well. The common thread. Humans create trust. Especially in times when Email and LinkedIn inboxes are spammed. Agents doing cold calls and content is AI-written. --- Thanks Julius GÃ¶llner and Stefan Bader , and the whole team, for this great event. ğŸ‘‡Do you think cold calls will be successful in 2028?

I'm totally in it for website audits. Last week I audited a SaaS company's main webpages because the CEO wanted someone external to look at it. Here's my 2 cents 1ï¸âƒ£ Homepage - A primary and secondary CTA are must-haves on the homepage - Add a social proof element in the hero - Add a problem / before section on your homepage, especially if your main competitor is a shitty status quo - Include case studies/testimonials in your navigation bar - Keep CTAs consistent, avoid using different wording - Add an FAQ section 2ï¸âƒ£ Pricing page - Have social proof right above/below your pricing table (or even part of the table) - Highlight a preferred pricing plan - Add â€˜who is the plan forâ€™ right in the pricing table 3ï¸âƒ£ Competitor pages - Include a comparison table - Be honest about your competitors (acknowledge what they do good) - Guide users on how to choose the right product Key insight here, though - sometimes it helps if you get some external advisor to roast your website. P.S. You want me to roast yours? DM me. P.P.S You want to roast mine. Shoot me a DM ğŸ™‚

Founders, be honest. Is creating your sales deck a super daunting task for you? ğŸš¨Do these two things BEFORE you design your sales deck to save hours of back and forth and money. 1ï¸âƒ£ Decide the outline -> You need to convey your story through your sales deck. -> Take each slide within a template and write 1-2 sentences about what part of your story you want to cover on that page. -> Focus on perfecting your messaging for that page. 2ï¸âƒ£ Read it out loud -> Yes, you read that right. -> Read those outlines out loud with your team members/co-founder/friends, anyone. -> This simple step makes sure you have a consistent and compelling story. I recently did this with one of the founders I'm working with, and it was a game-changer. Do these two things before you think of visuals, design or before sending it to your designer. Your sales deck is a powerful tool in your kit. Take time to perfect it and convey your story through it. If you're looking for a template to start with, check out the link in the comments

I have helped 25+ early stage founders in the last 3 years. Here are the 3 things I shared with Joran Hofman that work well consistently in the 0-1mil ARR stage ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Prioritizing Founder-led sales - No one can learn, sell, and adapt faster than the founder - Don't hire a sales team member until you've built a repeatable process - Learnings from early sales are GOLD in building a better product 2ï¸âƒ£ Focusing on 1-2 GTM Channels - Run micro tests with 3-4 channels, but double down only on 1-2 - Donâ€™t try to be everywhere; find the channels that consistently bring qualified leads and go deep. 3ï¸âƒ£ Don't build a new product category (99% of the time) - Build your positioning around an existing category or use case. - It is much easier to explain and sell. Early SaaS is hard. Going from 0-1mil ARR is hard. Hopefully, these 3 tips will help you in your journey. Btw, if this helped you, go check out the full episode of this podcast, I break down the 3-step GTM playbook that helps founders go from 0-1 mil ARR. Link in the comments.

Every founder's worst nightmare? Not having enough runway. One of the ways to stop that from happening? Getting your GTM strategy right from Day 1. I did a podcast with Joran Hofman recently, where he asked me why it was so important for founders to have GTM strategy right from day one. Here's what I told him, Think of your GTM in two parts 1ï¸âƒ£ Strategy 2ï¸âƒ£ Execution Without a strategy, execution wonâ€™t work, and the opposite is true as well. Eg - Your ICP, Positioning and Messaging (strategy) are TOO relevant for GTM execution. Without these, you won't know - Who to sell to - Why customers should pick you - How do you communicate with your customers Without the right GTM playbook, you waste your runway chasing wrong-fit customers and/or unscalable channels. During early days, aim to create repeatability in your GTM. Spend time charting your GTM strategy, you'll be much better off managing your runway and executing your GTM. What do you think? The rest of the episode is full of such insights. Check it out if you're a founder in the 0-1 mil ARR stage. Link in the comments.

I have helped 25+ founders in their GTM, but people often ask, "What's your own GTM (for your advisory)?" So today, I am sharing my own GTM playbook. 1ï¸âƒ£ Content -> I have been writing MRR Unlocked ğŸš€ , my GTM newsletter, bi-weekly for the last 3+ years. -> I have also been posting GTM content daily on LinkedIn My goal of creating content is to - Reach more founders and help them - Build trust - Build relationships with them by providing value upfront It's a long-term game, don't expect immediate results. 2ï¸âƒ£ Referrals I advise most of my founders to do this, so naturally, I've been doing it too. -> I actively ask the founders I have/am working with for case studies, testimonials, and referrals. 3ï¸âƒ£ Partnerships -> I have created a network of trusted partners within different niches in GTM. -> These enable cross recommendations and warm intros. -> I have also been experimenting with VC / business angel partnerships and value-based outreach to ICP founders on LinkedIn (will keep you posted on how it goes) Next on my list are: --> Podcast guest speaking --> Newsletter guest posts --> Deepen VC partnerships Building trust and relationships is key to enabling growth. Content has been one of the best levers to build these. P.S. I have 2 CTAs today: 1ï¸âƒ£ If you are an early-stage B2B SaaS founder, I'd love to help you build your GTM foundation. 2ï¸âƒ£ If you are an early stage investor or agency/expert in the early stage GTM space, let's talk about a partnership.

If there's one thing I keep seeing early-stage founders get wrong again and again, it has to be this.. And I hope I can break this myth today ğŸš¨You don't need the perfect GTM playbook from day 1. Instead, think of it as an iterative process. While 0 to 1 is a big milestone, it comes with not ONE, but THREE different stages 1ï¸âƒ£ Hustle mode 2ï¸âƒ£ Focus Mode (pre-PMF) 3ï¸âƒ£ Expansion Mode (post-PMF) What works for hustle mode, will certainly not work for focus mode and what works for focus mode, will not work for expansion mode. Each of these stages comes with its playbook, strategy, and channels Your growth across these stages is hardly linear. So the best way to approach this is to keep iterating your GTM playbook. Instead of THE perfect ICP, pricing...from day 1, it is okay to aim for âœ…Multiple ICPs over time âœ…Iterative Pricing âœ…Iterative Positioning & Messaging Constantly work on feedback to make these better over time. No pressure to get it right from Day 1. What do you think?

Here are 5 tactics to get more MQLs that I brainstormed last week with one of the SaaS founders I work withğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Customer Success Story Campaign Show proof that you can solve the problem and that they can trust you. -> Embed into the sales process /emails -> Add them in the newsletter -> Re-activation with lost deals / old leads 2ï¸âƒ£ Co-marketing with Integration partners Leverage your partner's network and credibility to reach a wider audience -> Integration page on website -> Co-marketing (joint article, webinar) 3ï¸âƒ£Customer Referral Program Use every touch point with your customers to find who else from their network can benefit from your solution 4ï¸âƒ£Partner Referral Program Incentivize partners to refer your product to their network 5ï¸âƒ£Public â€˜template libraryâ€™ page This one works well, depending on your product. Provide as much value upfront as you can. What are your experiences with these?

Being an early stage founder in B2B SaaS is not easy. Here's the hard, less spoken truth about just starting your SaaS.. To hit your first â‚¬10K MRR, you NEED to do the non-scalable things In the early days, you don't have much to start with. Not a lot of people know about you or your product. So, how do you grow? By doing these 3 non-scalable and hard thingsğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Leveraging your network - Reach out to your old colleagues, SMEs, advisors, and investors (if any), to get to your first set of early customers. 2ï¸âƒ£ Spending time on discovery - Talk to as many potential customers as possible (you can do cold outreach here) - Record every call, show them your product, let them use it, and give you feedback. - High chances these will be your early customers 3ï¸âƒ£ Doubling down on referrals - Once you have early customers, use your conversations and touchpoints with them to ask for referrals. Ask them, "who else do you think can benefit from this?" - Turn customer success into a revenue driver through expansion and referrals ğŸš¨It's not going to be an easy, repeatable process, But you need to put in the reps in the beginning. You need to do what is non-scalable. To scale your SaaS further down the road. What non-scalable channels have you been using for your SaaS?

My last 8 LinkedIn posts and 3 MRR Unlocked ğŸš€ were all about SaaS GTM foundation from â‚¬0 to â‚¬1 million ARR. Now I wanted to turn all insights into 1 master cheatsheet ğŸ‘‡ When I talk about building a strong GTM foundation, I refer to these 10 elements: (I tried to add 1-short description to each element - what I believe is key for each) âœ… Ideal Customer Profile --> Know your best fit customers and say no to your Anti ICP âœ… Positioning --> Know what you are (usecase/product category) and 1 attribute how you are different âœ… Messaging --> Turn positioning into words that resonate with your ICP âœ… GTM Collaterals --> Have your messaging on your relevant assets (website, case study, sales deck...) âœ… Channels --> Find 1-2 channels that attract qualified leads âœ… Pricing --> Find the right value metric. Keep it iterative. âœ… Sales Motion --> Don't perform PLG and SLG simultaneously. âœ… CRM & Tracking --> Build a repeatable process and track it. âœ… Forecasting & Planning --> Reverse engineer your goals. âœ… Internal Operating Systems --> Get internal ready for scaling. --- ğŸ‘‡What is a strong GTM foundation for you?
