GTM Foundations Series Day (8/8): Outro. We've reached the end of our 8-day GTM Foundations series. I had a lot of fun sharing the 7 most important GTM foundations last week. ğŸ‰As bonus, I will cover 4 more aspects of GTM that you need to work on 1ï¸âƒ£ CRM & Tracking -> Your CRM is the best place to learn about your ICP. -> Set company-wide standard fields and ensure everyone in sales populates customer data in those fields. Some fields you shouldn't miss: -> Self reported attribution -> Lost reason -> ICP / Usecase ->Deal stage probability ->Buying roles --> ICP criteria like tech stack, size, alternative solutions... 2ï¸âƒ£ GTM Collaterals Here are a few that 99% of founders need - Homepage - Other website pages: Pricing + Book a Demo + How it works (feature / usecase pages) + Resource - Sales Deck - Case Studies - LinkedIn profiles 3ï¸âƒ£ Forecasting & Planning -> Reverse engineer to break a hard-to-grasp goal into very specific, short-term goals. -> Use these as to-dos to work on within your daily operation. 4ï¸âƒ£ Internal Operations & Systems Create systems to deal with: - Investor Updates - Founder Syncs (weekly meetings, offsites...) - Goal setting frameworks (e.g. OKRs) - Sales, Marketing, Customer Success Syncs - Product & â€˜GTMâ€™ Syncs (Roadmap planing, Customer Feedbacksâ€¦) - Competitive Intelligence Hopefully, by now, âœ… You know and understand the GTM foundations well. âœ… You can use them to grow your SaaS. If you don't, feel free to drop me a DM. I work with SaaS founders 1-on-1 to build and execute a strong GTM foundation to bring your SaaS to â‚¬1 million ARR and Product-Market Fit.

GTM Foundations Series Day (7/8): Pricing. SaaS pricing is considered super complex. But it doesn't have to be. Today, I will break down SaaS pricing for you. Your pricing is simply a combination of 4 factors 1ï¸âƒ£ Value Metrics -> Align these with the customer's value of using your product -> These can be per seat / per user / per subscriber, etc. 2ï¸âƒ£ Packaging & Tiers -> Decide on what (not) to include in tiers. -> Here, you can experiment with feature gating 3ï¸âƒ£ Payment terms Decide on policies like - Contract duration - Cancellation policy - (Auto) renewals and timelines - Billing policy (monthly / yearly) 4ï¸âƒ£ Discount policy -> Create a framework of how, when, and why to give discounts -> Always ask for something in return, like referrals, testimonials, etc. You don't need to have your pricing figured out on day 1. Bonus: Do NOT copy the 'perfect' pricing models from Notion, Miro, Asana of the world. Not if you are early-stage â›” Pricing for early-stage startups is NOT about optimizing growth. I believe pricing should be good enough to NOT stop you from growing to 1â‚¬ million ARR. So it is primarily about: âœ… Aligning pricing model with growth motion (sales-led vs. product-led) âœ… Finding the right value metric (for value-based pricing) âœ… Getting clarity on packaging Start with simple, then iterate on a monthly/quarterly basis. PS: If you are new to this series, check out my previous posts to catch up on the GTM foundations. See you tomorrow! --- Work 1-on-1 with me as your GTM co-pilot to build and execute your GTM foundation â€” over 6 months, in focused 2-week sprints

GTM Foundations Series Day (6/8): Sales Funnel I get asked this a lot. How do you design the perfect buyer journey/sales funnel? A buyer journey connects the last two GTM foundations (channels and sales motion) with the customer's product adoption. Think of it in 4 stages 1ï¸âƒ£ Awareness -> Identify your GTM channels -> Ideally content, referrals work the best -> Get visitors on your website 2ï¸âƒ£ Consideration -> Generate MQLs (or product sign ups) -> Qualify them through a discovery call -> Run demos for qualified leads (SQLs) 3ï¸âƒ£ Decision -> Set up trials/pilots for SQLs -> Negotiate the pricing -> Close the deal 4ï¸âƒ£ Customer success -> Onboard won customers -> Get them active and happy -> Expand & get referrals Here's how you can enhance your funnel âœ… Decide intentionally how you get customers from one stage to the next. âœ… Use sales methodologies like MEDDIC, SPIN, SUGAR, SPICED to define what qualifies a prospect to move to the next stage. That's it! You have your funnel / buyer journey. Draw it out to make the process easier. PS: If you are new to this series, check out my previous posts to catch up on the GTM foundations. See you tomorrow! --- Work 1-on-1 with me as your GTM co-pilot to build and execute your GTM foundation â€” over 6 months, in focused 2-week sprints

GTM Foundations Series Day (5/8): Sales Motion You're already halfway into understanding GTM Foundations ğŸ‰ By this point, we've laid the GTM groundwork, now, let's move to sales. First things first, you need to decide your sales motion. This is how you want users to approach you through the channels. It can be Sales-led or Product-led. âœ… Sales-led -> If the CTA on your website/emails says "Book a demo" you're probably aiming for a sales-led motion. -> A sales team member is involved in the buying process âœ… Product-led -> If you're pushing for "Free Trials", you're aiming for a product-led motion. -> The interaction is directly between your product and the user without any sales involvement. A few factors you need to consider while deciding your sales motion 1ï¸âƒ£ Complexity of your product 2ï¸âƒ£ Length of your buying process 3ï¸âƒ£ Pricing 4ï¸âƒ£ Customer preference Based on these, you can decide what works for your SaaS. PS: If you are new to this series, check out my previous posts to catch up on the GTM foundations. See you tomorrow! --- Work 1-on-1 with me as your GTM co-pilot to build and execute your GTM foundation â€” over 6 months, in focused 2-week sprints

GTM Foundations Series Day (4/8): Channels By this point, you have hopefully understood the major strategy-related foundations - ICP, positioning, and messaging. But, how do you REACH your ICP to convey your messaging? Good news is, you have plenty of options to reach your ICP. They're called GTM channels. There are 21 different channels, to be precise. But, as an early-stage startup, keep in mind that 1ï¸âƒ£ You can NOT run more than 3 (better 1-2) in parallel 2ï¸âƒ£ Not all channels are equally relevant for you (depends on your ICP, ACV, own skills) Depending on your stage, some channels are a better fit than others. If you are just starting, use primary channels like - Network & Referrals - Content & SEO - Social Selling (LinkedIn) - Outbound - Social Listening - Google Ads Once you find a primary channel that works, use secondary channels like - Affiliates - LinkedIn Ads - Influencers - Events - PR - Partnerships - Communities It's tempting to use multiple channels at once, to "speed up" your growth. But it'll most likely slow you down. Instead, run micro tests to see what works and double down only on those channels. Wanna deeo dive into these 21 channels? Link is in the comments. PS: If you are new to this series, check out my previous posts to catch up on the GTM foundations. See you tomorrow! --- Work 1-on-1 with me as your GTM co-pilot to build and execute your GTM foundation â€” over 6 months, in focused 2-week sprints

GTM Foundations Series Day (3/8): Messaging Positioning, as we spoke in the last post, is an intangible concept. So, as founders, how can you use it to grow your SaaS? Through Messaging. Messaging is how you turn your positioning into something tangible. Think of it this way, âœ… You have a great product âœ… You have mapped your users and ICP âœ… You know your positioning in the market But what next? Notice the gap here. How do you TELL your ICP that you are the best fit for them? How do you communicate your value proposition to them? Messaging bridges this gap and lets you communicate your value to ICP. Your messaging is built on 5 parts âœ… Market âœ… ICP âœ… Competitive alternatives âœ… Product âœ… Value proposition Use it in GTM collaterals like âœ… Homepage âœ… Sales Deck âœ… LinkedIn posts âœ… Case Studies âœ… Sales Demos Take some time to get it right. It is a crucial foundation of your GTM. If you want to know how to nail your messaging and frame your one-line value proposition, link in the comments. PS: If you are new to this series, check out my previous posts to catch up on the GTM foundations. See you tomorrow! --- Work 1-on-1 with me as your GTM co-pilot to build and execute your GTM foundation â€” over 6 months, in focused 2-week sprints

GTM Foundations Series Day (2/8): Positioning. Now that you know your ICP, you need to establish your product as the best choice to solve their problem. Why? Because even if there are similar solutions out there (which there will be) Your expertise in a use case and the ICP you cater to might be totally different than theirs. So, how do you do this? By positioning your product. Positioning helps your customers understand 1ï¸âƒ£ Who benefits from your product = Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) 2ï¸âƒ£ What your product does = Product Category and/or Primary Use Case 3ï¸âƒ£ Why itâ€™s better than the default option = Limitations of Status Quo + Your Key Benefits 4ï¸âƒ£ How itâ€™s different from other alternatives = Unique Differentiator / Positioning Angle To nail your positioning, âœ… Build clusters of solutions, use-cases, and target customers âœ… Build connections and decide who / what is a good fit âœ…Add arguments why specific connections are good/bad ğŸ’¡Quick positioning testğŸ’¡ If you're on a customer call, being compared to a product that is NOT a competitor, you have a positioning issue. Bonus: - Check your homepage and ask yourself if you answer all these questions on your website (if not: you need to work on your positioning) To learn how to get your positioning right, see the link in the comments. PS: If you are new to this series, check out my previous posts to catchup on the GTM foundations. See you tomorrow! --- Work 1-on-1 with me as your GTM co-pilot to build and execute your GTM foundation â€” over 6 months, in focused 2-week sprints

GTM Foundations Series Day (1/8): ICP. Your SaaS won't grow if you don't know WHO you're building for. ICP is the first foundation of your GTM. Everything else builds up on it. Here's what you need to know about ICP Your ICP is NOT the same as Early Customer Profile (ECP). ECPs are your first 10-100 customers. The ones you land when you are in 'hustle mode' But these are most likely across âŒ Multiple use-cases âŒ Different customer types So not ideal for growth. To grow, niche down to an ICP that gets the MOST value from your solution. A powerful ICP has two parts âœ… Ideal Company âœ… Ideal Persona (User + Buyer) My ICP framework (on Miro) has more than 10k views. And it covers 20+ criteria of a good ICP. But here's how you go from ECP to ICP. 4 steps to go from ECP to ICP 1ï¸âƒ£ Define your â€˜better fitâ€™ indicators 2ï¸âƒ£ Collect data on your early customers 3ï¸âƒ£ Break down your customer base into segments 4ï¸âƒ£ Analyze customers against metrics that are indicators of â€˜better fitâ€™ Once you have your ICP, track them in your CRM, To make your GTM easier and sales predictable. If you want: - a detailed guide to execute each of these steps, - my ICP framework then, check out the link in the comments. PS: Don't forget to map your Anti-ICP, who you do NOT want as customers. It's equally important to help you focus. See you tomorrow with the next foundation! --- Work 1-on-1 with me as your GTM co-pilot to build and execute your GTM foundation â€” over 6 months, in focused 2-week sprints

When I work with SaaS founders, one of the first things I tell them is that a huge discount doesn't close deals faster. You need to convince the stakeholders that your product solves their problem and is the best solution for a very specific use case. Pricing can âœ… be a game stopper, but âŒ not a reason to win deals. What I mean by this is that B2B buyers do not just buy products because they are now cheaper. They buy because they understand the value (or at least are convinced enough to test it out). So value is closing deals. Pricing then can be just a game-stopper. A reason to lose deals. But never a reason to win deals. P.S. Always try to give discounts for something in return (case study, referral, quote). P.P.S. Check out the new SaaS Go-To-Market Report by ChartMogul and Sofia Faustino

It sucks to see founders getting stuck at $500k ARR with no clue what's wrong and how to get to $1mil. If you're stuck at that stage, don't worry. Here are a few things you can do ğŸ‘‡ (I know this from having helped 20+ founders in their GTM in the last two years) 1ï¸âƒ£ Do a sales funnel deep dive -> Try to map the part of the funnel that is broken. Is it awareness, conversion, churn? Enough new pipeline? Good Win rate? Healthy churn rate? Fix accordingly. 2ï¸âƒ£ Find and nail your ICP -> To scale, analyze your early customers to identify your best ICP and go after only them. Don't try to 'scale' in different usecases and different ICPs to early. Less is more. 3ï¸âƒ£ Create a repeatable sales motion -> Document your sales playbook step by step and note what works. -> Aim to create a standardized process for sales. This will also help when you start building your sales team. 4ï¸âƒ£ Double down on 1-2 GTM channels -> Instead of trying to be everywhere, identify 1-2 channels that worked for you in the past and double down on those heavily. Make sure you track your sources properly. I'm a big fan of self-reported attribution. 5ï¸âƒ£ Invest in a referral engine -> This depends on your ACV, but referrals are a great channel to scale during early days. Every customer interaction can be a source for a warm intro/referral. Depends on your sales motion, you have different sources for referrals: - Your sales calls, onboarding calls, support calls. - In-product announcement - Post NPS surveys 6ï¸âƒ£ Invest in social proof and case studies -> You need to build trust with prospects, that your product can solve their problem. -> Build social proof and case studies from the customers that you already have, and use them to convince new customers. If you need help in executing any of these, or with your GTM in general, drop me a DM. Let's get building!

"If you only had ONE day with a founder, what would you fix?" I recently got asked this question and it caught me slightly offguard. Because GTM is not a one day thing. It requires months of focused work to succeed. But here's what I told them anyway 1ï¸âƒ£ I'd dig into their sales funnel to identify what is not working - Usually, it's either a Top of Funnel awareness problem, or a Middle of Funnel conversion issue. - Whatever it is, I'd fix that first to make sure the pipeline isn't leaky. 2ï¸âƒ£ I'd review their key GTM assets like website, sales deck and sales call recordings The goal? - To identify if their positioning and messaging is well executed. - Is their Who, What, Why clear? And finally, 3ï¸âƒ£ I'd analyze their definition of ICP - The idea is to see the "tightness" of their ICP, how clear are they in understanding their ICP. - Most founders think they know their ICP, but their pipeline tells a different story. - So Iâ€™d compare their ICP definition to their actual pipeline and see if it is aligned. ğŸš¨GTM foundations are all dependent on each other. So, it is essential to have some of these basics in place, else scaling your GTM will be hard. âŒ Honestly, you canâ€™t fix everything in a day. Fixing GTM isnâ€™t a quick job. But sure, you can aim to find the one thing holding your business back. Feel free to DM if you want your GTM audited.

That's it! You have your funnel / buyer journey. Draw it out to make the process easier. Sales-led VS Product-led. âœ… Sales-led -> If the CTA on your website/emails says "Book a demo" you're probably aiming for a sales-led motion. -> A sales team member is involved in the buying process âœ… Product-led -> If you're pushing for "Free Trials", you're aiming for a product-led motion. -> The interaction is directly between your product and the user without any sales involvement. A few factors you need to consider while deciding on your sales motion 1ï¸âƒ£ Complexity of your product 2ï¸âƒ£ Length of your buying process 3ï¸âƒ£ Pricing/ACV 4ï¸âƒ£ Customer preference Based on these, you can decide what works for your SaaS. SaaS pricing is considered super complex. But it doesn't have to be. At least not if you're < â‚¬1 million ARR. It's a simple transaction. You provide value to users (by solving their problem) They invest in you (by paying your price) Your pricing is simply a combination of 4 factors 1ï¸âƒ£ Value Metrics -> Align these with the customer's value of using your product -> These can be per seat / per user / per subscriber, etc. Your value metric should - Be easy to understand - Align with the customersâ€™ value of using your product - Be scalable and grow with customersâ€™ usage of your product 2ï¸âƒ£ Packaging & Tiers -> Decide on what (not) to include in tiers. -> Here, you can experiment with feature gating (if you want) Most of the time, feature gating is not recommended early stage. 3ï¸âƒ£ Payment terms Decide on policies like - Contract duration - Cancellation policy - (Auto) renewals and timelines - Billing policy (monthly / yearly) 4ï¸âƒ£ Discount policy -> Create a framework of how, when, and why to give discounts -> Always ask for something in return, like referrals, testimonials, etc. You don't need to have your pricing figured out on day 1. Start with simple, then iterate on a monthly/quarterly basis. I like to think about pricing as something iterative. You have a pricing strategy to get from: 1ï¸âƒ£ 0 to first 10 customers = pricing v1 2ï¸âƒ£ 10-100 customers = pricing v2 3ï¸âƒ£ 100 to X = pricing v3 Your pricing needs to match the stage of your company. If you need a detailed guide on how to price your SaaS, I'm launching an episode about GTM Foundations this Sunday. Don't miss it. Link in the comments PS: What are you struggling with in terms of pricing currently?

But, as an early stage startup, keep in mind that 1ï¸âƒ£ You can NOT run more than 3 (better 1-2) in parallel 2ï¸âƒ£ Not all channels are equally relevant for you (depends on your ICP, ACV, own skills) These channels enable you to communicate your messaging to your ICP. Depending on your stage, some channels are a better fit than others. If you are just starting, use primary channels like - Network & Referrals - Content & SEO - Social Selling (LinkedIn) - Outbound - Social Listening - Google Ads Once you find a primary channel that works, use secondary channels like - Affiliates - LinkedIn Ads - Influencers - Events - PR - Partnerships - Communities It's tempting to use multiple channels at once, to "speed up" your growth. But it'll most likely slow you down. Instead, run micro tests to see what works and double down only on those channels. Need help on how to run each of these channels? Founders have 3 target audiences, NOT 1. 1. Target customers 2. (Future) Employees 3. Investors --> only if you want investors of course. Most VC-backed founders focus their messaging too much on 3. But the big-vision messaging that resonates with VC do NOT resonate with potential customers. They care about different things. VC = long-term vision VC = big TAM VC = future opportunities Customers = Fix the problem today Customers = specific audience (me?) Customers = product capabilities today So when I work with founders on building their messaging. We try to seperate the messaging from the pitch deck (visionary messaging) from the sales deck & homepage (messaging for clients). P.S. I just saw that my SaaS Messaging framework was used 4500+ times. Send me a DM if you want it too.

Case studies and testimonials are your (secret) GTM weapon. Before someone buys, they need proof that your product works (aka. social proof). And thereâ€™s no better proof than real customers saying, â€œThis SaaS changed my business.â€ - Customer X Thatâ€™s why case studies are one of your most crucial GTM assets. You can (and should) use case studies: âœ… on your website âœ… in your sales deck âœ… on your blog articles & landing pages âœ… on social (e.g. LinkedIn posts) âœ… in your sales prospecting âœ… for fundraising But when Romana Kuts and I work with SaaS founders, we usually hear the same 3 challenges: âŒ How do we get that proof when youâ€™re just starting? âŒ What type of case studies & testimonials work the best? âŒ How do we write a good case study? What is a good case study structure? So we decided to join forces and write a guide. The case study guide will cover: âœ… Where and how to get your first testimonials - even if you donâ€™t have customers yet. âœ… How to find testimonials everywhere - sometimes theyâ€™re already out there, you just need to collect them. âœ… Case study trends you should know - from traditional written case studies to Walls of Love, video testimonials, and quote libraries. âœ… How to structure and distribute case studies for maximum impact, ensuring they reach the right audience. âœ… Case Study Interview Questions âœ… SaaS Case Study Page template you can steal :) ğŸ‘‰ Drop your favorite case studies & testimonials in the comments. Weâ€™re collecting the best examples. hashtag # saas hashtag # gtm hashtag # saasmarketing

How clarity on positioning and messaging turned into a new homepage for Innkeepr ğŸ‘‡ I've been working with Willi Linke on building the GTM foundation for Inkeepr for 6 months. And we are seeing great results. He managed to close deals with leading e-commerce brands. Companies like LILLYDOO GmbH asambeauty DocMorris and many more. We used the framework to rework 2 main GTM assets: 1ï¸âƒ£ New Homepage 2ï¸âƒ£ New Sales Deck Based on the messaging framework, we drafted our first homepage design in Canva. Did some iterations. There's so much talk about positioning. But how can you, as founders, use positioning to grow your SaaS? Through Messaging. Messaging is how you turn your positioning into something tangible. Think of it this way, âœ… You have a great product âœ… You have also mapped your users and ICP But what next? Notice the gap here. How do you tell your ICP that YOU are the best fit for them? How do you communicate your value proposition to them? Messaging bridges this gap and communicates your value to your ICP. Use it in your GTM collaterals like âœ… Homepage âœ… Sales Deck âœ… LinkedIn posts âœ… Case Studies âœ… Sales Demos To better reach your ICP. Take some time to get it right. It is a crucial foundation of your GTM. If you want to know how to nail your messaging and frame your one-line value proposition, check out our latest episode on GTM Foundations at MRR Unlocked. Link in the comments.

Your ICP is NOT your Total Addressable Market (TAM). Your TAM = The big market you sell to your investors Your ICP = The part of the market that you target today with your product Your ECP = A sub-segment of your ICP, that is easier to win early on. Your ICP is NOT the same as ECP and here's whyğŸ‘‡ ECPs are your first 10-100 customers. The ones you land when you are in 'hustle mode' But these are most likely across âŒ Multiple use-cases âŒ Different customer types So not ideal for growth. To grow, niche down to an ICP that gets the most value from your solution. A powerful ICP has two parts âœ… Ideal Company âœ… Ideal Persona (User + Buyer) Here are 4 steps to go from ECP to ICP 1ï¸âƒ£ Define your â€˜better fitâ€™ indicators 2ï¸âƒ£ Collect data on your early customers 3ï¸âƒ£ Break down your customer base into segments 4ï¸âƒ£ Analyze customers against metrics that are indicators of â€˜better fitâ€™ Once you have your ICP, track them in your CRM, To make your GTM easier and sales predictable. If you want a detailed guide on how to execute each of these steps, check out our upcoming episode at MRR Unlocked. PS: Don't forget to map your Anti-ICP, who you do NOT want as customers. It's equally important.

Last month, I spoke about having an accountability buddy to keep your growth in check. It's been 2 months for me now, and this is how it's been going so far We've figured out a structure that works for us âœ… We meet for around 3 hours on a bi-weekly basis âœ… Each of us gets 1.5 hours to share our updates, progress, goals We pour our thoughts out to each other, and this helps set goals for the next time too! One downside of being a solopreneur is you don't always have someone to - Brainstorm - Share your goals with - Bounce off ideas - Strategize with Having someone who not only listens to your ideas, but also gives you feedback and holds you accountable for execution is gold. I had 3 goals for my business 1ï¸âƒ£ Launching a website 2ï¸âƒ£ Publishing 2 new case studies 3ï¸âƒ£ Closing 1 new client The fact that I was accountable to someone Maximilian Antosch made me push even harder in achieving these goals. And guess what? I've almost achieved all three. So get yourself an accountability buddy, you won't regret it. PS: Check out my new website where I bring ALL my GTM resources in one place for you to use - https://lnkd.in/ekvpTEAu

What is it that gets founders from â‚¬0 to â‚¬1 mil ARR? 10 GTM foundation parts that bring you to the first Big Milestone in a founder's journey - Product-Market Fit (PMF). It's a simple formula Problem-solution fit + Go-to-market fit = Product Market Fit You need to âœ… Validate the problem âœ… Validate your solution to it âœ… Identify the best channels to get the solution to your ICP And there you have it. But most founders I speak to still struggle with it. To help you with this, I have prepared a checklist of things you need to have in place to go from 0 to 1 mil ARR. To PMF. You need to work on 1ï¸âƒ£ Ideal Customer Profile 2ï¸âƒ£ Positioning 3ï¸âƒ£ Value Proposition & Messaging 4ï¸âƒ£ GTM Collaterals 5ï¸âƒ£ Pricing 6ï¸âƒ£ Sales Motion 7ï¸âƒ£ CRM & Tracking 8ï¸âƒ£ Forecasting & Planning 9ï¸âƒ£ Internal Operating Systems ğŸ”Ÿ Channels Check out the visual below to see what exactly you need to tick off within each of these components ğŸ‘‡ If you want to deep-dive into each of the 10 elements, then ğŸ‘‰ Don't miss the guide that I publish on mrrunlocked this Sunday ğŸ‘‰ Send me a DM and I share with you detailed guides on each of the 10 elements.

I started MRR Unlocked ğŸš€ just as a place to share insights on SaaS GTM. 3 years and 4700 subscribers later, it has turned into my biggest growth channel. When I left my last startup, I only wanted a place to share what I learned. But when I got messages from people who liked my content, that feedback was a push to keep going. Writing helped me become crisp at sharing my insights. It helps me get better at organizing my thoughts, and it helps others who read it. However, growth did not happen overnight. It was slow and steady and hardly a hockey stick. For three years, I stayed consistent. Every two weeks, a new episode, almost never missing a beat. A few things made all the difference: ğŸ”¸ I look at what other writers do Kyle Poyar Matteo Tittarelli âš¡ï¸ Emily Kramer Daniel Zsolt RÃ©nyi - thanks for the inspiration ğŸ”¸ Newsletter cross-recommendations bring in about 20% of my subscribers ğŸ”¸ I clear out inactive subscribers to keep engagement high ğŸ”¸ I use LinkedIn as an acquisition channel to bring people to my newsletter ğŸ”¸ Investing in good design (thanks Florian Goertzen has been a game changer because images do have the highest real estate on LinkedIn. Writing started as a way to share my thoughts. Now, itâ€™s my main inbound channel. Every episode helps me learn, and helps others too. Big Thank You to everyone who has been reading the newsletter and supporting me. and also to all my sponsors of the newsletter ğŸ™Œ If you aren't already, go check it out!

Founders, if you do these 3 things every quarter, you immediately increase the chances of your startup succeeding Here's what you need to doğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Pricing deep dive You can analyze - Packaging & Value Metrics - POC, Free Trials or Freemium - Pricing terms (contract length, payment schedule, cancellation policy) ğŸ’¡ Best is to take one of these at a time and do a full deep dive on a quarterly (or at least bi-annually) basis. 2ï¸âƒ£ GTM channel audit Analyze the performance of your GTM channels like outbound, ads, content, etc. to understand - If you need more resources - What's working - What's not working and needs to be stopped 3ï¸âƒ£ Analyze 'Lost Reasons' Try to gain insights like - Which competitors are you losing to? - Whose name keeps coming up frequently - What are your top reasons (status quo, indecision?) ğŸ’¡ Learning why you are losing is pure gold. Use these insights to offer a better product to your prospects. You might say, Alex, founders already have 1000 other things on their plates, do they need to do these 3 too? The truth is, to succeed, you cannot rely only on a great product. You NEED to consistently build a strong foundation for your GTM as well. Agree?

10 hard truths about working with me. Q&A with Ayunis / Locaboo CEO Andreas Michel on our 24+ month GTM collab. I always wanted to know: 'How is it working with me? So I asked Andi a few questions - I wanted brutal honesty from him ğŸ˜€. Let's go. 1ï¸âƒ£ What helped you surprisingly well that you didnâ€™t expect from me? --> Your radical focus on clarity. No PowerPoint overload, just one question: â€œWhat drives revenue and growth within our ICP?â€ 2ï¸âƒ£ Whatâ€™s one trait of mine thatâ€™s incredibly effectiveâ€”but occasionally frustrating? --> You're relentless. Thatâ€™s incredibly valuable - even if you sometimes just wish youâ€™d let it slide. 3ï¸âƒ£ When have you felt the most challenged by me? --> When you tore apart our entire sales setup. You cut old habits and sharpened our ICP. That meant letting go of a lot. It was tough, but necessary. Nothing was the same after that. Thankfully. 4ï¸âƒ£ Have I ever pushed you too far or too fast? What happened? --> Yes. Quite often actually ğŸ˜‚. And Iâ€™m glad you did. 5ï¸âƒ£ Whatâ€™s something I do that took time to appreciate? --> Your directness. You're highly goal-oriented and always come in with a clear plan. In the first week, I often thought, â€œThis could get interesting.â€ 6ï¸âƒ£ Whatâ€™s one moment you questioned working with me? --> Yes, during one of our first discussions about our target group and ICP. It was tough, and to be honest, it sometimes felt like a bet. "If we go through with this, it could go really well, or we could lose just everything." But in the end, you were right. Honestly, that was the hope when we brought you in. 7ï¸âƒ£ What do I do that makes you feel genuinely supported? --> You never just criticized, you always thought things through, pushed alongside us, and gave 100%, even as an external. I always said: we donâ€™t need just a consultant who talks, we need someone who puts on the boots and gets things done. 8ï¸âƒ£ What advice from me took time to sink in? --> Focus on one clear ICP. Digging deep instead of trying to be everything to everyone was a game-changer. But it took time to fully understand just how critical that really was. 9ï¸âƒ£ If someone new were about to work with me, what would you warn them about? --> Get ready for speed, straight talk, and questions that push you way out of your comfort zone. ğŸ”Ÿ Whatâ€™s something you wish I did more of? What do you wish I did less of? --> I wouldâ€™ve loved to have more office time together. Those in-between conversations were incredibly helpful for me. And you couldâ€™ve lost a few more table tennis games; the team was getting a bit demoralized ğŸ˜‰ Bonus: Whatâ€™s one â€œhard truthâ€ about working with me thatâ€™s ultimately a gift? --> You donâ€™t let us get away with excuses. ğŸ‘‡ What question should I ask in my next Q&A?

One Founder must own Go-to-market for ever. There is no "transition out", your role just evolve in 6 founder-led sales stages ğŸ‘‡ There's a dangerous myth circulating among founders "Once you reach â‚¬X in revenue, you can hand off sales to professionals and focus on being a real CEO." This well-intentioned but catastrophically wrong advice has killed lots of promising startups. Being involved in and being the steward of the revenue engine is a lifelong founding decision. One founder must always be involved. Why? Founder-led sales isn't just about the founder personally closing deals (though it starts there). It's about the founder driving the revenue engine for the entire existence of the company. Founders who delegate sales too early find themselves completely disconnected from market reality. They lose touch with critical market truths: ğŸ”¸ Are customers actually willing to pay for your solution? ğŸ”¸ Which features truly drive purchase decisions? ğŸ”¸What objections consistently block deals? ğŸ”¸ Is the pricing aligned with perceived value? Who do you compete most with (direct & indirect competition)? ğŸ”¸Is your messaging still resonating with your ICP? So when growth stalls, they lack the context to diagnose what's wrong. All these things require the founder to be close to the metal, close to the action, steering from the source of truth, and it comes only from direct communication with the customer. If there is anyone else between you (the founder) and the customers/prospects, you'll most likely receive biased information based on who's giving it to you. For these reasons, the founder must be close to the go-to-market forever.

The biggest killer of startups is a detachment from reality, itâ€™s how promising startups die. When you delegate sales too early, You become completely disconnected from market reality. So when growth stalls, you lack the context to diagnose what's wrong. When you do outbound prospecting yourself, you understand nuances like âœ… The messaging needed to attract a prospect, âœ… What makes a good ICP & Buyer persona âœ… What they care about (Pain points, objections, critical events...) Someone else doing this for you increases the likelihood of failure because you lack clarity about critical points like - What goals should you set for your business? - What is the best way to deploy resources? - Who is the best hire? - What should be your product roadmap? If there is anyone else between you and the customers/prospects, You'll most likely receive biased information based on who's giving it to you. If you're a founder, especially at the early stage, You HAVE to be close to GTM forever, it's a non-negotiable for success.

An early customer program can be a great tactic to close your first 10-100 paying customers I've been working with Tawuya C. and the eleni finance team, and they had a great product, but they were still very early in their GTM. My solution to them? An early customer program. It's a great way to work closely with your market and get first customers. Here's how we structured a good early customer program for their early customers: They got: 1ï¸âƒ£ Early access to the platform and all its features 2ï¸âƒ£ Dedicated Finance Team to reach out anytime 3ï¸âƒ£ Free access for a 60-day pilot phase 4ï¸âƒ£ Special price for the 1st year (99â‚¬ instead of 499â‚¬ per month) 5ï¸âƒ£ Exclusive 50% discount from Year 2 6ï¸âƒ£ Consultancy sessions with an expert CFO (professional service) for free 7ï¸âƒ£ Referral perks (1x extra CFO session for each referral) 8ï¸âƒ£ Access to the Customer Slack group If you don't have an early customer program yet, you're missing out on both - Building a better product - Reaching your early customers faster Feel free to DM if you want to know more about how you can structure an early customer program for your startup. P.S. You will find the Link to the Early customer program slides in the comments. P.P.S. Need a better 'Finance Cockpit' for your business? Eleni might be a good fit.

I always recommend founders to have 1 ICP. But I need to admit, that this is wrong. You will have a lot of different ICPs over time ğŸ‘‡ So first things first. âŒ Your TAM is not your ideal customer profile. Especially if youâ€™re VC-funded and talk a lot about the HUGE market, itâ€™s a common mistake. Your TAM is something you will (eventually) win in 5+ years, but not today. In order to 'win' your TAM, you need multiple (different) ICPs over time. So live with the fact that your ICPs will change over time. Think about it this way: Your ICP today brings you to your next milestone. Once you hit the next milestone, you can revisit your ICP. How do you think about your ICP?

Founder-led sales isn't a phase you graduate fromâ€”it's a permanent responsibility. There's a dangerous myth circulating among foundersğŸ‘‡ "Once you reach $X in revenue, you can hand off sales to professionals and focus on being a real CEO." This well-intentioned but catastrophically wrong advice has killed more promising startups than Seth DeHart and I can count. Being involved in and being the steward of the revenue engine is a lifelong founding decision. ğŸ’¡ One founder must always be involved ğŸ’¡ Founder-led sales isn't just about the founder personally closing deals (though it starts there). It's about the founder driving the revenue engine for the entire existence of the company. Yes, your role will evolve. Yes, you'll eventually build a team. But no, you should never fully disconnect from sales. Think of it this way: --> In the beginning, you're the engine. --> Later, you're the engineer. --> Eventually, you're the architect. But you're always, ALWAYS responsible for ensuring the machine runs. âœ… It's certainly transitioning out of solo selling or founder selling, âŒ But not out of sales entirely. Founders who delegate sales too early find themselves completely disconnected from market reality. They lose touch with critical market truths: - Are customers actually willing to pay for your solution? - Which features truly drive purchase decisions? - What objections consistently block deals? - Is the pricing aligned with perceived value? - Who do you compete most with (direct & indirect competition)? - Is your messaging still resonating with your ICP? So when growth stalls, they lack the context to diagnose what's wrong. So one more time: One Founder must own the go-to-market motion for a very long time. ğŸ‘‡ Disagree?

I've partnered with Seth DeHart to deep dive into phase 4 of Founder-Led Sales: Making your GTM predictable. With your first hire(s) in place, you focus on creating a truly predictable process with clear KPIs and conversion metrics. You need to understand factors like HOW many prospects need to be entered into a cadence â¬‡ï¸ To generate HOW many discovery calls, â¬‡ï¸ To get how much pipeline and opportunities, â¬‡ï¸ To produce HOW much revenue in WHAT time You start to make your GTM predictable and can answer: âœ… Your MQL to SQL conversion rate âœ… Your SQL to customer conversion rate (deal win rate) âœ… Your sales cycle âœ… Your average contract value (ACV) You also develop sales methodologies that work for your specific business during this phase.. The goal is to come up with a sales forecast that allows you to know your exact targets on a - Daily, - Weekly, - Monthly, and - Quarterly basis To hit your next revenue milestone. If you can bring this predictability and repeatability to your team, you're doing great. Seth and I shared loads of such key advice in our latest episode of MRR Unlocked. If you're a founder, I highly recommend you check this episode out.

10 things that separate founders who succeed at founder-led sales from those who don't ğŸ‘‡ Successful founders - 1ï¸âƒ£ Sell early and often. No learning comes close to the insights from this process. 2ï¸âƒ£ Document everything. What worked/didn't work, what questions arose? This becomes the foundation of GTM playbook. 3ï¸âƒ£ Focus on repeatability before chasing scale. One repeatable motion >> randomly closed deals. 4ï¸âƒ£ Stay in the trenches even after the first sales team is hired. 5ï¸âƒ£ Build micro playbooks (discovery call, demo, objection handling) and document processes for all of these separately. 6ï¸âƒ£ Hire for exactly what is needed today, not who could eventually take up a VP Sales role. 7ï¸âƒ£ Establish a qualification framework and stick to it. Don't spend time on leads that aren't a fit. 8ï¸âƒ£ Leverage their credibility as a founder. Prospects will often open up more and give you direct feedback. 9ï¸âƒ£ Use what they hear in sales to influence product decisions weekly. ğŸ”Ÿ Are shameless when it comes to asking for referrals. How you shape up your GTM org in the early days is crucial for the success of your startup. If you're in the process of figuring âœ… Founder sales or âœ… Transition to founder-led sales, Seth DeHart and I have worked on a guide that will help you with just this. Comment 'founder' or drop me a DM, I'll send it right over to you. Anything missing?

Do NOT copy the 'perfect' pricing models from Notion, Miro, Asana of the world. Not if you are early-stage â›” Pricing for early-stage startups is NOT about optimizing growth. I believe pricing should rather be good enough to NOT stop you from growing to 1â‚¬ million ARR. So it is primarily about: âœ… Aligning pricing model with growth motion (sales-led vs. product-led) âœ… finding the right value metric (for value-based pricing) âœ… Getting clarity on packaging So you need to analyze: - Packaging & Value Metrics - POC, Free Trials or Freemium - Pricing terms (contract length, payment schedule, cancellation policy) I like to thing about pricing as something iterative. You have a pricing to get from: 1ï¸âƒ£ 0 to first 10 customers = pricing v1 2ï¸âƒ£ 10-100 customers = pricing v2 3ï¸âƒ£ 100 to X = pricing v3 Your pricing needs to match the stage of your company. So don't copy the 'perfect' pricing models from Notion, Miro, Asanas of the world. Not if you are early-stage. Instead, take it iteratively. Have a quarterly pricing meeting.

Many founders make a catastrophic mistake. âŒ They build first, then try to sell later. You won't believe me when I say this, but there is a right and a wrong way to acquire customers. The wrong way âŒ Build features âŒ Launch, hoping someone will buy âŒ Get feedback âŒ Start selling The approach that "If we build it, then they will come" is wrong. You need to be out in front of the customers, understanding what to build; otherwise, they won't come. The right way to acquire customers is âœ… Talk to potential customers âœ… Pre-sell / get strong commitments âœ… Build an MVP based on real demand âœ… Optimize with early adopters âœ… Grow Customer acquisition is scary, it requires hearing the truth from clients, telling you your baby is ugly. But the sooner that happens, the better. You'll be able to iterate, build features that clients will pay for. If you want to learn more about how to sell during the early days as a founder, Seth DeHart and I are launching a super detailed guide on this exact topic. Make sure you check it out at MRR Unlocked this Sunday. Link in the comments.

"Once you reach xâ‚¬ in revenue, you can hand off sales to professionals and focus on being a real CEO" Most founders don't know this, but one of the most important steps to succeed is NOT letting go of founder-led sales. Hear me out, I don't mean that you need to be your startup AE forever. But âœ… Founder-led sales isn't a phase you graduate fromâ€”it's your permanent responsibility. Your founder role will evolve. Here are 6 phases in which you'll evolve 1ï¸âƒ£ Finding Poblem-Solution Fit -> Here, you're personally validating that customers will pay for your solution. -> The focus is on having real conversations that lead to paying customers. 2ï¸âƒ£ Acquiring First Customers -> Focus on creating a repeatable process for finding and closing customers here. -> You're personally closing deals and beginning to recognize patterns in what works. You are acquiring customers for the purpose of learning, until the process becomes repeatable. â†’ This phase is not about scaling. It mostly is about doing non-scalable things to learn and get 1-2 channels performing. 3ï¸âƒ£ Making your first sales hire -> Don't think of this as your escape from sales. -> Here, you transition out of 'solo' selling to supplement and accelerate what's already working because you are at capacity. 4ï¸âƒ£ Making It Predictable -> Focus on creating a truly predictable process with clear KPIs and conversion metrics -> You can build sales methodologies and reverse engineer your sales forecast at this stage. 5ï¸âƒ£ Multiple Sales Hires -> Once your process is repeatable and predictable, bring on additional salespeople who can succeed within your established framework. 6ï¸âƒ£ Hiring a Sales Leader -> The right time to hire a sales leader is when a handful of people on the sales team are already executing. -> But you, the founder/CEO stay the CRO, no matter what, always managing that sales leader. ğŸ”‘ By following these phases in order, you become a competent sales leader yourself before hiring one. If you're a founder, recognize what phase you're in currently and plan for the next phase accordingly. If you want to know about each of these phases in detail, Seth DeHart and I are coming up with a Founder-led Sales guide this Sunday, Want it? --> Sign up on mrrunlocked .com and get it delivered to your inbox on Sunday or --> Comment 'Founder' and I will DM you the guide.

Positioning is a core aspect of your SaaS GTM Foundation. So letâ€™s start with what positioning is. So, in a nutshell, positioning means having clarity on: 1ï¸âƒ£ Who benefits from your product = Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) 2ï¸âƒ£ What your product does = Product Category and/or Primary Use Case 3ï¸âƒ£ Why itâ€™s better than the default option = Limitations of Status Quo + Your Key Benefits 4ï¸âƒ£ How itâ€™s different from other alternatives = Unique Differentiator / Positioning Angle ...and being able to clearly communicate this across your product, marketing, and sales touchpoints. To answer these core questions, you need to ask yourself: âœ… Who is your direct & indirect competition? âœ…What is your primary competitor (aka. status Quo)? âœ… What sets you apart from the status quo (aka. limitations and benefits)? âœ… How are you different from your direct competitors (aka. unique differentiator)? One of the best ways to answer â€œWhat is your product? For what do I use the product?â€ is to know your: âœ… Product Category and/or âœ… Usecase In a nutshell, do this: âœ… Product Category positioning: if youâ€™re building a product in an established market â†’ Good indicator: you will find a category on G2, Capterra, etc., and thereâ€™s existing search demand on Google & co. âœ… Usecase positioning: if youâ€™re building a product in a rather new market (blue ocean); no established product category has been built yet. â†’ Good indicator: No product category on G2, Capterra, etc. There is a great visual by FletchPMM for this. On Sunday I will guide you step-by-step on how to build your GTM foundation, including Positioning.

Sales enablement, the way we've done it in the past, doesn't work anymore. What's working instead? Buyer Enablement. Sales enablement is transitioning from âŒ Building content libraries and sales training to âœ… Helping your buyers make better, faster, and more confident decisions. So I've asked Marc Grewenig what's working in 2025. 7 ways to enable your buyers and win more deals along the way ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Create a Content Hub Make your content findable, not just available. -> Create a hub to locate the right content at the right time, in the right context. And no: It's not 73 folders in Sharepoint. 2ï¸âƒ£ Enable your buyerâ€™s champion, Your champions sell internally. Give them what they need to make the case when youâ€™re NOT in the room. 3ï¸âƒ£ Ditch the one-pagers. -> Build decision customer portals that give buyers a place to align, explore, and decide. -> Use tools like emlen to help you with this. 4ï¸âƒ£ Treat your buyers like customers (even before they pay) A great experience isnâ€™t just post-sale support. Itâ€™s clarity, trust, and ease, from the first interaction. 5ï¸âƒ£ Donâ€™t just track engagement. Act on it. Views are vanity. But seeing who engages with what â€“ and reacting fast â€“ wins deals. 6ï¸âƒ£ Respect their time. Simplify their path. Every unnecessary meeting, email, or file slows your buyers down. -> Reduce friction. Increase momentum. 7ï¸âƒ£ Be present, without being pushy. The best enablement feels invisible, helpful, personal, and available on demand. Treat Buyer Enablement as the new Sales Enablement. Your reps will thank you. Your buyers will too. ğŸ‘‡ How do you enable your buyers & sales team? P.S. Need hands-on support in building your buyer enablement, reach out to Marc Grewenig hashtag # buyerenablement hashtag # sales hashtag # paidpartnership

How Moritz Weiss turned Customer success from reactive support to proactive customer success and #1 source for referrals. âŒ Everyone makes the mistake of seeing CSM as a reactive function. âœ… But the real opportunity lies in turning it into a proactive referral engine. I've worked with Moritz and the whole Ayunis / Locaboo for 2+ years - building the GTM foundation and growing the company beyond â‚¬1 million ARR. And a big part of the success has been referrals. So I asked Moritz if he wants to share the secrets we implemented over the last months. (He has been handling more than 600 customers in the DACH region for Ayunis / Locaboo ) Here's the process to build a strong CS Referral engine ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ­: Customer check-ins -> Schedule regular check-in calls with your customers. -> We assigned a dedicated CS manager to each customer. -> Make it a point to actively ask questions about their experience during every contact you have with customers. -> This sets a good foundation to get in the referral mindset. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ®: Draft the perfect script -> Prepare a script that you can use to request referrals on these customer calls. ğŸš¨ Getting the right referrals depends a LOT on how you ask for them. So make sure you have the right script. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ¯: Set referrals as a KPI -> Set monthly referral targets for each Customer Success Manager. -> Actively report and track them within the team. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ°: Pool referrals in a single place -> Build a dedicated Slack channel in which all referrals are shared transparently and celebrated. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ±: Involve sales in the process -> Forward these referrals to sales as warm leads. -> Our SDR teams proactively reach out to warm recommendations. Bonus: Build awareness on how your customers refer other clients. In our case we know: -> They know other cities around them (so you can prepare for the calls and know who they might know) -> They work closely with other departments (so we know how to get warm intros to other departments) You're missing out if you are not actively engaging with your customers and building a referral engine around them. ğŸ‘‡ How do you use CS for referrals? P.S. In the screenshot, you see how sales and customer success all share and celebrate referrals in Slack. Congrats Florian Obermeier & Stefan Ockenfels --- If you want to know how to ask for referrals the right way, we have a dedicated guide over at MRRUnlocked.

I've added another criteria to my ICP. And it has nothing to do with firmographics. It's a matter of 'work ethic'. If someone don't show up to our intro call, it's a disqualifier. I spoke to 2 founders last 2 weeks that were making the same mistake that could break their SaaS. Both these founders had almost 0 touchpoints with their remote co-founders. Not even quick daily / weekly syncs. Only Slack messages, back and forth. Pre-covid, founders met frequently, sat in the same room, solved problems together. Now? Many teams are remote, but they forget to check in with each other. A Slack channel helps with fast updates, but it doesnâ€™t build trust or clarity. It wonâ€™t replace a real conversation about tough questions or next steps. Hereâ€™s what I see happening: â†’ Misalignment on priorities â†’ Hard topics getting lost in Slack threads. I get why remote-first is popular. I love the freedom, infact I work remotely too. But I never skip on weekly syncs. And I believe founders shouldn't too. Even a short weekly call makes a huge difference. How do you keep your team aligned during early days?

If I joined a startup as a late co-founder handling GTM, here are 12 things I would do in the first 3 months ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Check if we have a clear ICP and a set criteria to qualify / disqualify them. 2ï¸âƒ£ Check if we understand our positioning against direct / indirect competition and what sets us apart from status quo. 3ï¸âƒ£ Understand how we convey our value proposition and to whom. 4ï¸âƒ£ Check how our messaging is applied on homepage, sales deck, emails. 5ï¸âƒ£ Check our pricing - do we have the right packaging, value tiers, payment terms, policies. 6ï¸âƒ£ Understand our GTM motion (PLG, SLG, hybrid) and if it aligns with our ICP, pricing and product. 7ï¸âƒ£ Analyze our sales funnel and check for any issues that hold us back. 8ï¸âƒ£ See if we follow a sales methodology or identify what needs to happen to move deals through the pipeline. 9ï¸âƒ£ Check how we do our demo and discovery calls (hope for no feature f*****) ğŸ”Ÿ See how our GTM channels are performing / what can we do to get new leads. 1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Review if our GTM assets (e.g. case studies, product videos...) reflect our ICP, positioning and messaging correctly. 1ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£ Gather growth insights from sources like lost deal analysis, product usage, CRM audit, customer segmentation. GTM is the foundation of your SaaS. If you don't have it right, you're going to struggle in growing your SaaS. If you need help with your GTM, drop me a DM, I'd love to help you grow! Not a a co-founder, but as your GTM advisor ğŸ˜€

Start with initial customers (beachhead segment) and scale from there. âŒ ğ— ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µ ğŸ¯: Our product is all-in-one Itâ€™s tempting to build everything for everyone but it is better to figure what is most needed for your ICP and focus on that. âŒ ğ— ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µ ğŸ°: My prospects want to see all features, thatâ€™s why I demo all features -> Itâ€™s a demo. Not a product training. -> Focus only on top 3-4 features that matter to your prospect. âŒ ğ— ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µ ğŸ±: We do all channels at the same time - Outbound, Content, PPC, SEO, Events, Affiliates... -> Each channel works differently and takes up resources. -> Do smaller tests to figure which channels work and go all in on just those. âŒ ğ— ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µ ğŸ²: We donâ€™t have any competition -> Every company has competition. -> Look at your indirect competitors and status quo if you can't find direct competitors. âŒ ğ— ğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µ ğŸ³: We lose deals because we are too expensive -> Actually, most startups undercharge. -> It's not your pricing, it's how you package your product and value. When I work with SaaS founders, I see 3 common mistakes with their ideal customer profile. âŒ Being too broad & unspecific --> Our ICP are â€˜companies with 1-100â‚¬ million revenueâ€™ - so everyone Skip the FOMO. Start with early customers. In the early days, you usually donâ€™t have the resources to serve everyone. Start with initial customers (beachhead segment) and then scale from there. âŒ Your ICP changes over time --> You will have multiple different ICPs over time. The 'ideal' customers in the 0 to 100k â‚¬ is different than your 'ideal' customers from 1â‚¬ million to 5â‚¬ million etc. So create a mindset that your 'ideal customer' is ideal until you reach the next milestone. âŒ TAM vs. ICP And also remember, your TAM is not your ideal customer profile. Especially if youâ€™re VC-funded and talk a lot about the HUGE market, itâ€™s a common mistake. Your TAM is something you will (eventually) win in 5+ years, but not today. So live with the fact that your ICPs will change over time. Think about it this way: Your ICP today brings you to your next milestone. Once you hit the next milestone, you can revisit your ICP. ğŸ‘‡ How do you think about your ideal customers?

Why am I advising this founder against building an all-in-one tool. "Should I build everything for everyone from the start, or take it one use-case at a time and scale it at the next stage?" Founders face this dilemma in the early days. Investors specifically love an all-in-one vision for a product, and it is appealing too! They want to become this mega tool where their customers can - Have all their data, - Manage all workflows - Have multiple use-cases âŒ But it's not the best way to enter a market. Instead, âœ… Identify a subsegment of the market, that you want to cater to. âœ… Find 1-2 most appealing use-cases for them. âœ… Build just those use-cases to start with. This is the exact advice I gave to the founder I'm working with. If you're a founder facing a similar dilemma, focus on 1-2 key use-cases, you'll be far better off than going in all at once. Have you faced this in the past too? If so, what was your decision?

A lot of times, you read about the 0 to 1 stage. I rather believe the 0-1 stage consists of at least 3 (sub) stages. 1ï¸âƒ£ Stage 1: Hustle mode Your goal is to find the first 10 / 100 customers (depending on your ACV). You will run different tests. You want to validate your hypothesis, so you do any and everything to land that first set of customers. I call this GTM Experimentation. 2ï¸âƒ£ Stage 2: Focus mode The goal is to go beyond 10 / 100 customers. But you canâ€™t do this while serving multiple segments and multiple channels because each of them requires different strategies and resources to work. So, how do you do this? Analyze your early customers (Early Customer Profile) to find your best-fit customers (Ideal Customer Profile) and focus on them till you scale to â‚¬1 million ARR. I call this GTM Playbook V1. 3ï¸âƒ£ Stage 3: Expansion mode Here, your goal is to go beyond 1 million ARR. You can do this in three ways - ğŸ‘‰ Vertically - Same target audience (aka. ICP), but new use cases ğŸ‘‰ Horizontally - Same use case, but new target audiences ğŸ‘‰ Simply continue what you already do if there is a big enough market. Double-down/scale. To get there, you need to build your GTM foundations. The GTM foundation spread over: GTM Experimentation + GTM Playbook V1 --- P.S. After the 'focus mode' you achieved Product Market Fit. Thanks Anthony Pierri ğŸ¸ for the great definition of PMF. --- On Sunday we will cover how to build your GTM foundation in the mrrunlocked newsletter.

Your 'price tag' is NOT your pricing. I hate to break it to you, but it is only a tiny portion of your pricing strategy. If you feel like the "perfect" price for your SaaS is everything, When I have pricing discussions with founders, the most common thing I hear them worry about? The actual price. But along with the price, you also need to work on elements like 1ï¸âƒ£ Value metric --> per seat / per user.. 2ï¸âƒ£ Mechanism --> Is it usage based / feature gating, or a combination of both? 3ï¸âƒ£ Packaging --> Flat fee / tier based (how many tiers do you need if you choose this) 4ï¸âƒ£ Payment terms --> Quarterly / Monthly / Annually --> Kyle Poyar shared a post that the avg. discount for an annual is 22%. 5ï¸âƒ£ Contracts --> Monthly / Annual 6ï¸âƒ£ Discounts --> Should you have them on monthly vs annual payments --> When to give discounts (e.g. 5% for a case study) 7ï¸âƒ£ Cancellation policy --> When / How can you cancel and downgrade? 8ï¸âƒ£ Expansion policy --> How do you manage upselling? The actual price is only ONE part of the entire pricing strategy. Although it is important, it shouldn't be the only thing you are thinking about.

We all talk about positioning. But what is positioning really? My definition in a nutshell: Positioning means having clarity on: 1ï¸âƒ£ Who benefits from your product = Ideal Customer Profile (ICP) 2ï¸âƒ£ What your product does = Product Category and/or Primary Use Case 3ï¸âƒ£ Why itâ€™s better than the current/default option = Limitations of Status Quo + Your Key Benefits 4ï¸âƒ£ How itâ€™s different from other alternatives = Unique Differentiator / Positioning Angle ...and being able to clearly communicate this across your product, marketing, and sales touchpoints. But I'm sure the positioning experts Anthony Pierri ğŸ¸ and Robert Kaminski ğŸ¯ have an even better definition? ğŸ‘‡What's your definition of positioning?

Founders, you really don't need to worry about the 'Ultimate Pricing Strategy' from day 1. Comparing yourself to Notion and Miro , etc. will most likely backfire. They have been around for a while and use complex mechanisms like - Feature gating - 1-2 value metrics - Multiple tiered plans - Great expansion, upselling mechanism However, to get to this stage, you need a LOT of data and clients. Here's how you can approach it instead ğŸš¨Build V1, V2, V3.. of your pricing and iterate it quarterly / bi-annually. At a â‚¬0-100k stage âœ…Find the right value metric for your SaaS. âœ…Keep your pricing simple. At â‚¬100K+ stage, answer questions like --> Is your value metric right? --> Is your pricing right? --> Does usage-based or feature gating make sense for you? The key here? Iterate. Iterate. Iterate. Don't be fixated on the ultimate pricing plan from day one, trust me, you'll get there. For now, focus on keeping it simple and iterating based on feedback. You will have multiple 'perfect pricings' over time. The perfect pricing from 0-100kâ‚¬ is different than the perfect pricing from 100kâ‚¬ to 500kâ‚¬; and so on. How have you been pricing your SaaS?

Proper lost reasons are 1 of 3 easy fixes for your CRM. I get it. CRM is hard. Millions of things to optimize. But simplicity is king. Tracking your deal lost reasons is one of 3 things that can really make a big impact on your SaaS success. The other 2 are: - Self-reported attribution Asking prospects: How did you hear about us? - Mandatory deal fields To move the deals through your pipeline. But let's focus on lost deals. Learning WHY you lost a deal is pure gold. Because getting to know your customers, especially when they decide NOT to go ahead with you, is keyğŸ”‘ However, most founders donâ€™t track the reasons systematically in their CRM- To really get insights from your lost deals, âœ… Here are the 7 'lost reasons' I recommend tracking ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Decided for competition 2ï¸âƒ£ Status quo sufficient 3ï¸âƒ£ Decision delayed 4ï¸âƒ£ Too expensive / no budget 5ï¸âƒ£ missing key feature 6ï¸âƒ£ no response 7ï¸âƒ£ other âŒ Using open text boxes to track reasons is not ideal. âœ… Instead, use dropdown options. âœ… These 7 pre-defined lost reasons should cover 90% of your lost deals. âœ… In case you see an emerging reason in your 'other' bucket you could add them as a dropdown option (e.g. Compliance risk). âœ… Having pre-defined reasons makes analyzing lost reasons easier. âœ… Add an (optional) text field to add more context to the lost reasons. These insights will help you understand which GTM channels to optimize and what's stopping your ICP from buying. It will also help you close deals faster once you address the issues. Get started with this today by setting up your CRM and let me know how it works for you!

I've been talking about good vs bad sales decks in the past few posts.. In this post, I'm going to help you build one slide by slide (stay put it's a long one) Slide 1ï¸âƒ£: Cover Slide --> Add your company name, company logo, and your 1-sentence description. Slide 2ï¸âƒ£: Market Insight / Macro trend --> Set the context. Share insight about the market, what's changing and why it matters? Slide 3ï¸âƒ£: The problem --> What is the problem for them? Why it is a real pain? Slide 4ï¸âƒ£: Status Quo (Old way) --> Describe the (shitty) status quo of your ideal customers. Slide 5ï¸âƒ£: Solution (New way) --> Share high-Level Information about your Product Slide 6ï¸âƒ£: Solution --> Highlighting the top 3 Capabilities & Features Slide 7ï¸âƒ£: Product Demo --> Switch to presenting your product (the actual 'product demo') Slide 8ï¸âƒ£: Benefits --> Explain what's in for them! Focus on max. 3-4 benefits Slide 9ï¸âƒ£: Trust/Social Proof --> Add Social Proof elements. Case Studies, Testimonials, Reviews, Badges, Logos. Slide ğŸ”Ÿ: Pricing --> How do you charge clients? What pricing plan is for whom? Slide 1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£: Why now/Cost of inaction --> Emphasize why they need to act now. **Remember, not making a decision (staying with the status quo) is your number 1 lost reason. Slide 1ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£: FAQs/Objections --> Proactively share the most common objections and your answers to them (concern handling). Slide 1ï¸âƒ£3ï¸âƒ£: Next Steps / CTA - -> What do you want them to do next? Provide guidance. (Free trial, Book demo, etc.) WOW, if you've made it this far, you've successfully made a 10/10 sales deck. If not, I've still got you covered. I'm sharing a template to make this process easier for you. The link is in the comments.

The most challenging part of being a solopreneur? Accountability. I thoroughly love being a solopreneur. It gives me the flexibility to work on my terms. But the downside is I lack accountability. There is no "manager" to check in on me. Up until now, I had been setting OKRs to keep me on track. It's harder, though, to track them when no one's checking on your progress. So 4 weeks ago Maximilian Antosch and I started this thing called "accountability buddy" It's not a new concept. The idea is to have someone who holds you accountable to your goals and OKRs. We've decided on bi-weekly syncs but you can choose a frequency based on what works for you. I'm going to test this out and keep you updated with how it goes. How have you been holding yourself accountable as a solopreneur?

I was the first sales hire myself 10 years ago. So I deeply enjoyed writing a guide on hiring your first GTM person with SaaS recruiting experts Machiel Kunst and Elvin Kingma . We created a list of characteristics to look for ğŸ‘‡ Hiring the right first salesperson for your business can have a multiplier effect, while hiring the wrong first salesperson creates the opposite effect. Getting this first profile correct is fundamental. What NOT to look for in a pioneer or founding AE: Filter out candidates who âŒ Come from big companies â€”> They have a hard time to adapt to a fast-moving start-up culture âŒ Lack of product knowledge â€”> A lot of (senior) sales reps, if they start working in an early-stage start-up, don't really (invest enough time) to understand the product. âŒ Not willing to become an industry expert --> This point is closely related to point 2. If your sales rep is not willing to dive deep into the industry/ problem of customers, that's a bad sign. âŒ Not keen on building an industry network --> Word of mouth, warm intros, high-touch relationships with customers are key growth strategies in the early stage. Itâ€™s super important they want to grow their industry-relevant network âŒ Always sell with massive discounts --> Only being able to sell with massive discounts is a sign of lacking sales skills. âŒ Competition-focused --> The wrong sales reps spend too much time comparing with the competition and blame missing product features for unsuccessful sales performance. âŒ Lack accountability & blames others --> Wrong sales reps blame others (product, marketing...) and miss accountability for hitting their goals. âŒ Don't have a growth mindset --> Early-stage sales is a tough game. Mostly, you try to convince customers of an early (buggy) MVP. You need to be creative, smart, and always find new ways. Instead, do LOOK for people who: âœ… Have startup experience âœ… Can prospect from scratch (full-cycle) âœ… Have a strong track record âœ… are Challenger Sellers âœ… Have grit & adaptibility âœ… Have a willingness to build, test, execute Disclaimer: I did not check all boxes (haven't had a strong track record/sales experience), but I guess most of them at least ğŸ˜€ Did I? Hanno Lippitsch Stefan Feirer What's missing? Want to read the Guide on the 9 most common hiring mistakes? Check out the link in the comments. - P.S. This is me 10 years ago playing tennis at a racket center in Munich - one of the first clients I closed for eversports.

Hiring your first GTM team is one of the most crucial tasks as a founder. The transition from founder sales to founder-led sales is not easy. Avoid these 9 most common hiring mistakesğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Not implementing a sales methodology --> Your way of doing sales as a founder might seem structured to you, but itâ€™s hard to replicate. 2ï¸âƒ£ Not setting realistic goals --> Overambitious quotas have the opposite effect of a higher level of revenue. 3ï¸âƒ£ Hiring the wrong Pioneer AE --> People from "big companies" have most likely not been in the trenches often. 4ï¸âƒ£ Hiring a sales leader before hitting PMF --> Most havenâ€™t been hands-on for a while and shouldn't be your first GTM hire. 5ï¸âƒ£ Hiring strategic leaders too early --> Executor >>> someone who only strategizes 6ï¸âƒ£ Hiring "cheap" salespeople --> Don't try to save money by hiring less experienced people. You don't have the required resources to train them. 7ï¸âƒ£ Being slow in hiring process --> Speed matters. The best candidates get multiple offers within weeks. 8ï¸âƒ£ Founder stop selling too soon --> You still need to be involved in sales, even after your first hire. 9ï¸âƒ£ Neglecting cultural fit --> Don't hire purely based on experience. Cultural fit and passion matters too. Machiel Kunst , Elvin Kingma and I have worked on a detailed guide where we show you how to avoid and fix these. Check out MRR Unlocked to find these in our next episode. Link in the comments. ğŸ‘‡ What would you add to the list?

Your first sales hire can either be a multiplier or have the complete opposite effect. To help you filter the right candidates, Machiel Kunst , Elvin Kingma , and I have built a scorecard specifically for SaaS businesses. They have helped 350+ SaaS companies hire the right GTM talent so far. Here are their dos and don'ts. What NOT to look for in a pioneer or founding AEğŸ‘‡ Filter out candidates who âŒ Come from big companies âŒ Lack of product knowledge âŒ Not willing to become an industry expert âŒ Not keen on building an industry network âŒ Always sell with massive discounts âŒ Competition-focused âŒ Lack accountability & blames others âŒ Don't have a growth mindset Instead, do LOOK for people that: âœ… Have startup experience âœ… Can prospect from scratch (full-cycle) âœ… Have a strong track record âœ… are Challenger Sellers âœ… Have grit & adaptibility âœ… Have a willingness to build, test, execute List the candidates you are considering and check them off against these points. If you want to know more about common hiring mistakes and how to avoid them, don't miss the next MRR Unlocked newsletter. We are launching it this sunday!

How to monitor high-intent social mentions to grow your SaaS in 4 steps ğŸ‘‡ Thanks Charlotte Schmitt for sharing your best tips from working with 1000+ GTM leaders on social listening. But first of all: What is Social Listening? --> Social Listening is the process of monitoring online conversations (on LinkedIn, X , Reddit Slack etc. about your brand, product, and industry, Usually via tracking certain keywords And why is this relevant for early-stage SaaS? Social listening lets you: âœ… Discover early leads --> You can find people actively asking for the solution you offer or complaining about a competitor, and get on their radar organically. âœ… Get unfiltered feedback --> People are often brutally honest on social media and forums. This feedback is gold for refining your product and messaging. âœ… Build brand awareness --> By participating in conversations, you start to be seen as part of the community, not just an ad in the sidebar âœ… Inform product and marketing strategy --> Patterns in discussions can reveal what features users care about, what language they use, where they spend their time, and how they compare options, guiding your product roadmap and marketing strategy. âœ… Collect testimonials --> Organic mentions of your product are a great way to collect first testimonials Okay, so how to do this the right way? 4 steps to monitor (high-intent) mentions Step 1ï¸âƒ£: Identify key channels --> where your audience and industry peers are most active. LinkedIn, Slack, Youtube, X, you name it. Step 2ï¸âƒ£: Define the keywords --> you need to track your brand name, product categories, competitor names, industry terms and specific pain points. Step 3ï¸âƒ£: Monitoring your channels --> With a social listening tool like Octolens or manually to find relevant conversations based on the keywords. Alternatives to consider: Google alert, F5bot, Brand24 , Mention , Brandwatch, Hootsuite Step 4ï¸âƒ£: Take action --> respond quickly and relevant to mentions that matter (both positive and negative) or learn from it (e.g., add a new feature). Make sure to povide Value First instead of pitching immediately or just dropping the link to your product and Be Transparent About Who You Are --> If youâ€™re the founder, say soâ€”it builds credibility. Want to deep-dive into social listening. We just published an extensive guide on social listening for SaaS founders on mrrunlocked.com ğŸ‘‡ Share your social listening experiences

Last week, I did a quarterly review with a SaaS founder, and here's what we found ğŸ‘‡ Their biggest challenge was: âŒ MQL to Closed Won conversion. They did a great job of getting MQLs, but conversion was pretty low. To figure what was wrong, I reviewed their: âœ… Discovery and demo calls âœ… Emails sent to clients (after calls) âœ… CRM (notes & tasks) And we found that, 1ï¸âƒ£ They always left calls without communicating next steps 2ï¸âƒ£ Their email templates did not hit the mark 3ï¸âƒ£ No updates to CRM post calls The next quarter is going to be about fixing these issues and monitoring their impact on conversion. If you're struggling with something similar, The key is to take a closer look at the communication through the sales cycle. Chances are that's where the gap is. Have you faced this conversion issue before? How did you tackle it?

Sometimes, small things can have a big impact on founders. 8 'small things' I recommended to founders in Q1 ğŸ‘‡ Yes, I mostly work with founders on building their GTM foundation. But yes, small things can also have an impact. 1. Have a weekly founder sync meeting --> Great to align on top priorities of the week. 2. Review pricing quarterly --> Treat pricing as the pricing for 'now' that brings you to the next milestone. 3. Plan 'deep work' sessions --> Especially if you feel like you never have time to get things done 4. Collect testimonials in a folder --> Build an internal testimonial hub that you can use for marketing. 5. Leverage your network for warm intros --> Sounds easy, but most don't do this properly. 6. Record your sales calls --> Analyze regularly your calls and ask someone else to review it (I do this with every founder I work with) 7. Turn customer calls into content --> Take notes of calls. Every question and objection can be worth a post/content. 8. Analyze your top KPIs weekly & monthly --> Define the key steps (visits, leads, MQL, SQL, won/lost etc.) and analyze what's working and what's not (tracking alone is not enough). What would you add to the list?

Charlotte Schmitt has helped 1000+ founders and GTM leaders with social listening through octolens. She has seen it all, especially what NOT to do. 6 common social listening mistakes and how you can avoid them ğŸ‘‡ 1. Going straight for the sale âŒ Sounds super spammy and non-contextual. âœ… Help first, THEN promote your product. 2. Not Disclosing Founder/Employee Role âŒ Don't hide your role. âœ… State who you are and why youâ€™re recommending your own product. 3. Not Tracking the Right Keywords âŒ Don't miss out on high-intent threads. âœ… Monitor brand name, competitor name, pain point, and product category. 4. Using AI-Generated Answers without a personal touch âŒ Lacks your POV and sounds like a bot. âœ… Edit AI outputs to include personal expertise and your pov. 5. Focusing Solely on LinkedIn âŒ Don't overlook other platforms where your ICP is active. âœ… Use a cross-platform monitoring strategy. 6. Being Inconsistent âŒ Youâ€™ll miss time-sensitive opportunities. âœ… Have real-time tracking to stay on top of every relevant mention. 6 keywords you SHOULD be tracking if you are social listening ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Your brand name --> Social handles, --> Context if your brand is a common word --> Common misspellings 2ï¸âƒ£ Product category --> Think like a user who doesnâ€™t know your brand. --> For example, Tally might track â€œform builderâ€ or â€œonline form toolâ€ 3ï¸âƒ£ Competitor names --> Direct competitors, adjacent solutions. --> If people mention them, you want to know (if theyâ€™re unhappy or looking around) 4ï¸âƒ£ Pain point phrases --> Things your ICP say when experiencing the problem your SaaS solves. --> E.g., if you have a server monitoring SaaS, track phrases like â€œserver downtime alertâ€ or â€œmonitoring our serversâ€. 5ï¸âƒ£ Buying intent triggers --> Words like â€œrecommendation, alternative, vs, choosing, looking for, anyone use...â€ combined with category terms. --> E.g:, â€œrecommend CRMâ€ or â€œalternative to Salesforceâ€. 6ï¸âƒ£ Industry terms --> Words that are used a lot by your ICP. --> E.g: â€˜cart abandonment rateâ€™ (for e-commerce) Charlotte Schmitt and I are launching a detailed social listening guide on MRR Unlocked this Sunday. 4 ways to engage with high-intent social mentions without sounding spammyğŸ«  1ï¸âƒ£ Provide Value First --> Instead of pitching immediately, contribute to the conversation first. 2ï¸âƒ£ Be Transparent About Who You Are --> If youâ€™re the founder, say soâ€”it builds credibility. 3ï¸âƒ£ Follow Up when needed --> If someone shows interest, help them or address any problems / questions that come up. --> Offer an extended free trial, share use cases, invite them to a private chat or call. 4ï¸âƒ£ Know when to take It to DMs --> Some discussions are better when moved to private messages. Ask them to DM you in such cases. --> Always DM to ask for permission before resharing positive endorsements or complaints about competitors. Companies like Tally and Documenso, Inc. have achieved amazing results by nurturing social mentions. In fact, Tally co-founder Marie Martens said that social listening became one of the best marketing hacks she used.
