How do you separate a bad sales deck from a good one - one that actually converts potential customers? Your sales deck should not be - âŒ A list of all your features. Overloading with features dilutes the focus on solving the prospect's specific pain points. âŒ A presentation of your vision. Prospects care about immediate solutions, not your 5-year roadmap. âŒ A VC pitch deck. Sales decks should focus on the customer, not investors. âŒ A wall of text. Slides overloaded with information. One slide = 1 message. âŒ A technical manual. Avoid diving deep into technical details. Itâ€™s not your documentation or help center. What it should do instead - âœ… guide you/your salesperson during a sales meeting âœ… help you to share your POV and set the context âœ… make it easier to sell with a story âœ… help the prospects to follow you (during the demo) âœ… allow you to add social proof very naturally âœ… be a great material for prospects to use internally after the demo ğŸ”‘ Your sales deck is a key asset in your sales cycle. If you see yours having any âŒ elements mentioned above, make sure you revamp it before your next call! If you need help getting started, send me a DM P.S. You will find the link to the free sales deck template in the comments

Social listening can be an efficient growth tactics for early stage founders. How? ğŸ‘‡ First up, for those who don't know. Social listening is tracking keywords to monitor conversation about your brand / product online. You can track and engage with high-intent mentions (signals that someone needs a solution like yours) to âœ… Discover early leads --> You can find people actively asking for the solution you offer or complaining about a competitor, and get on their radar organically. âœ… Get unfiltered feedback --> People are often brutally honest on social media and forums. This feedback is gold for refining your product and messaging. âœ… Build brand awareness --> By participating in conversations, you start to be seen as part of the community, not just an ad in the sidebar âœ… Inform product and marketing strategy --> Patterns in discussions can reveal what features users care about, what language they use, where they spend their time, and how they compare options, guiding your product roadmap and marketing strategy. âœ… Collect testimonials --> Organic mentions of your product are a great way to collect first testimonials If you aren't doing this already, start with these 4 easy steps - 1ï¸âƒ£ Identify channels where your audience is most active (LI, X, Reddit, communities) 2ï¸âƒ£ Define keywords you need to track. This should include: - your brand name - your product categories - competitor names - pain point phrases - buying intent triggers (e.g. alternative, recommendation...) - industry terms 3ï¸âƒ£ Monitor your channels to find keyword - based conversations. 4ï¸âƒ£ Take action by responding and gathering insights from these mentions. Everyone talks about Clay , but running successful Allbound campaigns is more than that. 5 key components of Allbound pipeline generation ğŸ‘‡ What is Allbound pipeline generation?ğŸ‘‡ âœ… Allbound integrates inbound and outbound sales approaches into one system Instead of separate channels with different teams. âœ… It marries top-of-funnel marketing activities (1-to-many communication) with mid-funnel activities typically handled by SDRs (1-to-1 communication). The 5 allbound engine components - 1ï¸âƒ£ GTM Strategy & Sales Collateral - --> Allbound only works once you have your GTM fundamentals in place. â€”> Work on your ICP, Sales Story & Messaging, Sales Collaterals (Sales Deck, Case Studies), Homepage & Founder LinkedIn Brand 2ï¸âƒ£ Demand Generation --> Only 5% of your TAM is â€˜in the marketâ€™ currently. --> You want to stay top of mind of the 95% out-of-market buyers and leverage (intent) signals to know when they go from â€œout of marketâ€ to â€œin marketâ€. --> Include activities like LinkedIn content, LinkedIn Auto Connect, webinars, paid ads, influencer partnerships, and value-first outreach to generate signals. 3ï¸âƒ£ Intent Signals --> Find signals most relevant to YOUR GTM motion, product, and stage of the company. Signals can range from --> First party intent (direct interactions with your assets) --> Second party intent (interactions with partner network) --> Third-party intent (market-wide signals) 4ï¸âƒ£ Tools & Tech Stack --> The number of tools to capture signals is large. --> Understand the problem you want to solve and the specific use cases before investing in tools. But do check out: Trigify.io , Teamfluenceâ„¢ Syft Data , Snitcher 5ï¸âƒ£ Outreach --> Signals matter only if you use them to reach the right prospect at the right time. --> Align your signal-based outreach with your GTM motion. --> Use LinkedIn DMs, LinkedIn sequences, multi-channel motions, etc., based on what aligns with your GTM motion. ğŸ”¥ Want to learn step-by-step how to get started with 4 highly-relevant allbound playbooks? --> Website visitor playbook --> LinkedIn Engagement playbook --> Champion tracking playbook --> Key Buyer Persona Hiring playbook Florian Lussi and I launched the Allbound Guide on Sunday. If I were to launch a SaaS in a crowded space like webinar software, CRM, or project management, betting on high-intent keywords would be my #1 growth priority. Hereâ€™s why ğŸ‘‡ Let's take webinar software. You would compete against big players like livestorm, zoom or webex. It's about finding high-intent keywords for your product. These keywords focus on users already very much aware and â€˜in the marketâ€™. Together with Colin van den Berg we summarized 10 High-buying intent keyword categories for SaaS 1ï¸âƒ£ (Tool-Specific) Pain Point/Problem Keywords â€œHow to transcribe a webinar recordingâ€ 2ï¸âƒ£ Pricing & Cost-Related Keywords Example: â€œAffordable webinar software for startups" or "Free webinar tools" 3ï¸âƒ£ Comparison & Alternative Keywords Example: â€œZoom vs. Livestormâ€ 4ï¸âƒ£ Competitor-Specific Keywords Example: â€œZoom vs. Livestormâ€: Which is better for small businesses?â€ 5ï¸âƒ£ Feature-Specific Keywords Example: â€œWebinar with breakout room featureâ€ 6ï¸âƒ£ Integration Keywords Example: â€œBest Webinar tool to integrate with Hubspot / Webflowâ€ 7ï¸âƒ£ Product Category (+ Target Audience/Usecase) Keywords Example: â€œBest Webinar tool for product demosâ€ or â€œBest Webinar tool for startupsâ€ 8ï¸âƒ£ Benefit-Driven Keywords Example: â€œHow much time can we increase participant engagement with webinar software?â€ 9ï¸âƒ£ Educational Keywords Example: â€œHow to launch an on-demand product demo on my SaaS website?â€ ğŸ”Ÿ Template-Based Keywords Example: â€œWebinar sign-up page templates?â€ The good thing. I see many founders missing out on referrals. They don't have a system in place. It's a nice-to-have for them. You can practically use every touchpoint with a prospect/customer to get warm intros. Best part? You only need LinkedIn for this. Here are 3 LinkedIn playbooks to run your referral programs - 1ï¸âƒ£ Getting referrals/intros from your sales conversations --> Before you get on sales calls, use LinkedIn to scan their network for ICPs. --> During the call, ask them if they know someone who can benefit from your product. --> In case they donâ€™t know anyone, mention names from your list and ask for an intro. 2ï¸âƒ£ Getting referrals/intros from your network --> Tap into the network of your closed group (e.g. investors, employees, partners, friends) and scan their LinkedIn connections for ICPs. --> Shortlist people you want to get connected to, share the list with your closed group, and ask them for introductions. 3ï¸âƒ£ Getting referrals/intros from your existing customers - --> Same play as above. Search for relevant connections of your customers, shortlist relevant people, and ask for an intro. ğŸ’¡This also works the other way around. Meaning if there's someone youâ€™re NOT yet connected with, you can use Sales Navigator to get a list of people who could make an intro for you. While these are fairly easy steps to execute, The success of referral programs depends highly on *how* you ask for them. Arnaud Renoux and I have created templates to help you with - âœ… What to say, âœ… When to say it and âœ… How to say it. Head over to our latest episode of MRRUnlocked to check these out! A powerful case study follows a clear storyline. Today, Romana Kuts and I will publish the ultimate case study & testimonials guide for SaaS founders. The guide will contain: 1ï¸âƒ£ Different types of case studies (written, video, wall of love) 2ï¸âƒ£ (Video) Case Study Interview questions 3ï¸âƒ£ The perfect structure of a case study We believe a powerful structure of an ungated written case study includes: âœ… The Customerâ€™s Story â€“> who they are & what they do âœ… The Challenge â€“> what problem they faced before using your SaaS. âœ… The Solution â€“> how your product helped solve that problem. âœ… The Results â€“> quantifiable impact (metrics, revenue growth, time saved, etc.) âœ… Quote & Image â€“> a strong testimonial (quote + image) âœ… Call-to-Action â€“> Clear next steps for readers. A great case study follows a story. Your customer was in a shitty situation A â¬‡ï¸ They faced a lot of challenges. Painful. â¬‡ï¸ They tried a few things. But none of them worked. â¬‡ï¸ Then they introduced your solution. â¬‡ï¸ Pain was gone. They arrived at dream situation B. â¬‡ï¸ And saw awesome results. ğŸ‘‰ What great case studies and testimonials do you know?

4 ways to find testimonials and case studies ğŸ‘‡ Most SaaS founders think testimonials have to be formal quotes collected via surveys or emails. But in reality, testimonials are happening all around you. Hereâ€™s where to lookğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Organic Mentions People talk about products they love, even when youâ€™re not asking them to. Scan for mentions: - Social media (LinkedIn, X, Reddit, YouTube) - Community discussions (Slack, Discord, Product Hunt) - Emails, LinkedIn DM & Slack messages from happy users Tools like Octolens are helpful. 2ï¸âƒ£ User Reviews & Ratings If youâ€™re listed on G2, Capterra, Trustpilot, or AppSumo, start collecting positive reviews and featuring them on your site. Tools like reviewflowz are helpful. 3ï¸âƒ£ Live Chat & Support Messages Users often leave positive feedback in support chats. Keep track and ask for permission to use those as testimonials. 4ï¸âƒ£ Proactively collect testimonials Goal: Build a small portfolio of case studies that you can then strategically use for sales: âœ… a case study for each use case (in case your product covers more)* âœ… a case study for different industries/customer types* âœ… a case study for different benefits (example: One on x% time saving; the other one on y% increase in revenue)* How: Identify best-fit customers and proactively reach out to them. For PLG: Quick, casual email outreach. For SLG: Ask them for a 15-minute customer interview Romana Kuts and I share the email templates in our Case Study guide on mrrunlocked.com 5ï¸âƒ£ Bonus: Turn them into multiple case study formats A great case study doesnâ€™t have to be a 5-page PDF buried somewhere on your website. --> Written Case studies Make them easily (ungated) accessible on your website. Canva, Attio and Amplemarket have great case studies --> Wall of Love A "Wall of Love" is a dedicated page where all your best testimonials live, creating instant social proof. Tools like Testimonial are helpful --> Video Case Studies Video is more engaging than text. Either video-interview your customers (& record) or let them record a video (user-recorded). Calendy runs a great video case study page. Tools like Trust - #1 Video Testimonial Platform are powerful. On Sunday, we will publish our Ultimate SaaS Case Study & Testimonial Guide on mrrunlocked ğŸ‘‡ What works best for you? hashtag # saas hashtag # saasmarketing hashtag # gtm

You can (and should) use case studies: âœ… on your website âœ… in your sales deck âœ… on your blog articles & landing pages âœ… on social (e.g. LinkedIn posts) âœ… in your sales prospecting âœ… for fundraising But when Romana Kuts and I work with SaaS founders, we usually hear the same 3 challenges: âŒ How do we get that proof when youâ€™re just starting? âŒ What type of case studies & testimonials work the best? âŒ How do we write a good case study? 4 little power words for better B2B SaaS CopywritingğŸ‘‡ ğŸ‘‰ instead of Marketing is always about comparing your customer's WORLD TODAY with their FUTURE world. So using "instead" is a good idea. "Instead of entering data manually into Excel lists, use (productname) and all your data is automatically updated in real time." ğŸ‘‰ Without You can also use the word "without" to point out differences and to anticipate objections. â€... without having to manually enter everything in Excel lists" "Without the privacy concerns of other solutions" ğŸ‘‰ So (that) 'So' enables you to 'bridge' the gap from features & capabilities to the benefits of your software. "So that you save hours of work every week." "So that you reduce risks by 99%" ğŸ‘‰Because It's like children ... give them a good reason and the likelihood that they will brush their teeth or put on their pajamas increases ğŸ˜œ "Because your team has better things to do than maintain data manually" "Because relying only on X is very risky" Do you know any other power words?ğŸ‘‡ Credits to Thomas Kemp who talked about these 4 power words in german. Follow him for more copywriting tips.

If I were an early-stage SaaS founder building in B2B, here's how I'd get my first 50 customers (Sharing from my experience in working with 20+ SaaS startups) Tactic 1-3 is to start with your network, warm intros and referrals. Tactic 4-7 focus on high-intent prospects (aka. demand capture) Tactic 8-9 is a bit of demand generation. 1ï¸âƒ£ Network sales - Reach out to people in your network. 2ï¸âƒ£ Warm intros - Ask your investors, advisors, friends, etc. for intros. One of your best bets. - These convert MUCH faster than cold ones 3ï¸âƒ£ Referrals - Ask your first customers (and even prospects) for intros. This depends a LOT on HOW you ask them. - Make sure you make it easy for them to refer you. 4ï¸âƒ£ Founder-led LinkedIn - Post daily and ENGAGE with your audience to build awareness about your product. - Treat your profile as a landing page for potential customers. 5ï¸âƒ£ Social selling - Track intent and reach out to ICPs. - This includes profile views, likes, comments 6ï¸âƒ£ Creating 'BOFU' content - Create alternative & comparison pages (for existing product categories). - Works great in rather crowded red-ocean markets with existing demand. 7ï¸âƒ£ Paid Search - Bet on high-intent keywords on Google. 8ï¸âƒ£ Influencer partnerships - Engage with 3-5 relevant experts. - Give them access to your product and let them do their magic in promoting it. 9ï¸âƒ£ Niche newsletter sponsorships - Find newsletters that are read by your target audience. On Top tactics to keep in mind: --> Social Listening (writing a guide on it with Charlotte Schmitt ) --> 'Value first' outbound sequencing --> Track website visitors + outreach --> building on top of big saas player: check out their marketplaces Getting your first 50 customers is hard. Here are Colin van den Berg and my real thoughts about SEO. âŒ Not every SaaS product naturally lends itself to organic search. If your product solves a âœ… Clearly defined problem that âœ… potential customers actively Google, You can reap significant rewards by ranking in search results. Otherwise, OTHER channels will make more sense to you. Let's unpack 6 criteria that make you FIT for SEO - 1ï¸âƒ£ People are actively searching for keywords related to â€˜your solution' --> "SEO works best when people already search for solutions in your space" 2ï¸âƒ£ Your competitors are ranking and getting (high) traffic from SEO --> Their success proves thereâ€™s demand, and with the right strategy, you can compete for a share of that traffic. 3ï¸âƒ£ You rely on recurring revenue and a scalable growth model --> Companies with a solid lifetime value (LTV) can justify upfront SEO investments. 4ï¸âƒ£ Youâ€™re prepared to invest in content --> Organic growth is driven by high-value, solution-oriented content. --> Your team should be equipped for consistent high-quality content production 5ï¸âƒ£ You can tolerate a 6â€“12-month ramp-up --> SEO is cumulative - you wonâ€™t rank overnight. --> But in the long run it can deliver an ever-growing stream of qualified visitors 6ï¸âƒ£ You want to reduce paid acquisition costs --> Ads can work in the short run but get expensive as you scale. --> SEO is ideal for lowering your overall Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) in the long term. If this sounds like you - you should give SEO a shot. If you want to know how to get started, we've launched a super detailed SEO guide on mrrunlocked.com

We recommend finding high-intent keywords (aka. money-keywords) for your product. These money keywords focus on users that are already very much aware and â€˜in the marketâ€™. Hereâ€™s a list of 11 high-buying intent keyword categories. 1ï¸âƒ£ (Tool-Specific) Pain Point/Problem Keywords Why: High intent & low competition. Example: â€œHow to export contacts from LinkedInâ€ (for a lead scraping tool) or â€œHow to follow up with leads without being pushyâ€ (for a CRM software) 2ï¸âƒ£ Pricing & Cost-Related Keywords Why: Strong purchase intent. Users searching for pricing are near decision-making. Example: â€œAffordable CRM for solopreneursâ€ 3ï¸âƒ£ Comparison & Alternative Keywords Why: Steal market share from competitors. These users already know they need a solutionâ€”theyâ€™re just deciding which one to pick. Example: â€œNotion vs. Asanaâ€ | â€œBest alternatives for HubSpotâ€ 4ï¸âƒ£ Competitor-Specific Keywords Why: Convert users already aware of similar products. These searches indicate high purchase intent. Example: â€œHubSpot CRM vs. Salesforce: Which is better for small businesses?â€ 5ï¸âƒ£ Feature-Specific Keywords Why: Target users looking for specific capabilities. Users searching for specific features have clear buying intent and are comparing options. Example: â€œCRM with VOIP callingâ€ 6ï¸âƒ£ Integration Keywords Why: Users want tools that fit their existing tech stack. If your SaaS integrates well, itâ€™s a strong conversion driver. Example:â€œBest payroll software that integrates with QuickBooksâ€ 7ï¸âƒ£ Product Category (+ Target Audience) Keywords Why: Relevance & niche targeting (especially for vertical SaaS). Helps attract highly relevant traffic but may have lower search volume. Example: â€œAI tools for law firmsâ€ | â€œBest project management tool for remote teamsâ€ 8ï¸âƒ£ Benefit-Driven Keywords Why: ROI-focused searches. Users want to justify their investmentâ€”case studies & ROI calculators work well here. Example: â€œHow much time can I save with a virtual assistant?â€ 9ï¸âƒ£ Educational Keywords Why: Guide users through the buying process Example: â€œHow to create a high-converting SaaS homepageâ€ or â€œHow to get started with SEOâ€ ğŸ”Ÿ Location-Based Keywords (If Relevant) Why: Capture localized demand. High intent if applicable, but not relevant unless your SaaS serves specific regions. Example: â€œBest invoicing software for German freelancersâ€ 1ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£ Template-Based Keywords Why: Lead magnets & backlinks. Great for lead generation & content marketing but low direct buying intent (unless templates are built in your tool / specifically for your tool) Example: â€œBest LinkedIn post templates for SaaS foundersâ€ On Sunday, Colin van den Berg and I deep-dived into SEO for early-stage SaaS founders on mrrunlocked.com hashtag # saas hashtag # seo hashtag # founders

âŒ You could be losing $$$ to competition by not having a personal brand on LinkedIn. Why? Founder who miss out on this, are at a risk of losing customers to founders who *do* have a brand on LinkedIn! Follow these steps to build a brand for yourself and better reach your ICP - 1ï¸âƒ£ Define your ICP and their JTBD - --> This allows you to create relevant content and drive engagement. --> Prioritize ONE segment to start with. 2ï¸âƒ£ Nail down your positioning and messaging - Talk about YOUR differentiation - why users should choose you over competition. 3ï¸âƒ£ Develop your founder brand and story - --> Highlight your journey, challenges, and the transformations you achieved while building your product. --> Talk about WHY you do what you do! 4ï¸âƒ£ Add your Thought Leadership - --> Great thought leadership content educates the ICP, challenges assumptions, and provides actionable insights to solve problems. --> Aim to become the go-to resource for your ICP. 5ï¸âƒ£ Set your goals - --> Define Your 2-3 Main goals that you want to achieve from LinkedIn content & prioritize them. 6ï¸âƒ£ Track self-reported attribution - Include a self-attribution field in your book a demo/sign-up form to determine if a lead came from LinkedIn - this will help you track leads from LinkedIn content. 7ï¸âƒ£ Build your content pillars - --> Many founders struggle with the question: What should I post about? --> Define up to 5 content pillars connecting your Expertise & Product, Market Needs and Business Goals. ğŸ”‘ Founder brand has become a MUST for founders aiming to build a distribution moat. Your 1-sentence tagline is the shortest way to position your product. And it should include only 3ï¸âƒ£ parts ğŸ‘‡ I prefer 1-sentence positioning statements answering: 1ï¸âƒ£ What the product does --> Describe the use case (e.g. creating websites) or --> The product category (e.g. CMS) 2ï¸âƒ£ Who is it for --> Mention your ICP here --> This can be the persons and/or companies/industries With these 2 elements, people understand if the product is relevant to them. And then, only then, you can add your differentiation. 3ï¸âƒ£ Differentiation This can include things like: âœ… cheaper / liter âœ… made for a specific niche âœ… better service âœ… unique feature âœ… unique attribute --> e.g. GDPR compliant or 'AI-powered'. Here are 3 examples: 1ï¸âƒ£ Superhuman â€“ An ultra-fast email client for busy professionals who want to fly through their inboxâ€”powered by AI and keyboard shortcuts. 2ï¸âƒ£ Webflow â€“ A no-code website builder for designers and businesses who want full creative control over their websitesâ€”without relying on developers. 3ï¸âƒ£ Loom â€“ A video messaging tool for remote teams who need to communicate faster and more effectivelyâ€”without endless meetings Now I want to hear your 1-sentences. Everyone talks about finding your Ideal Customer (ICP), but almost no one tells you how to do it (until now!). How to analyze your early customers to find your ICP in 5 steps ğŸ‘‡ WHY Niching Down at all??? â€œtrying to sell to everyone who'll pay is the slowest path to 1â‚¬M, or at least the slowest to 10â‚¬M ARRâ€ Would you rather be: 1ï¸âƒ£A small fish fighting for survival in a big pond (aka. your TAM) or 2ï¸âƒ£a big fish in a small pond (aka. dominating a sub-segment of your SOM) The math is simple. Let's say you're targeting a 100Mâ‚¬ market. - If you capture 10% of a niche, that's 10Mâ‚¬. - If you try to capture 1% of a 1Bâ‚¬ market, that's also 10Mâ‚¬ But here's the kicker: capturing 10% of a focused market is WAY easier than capturing 1% of a broad market. Serving multiple different segments at the same time is time and resource-intensive. Each customer segment you serve requires its own: âŒ Value proposition & messaging âŒ Sales playbook âŒ Product features âŒ Support processes Additionally, every time you add a new segment, you build a new GTM motion. âŒ Different content âŒ Different channels âŒ Different sales approaches âŒ Different success metrics And guess what? Your small team can't execute multiple GTM motions effectively. To validate your ICP, you need to: 1ï¸âƒ£Collect data of your customers 2ï¸âƒ£Break down your customer base into segments and 3ï¸âƒ£Analyze them against metrics that are indicators of â€˜better fitâ€™ We call them â€˜â€˜better-fitâ€™ Indicators (aka. Winning indicators). Generally speaking, your â€˜best-fitâ€™ customers: ğŸ’ª have higher product engagement ğŸ’ª show better commercial metrics ğŸ’ª are less support intense ğŸ’ª are better aligned with your strategy and values/culture On Sunday we, Daniel Zsolt RÃ©nyi and I published a deep dive on the 5 Steps to Identify Your ICP on Mrrunlocked. hashtag # saas hashtag # gtm hashtag # idealcustomerprofile

Serving multiple different segments at the same time is time and resource-intensive. Each customer segment you serve requires its own: - Value proposition & messaging - Sales playbook - Product features - Support processes maybe even skills & talents, etc. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. Along with these, every time you add a new segment, you're essentially building a new GTM motion. Each motion requires: âŒ Different content âŒ Different channels âŒ Different sales approaches âŒ Different success metrics And guess what? Your small team can't execute multiple GTM motions effectively. You'll end up doing everything poorly instead of one thing exceptionally well. Here's what happens when you chase every potential customer: âŒ Marketing messages become generic and forgettable âŒ Sales cycles get longer and more unpredictable âŒ Product development gets pulled in multiple directions âŒ Customer success becomes a constant firefight âŒ Churn increases as you fail to deliver specific value Neither fun, nor desirable. The path to 1â‚¬ and then to 10â‚¬M ARR isn't about maximizing your total addressable market. It's about dominating a specific segment. When you focus on one specific segment: âœ… Your marketing message becomes crystal clear âœ… Your sales team becomes highly efficient âœ… Your product roadmap gets laser-focused âœ… Your customer success becomes predictable âœ… Your referrals start flowing naturally Most importantly, you build deep expertise in solving specific problems for specific customers. This expertise compounds over time, creating a moat that competitors can't easily cross. Which will ultimately bring you to the point of predictable & repeatable growth. --- On Sunday Daniel Zsolt RÃ©nyi and I launched the Guide on How to analyze your early customers to identify your ICP. So join 4700 SaaS leaders on mrrunlocked.com

Mapping your ICP can be one of the most daunting tasks for an early-stage founderğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸ Don't you agree? But it's also something you can't skip! Because ICP mapping is one of the foundations of scaling your SaaS from 0-1mil ARR and beyond So how can you streamline this process to make it easier? The key lies in segmentationğŸ”‘ It's a 2-part process where you - 1ï¸âƒ£ Set your "Obvious Filters" Segment your customers in CORE groups, based on criteria that you deem are most important for YOUR business. These include (but are not restricted to) - âœ… Industry âœ… Tech Stack âœ… Company Size âœ… Geography 2ï¸âƒ£ Enhance these with "Advanced Filters" Surface-level segments often reveal initial patterns - but rarely the full picture. To make your segmentation foolproof - Layer on advanced filters that correlate with VALUE. These include - âœ… Vertical Specific (metrics specific to your vertical) âœ… User Persona (who uses your product) âœ… Use-Case (how they use it) âœ… Customer pain point (their main challenges) You're already half way into mapping your ICP if you are able to segment your customers in these groups. âŒ Founders - Don't confuse EARLY customers with IDEAL customers. You know the "Hustle Mode" very well, especially in the early days of building your SaaS. You're scrappy, and doing everything possible to land your first 10/100 customers. However, these first customers are your ECPs (Early Customer Profile). They tend to be: âœ…solution-aware, âœ…experimental, âœ…and in the market. They are most likely DIFFERENT from your ICPs (your ultimate goal). Your ICPs tend to be: âŒnot yet solution aware, âŒrequire proof of work and âŒare hard(er) to reach. At some point, you need to pause Hustle Mode. You need to start tapping into your ICP and that road is THROUGH your ECP. How can you achieve this? It's a 3-step process 1ï¸âƒ£ Collect data about your customers Example - Firmographic, technographic, product usage 2ï¸âƒ£ Segment your early customers based on various criteria relevant to your business Example - Industry, size, customer pain points, use-cases, tech stack, etc. 3ï¸âƒ£ Map these segments against key "winning indicators" of your best-fit customers Example - higher NPS, shorter sales cycle, higher ACV, higher product engagement, etc. Remember, the goal of this exercise is to go from Hustle Mode (ECP) to Focus mode (ICP) so you can scale to 1M / 10M ARR faster. Sounds like a huge task? Don't worry, on our upcoming MRRUnlocked, episodes, we, Daniel Zsolt RÃ©nyi and I walk you through the step-by-step process to achieve this. --- Link to the newsletter in the comments. By simply asking 'How did you hear about us?' you can (almost) fix the dark social problem. Dark social refers to social media activities that cannot be attributed to a specific channel And are not trackable by conventional analytics tools. It includes private communication channels such as Messaging apps, emails, or direct messages, where content is shared without a traceable source. To track leads and generated pipeline, we recommend that every company include a self-attribution field in their book a demo/sign-up form to determine where the lead is coming from. By simply asking 'How did you hear about us?' But now I want to hear your opinion. ğŸ‘‰ Dropdown vs. Open text field? What's the best way to track self-reported attribution? Here are my 2 cents: ğŸ”¸ If you are early, start with an open text field (gives you more in-depth insights) ğŸ”¸ if you are sales-led, go with an open text field (and have a second dropdown option in your CRM where you categorize the answers from the open text field) ğŸ”¸ for PLG/self-service: better dropdown option to make it easier to analyze What are your opinions? Ivan Peric Finn Thormeier Manuel Hartmann P.S. The image is the self-reported attribution in breakcold's onboarding flow Arnaud Belinga ğŸ§ŠğŸ”¨

65% of startups in the YC combinator batch have 'ai-powered' in their tagline. I don't think this is smart â›” Don't get me wrong. I think that AI can be a great differentiation for a company. Especially if you are building a 'second generation' of an established product category. Then AI can be your 'USP'. But is it the best way to describe your startup in 1 sentence? I don't think so. Your 1-sentence tagline is the shortest way to position your product. I prefer 1-sentence positioning statements answering: 1ï¸âƒ£ What the product does --> Describe the usecase (e.g. creating websites) or --> The product category (e.g. CMS) 2ï¸âƒ£ Who is it for --> This can be the persons and/or companies/industries With one sentence people understand if the product is relevant for them. And then, only then, you can add your differentiation. 3ï¸âƒ£ Differentiation This can include things like: âœ… cheaper / liter âœ… made for a specific niche âœ… better service âœ… unique feature âœ… unique attribute (e.g. GDPR compliant) or 'AI-powered'. If this is your differentiation, then go for it. What's your opinion? AI-powered positioning?

When it comes to positioning, you have 2 options ğŸ‘‡ Usecase vs. Product Category Positioning. Why should customers choose you over competitors? The answer is your POSITIONING. I recommend following 4 steps. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ­: ğ—¨ğ—»ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ˜„ğ—®ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ğ˜€ (ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ˜€ ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—¼) This can be Excel, intern, patching together tools, legacy software etc... ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ®: ğ—¨ğ—»ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—¼ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ You list the competitive alternatives with their pros and limitations. P.S. This is not only direct competition, most of the times it's indirect competition too. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ¯: ğ—–ğ—µğ—¼ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ—² ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—² ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² Decide on your 'playground'. You as a founder need to make a crucial decision in terms of positioning. In a nutshell, do this: âœ… Product Category positioning: if youâ€™re building a product in an established market â†’ Good indicator: you will find a category on G2, Capterra, etc. and thereâ€™s existing search demand on Google & co. âœ… Usecase positioning: youâ€™re building a product in a rather new market (blue ocean); no established product category has been built yet. â†’ Good indicator: No product category on G2, Capterra, etc. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ°: ğ—”ğ—±ğ—± ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—² ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» (ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ—¹ğ—²) Now you need to add 1 or more of the 6 SaaS positioning options. 1ï¸âƒ£ Niche down Finding an (underserved) segment of the market and building the best tool for them. Most of the time it's vertical-specific tools. 2ï¸âƒ£ Low-cost player Mostly in a more crowded market when market leaders increase their prices (a lot), you have the chance to build a low-cost version of it. 3ï¸âƒ£ Premium-player Serve clients that need more human touch (customer service, sales demos...). You can position yourself as the premium player. 4ï¸âƒ£ Unique benefit You have something very unique that no one else has. This can be a specific feature or the fact that you serve a specific market better (e.g. being GDPR compliant, if you sell to DACH market) Some other examples are: ğŸ”¸ Proprietary Technology (e.g. AI-driven) ğŸ”¸ Special expertise (e.g. founded by ex-XX) ğŸ”¸ Better support (e.g. dedicated account manager 24/7) ğŸ”¸ Speed of delivery(e.g. Quick onboarding with pre-built project templates) 5ï¸âƒ£ Being the 'lite' version of something complex You serve a customer segment that doesn't need the heavy, complex market leader (e.g. Salesforce or Adobe). 6ï¸âƒ£ Mix of the above Of course, each of the elements can be mixed. --- Thanks Robert Kaminski ğŸ¯ & Anthony Pierri ğŸ¸ for this great visual (as always!) ğŸ™Œ

Your sales deck is not: âŒ A list of all your features. Overloading with features dilutes the focus on solving the prospect's specific pain points. âŒ A presentation of your vision. Prospects care about immediate solutions, not your 5-year roadmap. âŒ A VC pitch deck. Sales decks should focus on the customer, not investors. âŒ A wall of text. Slides overloaded with information. One slide = 1 message. âŒ A technical manual. Avoid diving deep into technical details. Itâ€™s not your documentation or help center. Instead, your sales deck is a structured way to share your POV. Itâ€™s guiding your potential clients from the shitty status quo to the desired outcome. In a nutshell, itâ€™s about telling a story of: âœ… how they currently do â€˜usecaseâ€™ âœ… what the problem and limitations of this are (why it matters) âœ… how they overcome the current situation using your product âœ… what they will achieve (results) âœ… that they can trust you and that they are not alone (social proof) A great sales deck: âœ… guide you/your salesperson during a sales meeting âœ… helps you to share your POV and set the context âœ… makes it easier to sell with a story âœ… helps the prospects to follow you (during the demo) âœ… allows you to add social proof very naturally âœ… is a great material for prospects to use internally after the demo Want the sales deck template? Send me a DM or get it for free on mrrunlocked.com

Your website needs to answer 6 key questions of your visitors: 1ï¸âƒ£ What is the product/service they offer? 2ï¸âƒ£ What problem does it solve for me? 3ï¸âƒ£ What can I do with the product? 4ï¸âƒ£ Who is it for? Is this product for me? 5ï¸âƒ£ What are the main benefits for me? 6ï¸âƒ£ Can I trust the company? To get this right, you need to have: ğŸ‘‰ Solid understanding of your ideal customers ğŸ‘‰ Clear messaging framework You can use our free Figma Template to get started.

Donâ€™t forget to also add value for the prospect in your discovery call ğŸš¨ Too often I see SaaS founders and sellers purely focusing on asking all their questions. But by doing so, they forget to add value for the prospect. You donâ€™t want your discovery call to be a call where you only ask questions so that your prospect feels like being in an interrogation. At the end of the discovery, both parties need to mutually agree that it makes sense to move on. So itâ€™s not enough that you only â€˜qualifyâ€™, you need to give a bit of value already. This can come in different ways, e.g. âœ… Highlighting your value proposition (1-sentence value prop) âœ… Sneak preview of your product (5 minutes highlighting main capabilities) âœ… Giving your expert opinion (about their current situation) and sharing how other customers of yours overcome the challenge (sharing case study) âœ… Sharing (some parts) of your sales deck Want to know what questions to ask in your discovery? Check out my 24 example questions.

Founder: "How do I know if I found our ICP?" Sometimes itâ€™s not easy to know if you already â€˜foundâ€™ your ICP. But here are 11 good indicators ğŸ‘‡ Good indicators for having a powerful ICP and knowing how to communicate with them (message-market fit) and how to keep/make them happy (product-market fit) are: 1ï¸âƒ£ Increase in conversion rates ğŸ”¸ ad conversion rates ğŸ”¸ cold email response rates ğŸ”¸ website (to demo/signup) conversion ğŸ”¸ activation rates ğŸ”¸ deal win rates & free trial to paid ğŸ”¸ retention rates 2ï¸âƒ£ Great customer feedback ğŸ”¸during the sales calls & demos ğŸ”¸NPS ğŸ”¸customer support interactions ğŸ”¸shorter sales cycle (they push actively) 3ï¸âƒ£ (First signs) of referrals and virality ğŸ”¸share and invite others (from the same ICP) ğŸ”¸talks about you in niche communities Once you 'found' your ICP you will go from unpredictable inconsistent growth to a repeatable way.

The ANTI Ideal Customer Profile It's helpful to have a profile of companies & personas you DO NOT WANT as your customers. Someone you should not serve - your ANTI-ICP. These are personas & companies that are NOT a good customer fit for you because: âŒ don't value your product âŒ don't have a pain or need that you solve for them âŒ don't fit strategically into your business To find them, ask yourself what type of persona/companies: âŒ have long sales cycle and low win rates? âŒ have low contract values? âŒ high churn rates? âŒ high support volume? âŒ low engagement and satisfaction? So building your Anti ICP is learning who your best customers are not. Your Anti-ICP is very helpful when it comes to qualifying your prospects, either in your sales discovery or in your product onboarding - but also obviously when it comes to building campaigns. My Anti ICP is: âŒ non-SaaS business model âŒ revenue above 1â‚¬million ARR âŒ based outside Europe âŒ selling to enterprise clients âŒ with ACVs over 30kâ‚¬ âŒ idea-stage founders âŒ think GTM = sales âŒ look for fast 'hacks' Who's your ANTI ICP?

I'm talking every week with SaaS founders about how to track closed lost reasons. Here are the 7 reasons I recommend tracking ğŸ‘‡ Using open text boxes to track reasons is not ideal. Instead, use dropdown options. Here are the reasons I would go for: 1ï¸âƒ£ Decided for competition 2ï¸âƒ£ Status quo sufficient 3ï¸âƒ£ Decision delayed 4ï¸âƒ£ Too expensive / no budget 5ï¸âƒ£ missing key feature 6ï¸âƒ£ no response 7ï¸âƒ£ other These 7 buckets should cover 90% of your lost reasons. In case you see an emerging reason in your 'other' bucket you could add them as a dropdown option (e.g. Compliance risk). Having these pre-defined reasons make it easy for you to analyze your lost reasons. Add an (optional) text field to add more context to the lost reasons. ğŸ‘‡ What reasons are missing?

But hard at the same time. 4 weeks I was offline. âŒ No meetings âŒ No deep work âŒ No Slack âŒ (almost) no LinkedIn Instead, I enjoyed life with my wife ğŸ˜ Sun and sea in Thailand ğŸ§˜â€â™‚ï¸ Yoga, Pilates & Gym â˜• Yummy food & coffee ğŸ“— Books & Reflection But doing 'nothing' is hard. What channels are right for my SaaS? The right GTM channel(s) for your SaaS depends on view criteria. âœ… Your ACV (annual contract value) â€”> Some channels are just more expensive than others. Your pricing needs to justify the cost of the acquisitions. âœ… Stage of the company â€”> Focus on direct channels first. The feedback and learnings you get interacting with your clients are super valuable. Content, Outbound, and Paid search gives you immediate feedback. Also, some channels are very expensive (e.g. out of home) or take a long time to establish (e.g. strategic partnerships), and because of that are not available for most early-stage startups. âœ… Product Complexity â€”> If your product is rather complex, buyers prefer more education and human interaction (aka. sales-led). This comes with higher ACVs and impacts your choice of the right GTM channels. If your product is low in complexity, the opposite is true, which means SEO, affiliates, marketplaces, etc. can work quite well. âœ… Maturity of the market â€”> If you are building a product in an established market, you can bet on existing demand. This means people are actively looking for solutions, so review platforms, paid search, and affiliates are channels with a good fit. In comparison, if most of your buyers are not aware, you need to educate the market. This means you need to bet on channels that enable you to do so (e.g. outbound, owned content, events, etc.) âœ… Team/Founder Skills â€”> Some call it founder-model fit. Trust on (early) GTM channels that you can master well. ğŸ‘‡ What channel work best for you?

Most founders stop content marketing with content creation. But content distribution is at least as important as creation. They publish content on their blog post or post organic content on LinkedIn and hope for the best. But itâ€™s best if you think about how you can best distribute your content so that a lot of your ICP audience gets in touch with it. Here are some methods to keep in mind: âœ… Share your content on relevant communities But please stop just posting the link. Instead, provide value by answering related questions and link to your content as a full-length article on that topic) âœ… Have a small group of ambassadors These are people who engage with your posts on LinkedIn. They should be relevant to your audience. Ask them to interact with your content. âœ… Share content in your outreach Can you add your content to your latest prospecting campaign? If your content is valuable, then you should like the idea :) âœ… Cross Promo of Content Reach out to relevant industry experts, clients, influencers, newsletters, blogs, etc., and ask them to share your content. If itâ€™s relevant there is a high chance they are happy to help. âœ… Promote via paid channels If you see that your content performs well, you could even think about adding paid channels on top. âœ… Equip your employees with content More and more SaaS startups equip their employees with content so they can all build their online brands. We all agree that prospecting to referred leads (aka. warm leads) is easier and more effective than cold prospecting. â€˜Warmâ€™ leads have a higher trust in you and therefore show higher win rates. A great opportunity to get these â€˜warm introsâ€™ are ALL your interactions with your existing customers AND also prospects - Itâ€™s called Referral sales. The goal of referral sales is: âœ… getting your existing customers (and prospects) to give you contact information (ideally including introductions) of other relevant leads in their network, plus âœ… using their names when contacting new leads. If you are successful in getting referrals and intros depends a lot on HOW you ask them. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve created some blurbs that you can use straight away. Here is 1 sales blurb that you can use at the end of your demo, if the prospect was NOT interested / not a good fit. â€œOkay, thanks for the demo. I see that (your company name) is probably not a good fit for you. But now that you know who we work with (your ICP) and what our product can do for them, who are 2-3 other companies/people you think can benefit from it?â€ ...and then if they tell you some names, respond the following: â€œThanks. Would you mind making an email intro for me? If you want, I can also send you an intro template to make it easier for youâ€. Want more blurbs like this? Check our my newsletter where I shared 3 ready to use blurbs to get referrals. Link is in the comments.

The 1 advice I would give to SaaS founders on their way to 1â‚¬ million ARR if I could only share 1. it would be "1ï¸âƒ£" Here's what I mean by this. Focus on 1ï¸âƒ£ thing. 1ï¸âƒ£ is most of the time better than 2 or 3. Let me explain. âœ… 1 target audience --> easier to sell to than 2 or 3 in parallel âœ… 1 usecase --> easier to build a great product for --> easier to communicate âœ… 1 value metric --> keep your pricing simple --> find 1 metric that scales with usage âœ… 1 channel --> master 1 channel at a time. âœ… 1 GTM motion --> No PLG and SLG at the same time ğŸ‘‡ What else would you add?

Last week I had a power hour call about SaaS pricing with an early-stage SaaS founder. Here are 3 things we covered in 60 minutes ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Pricing value metric Most important thing in pricing is deciding on your value metric. What is *the thing' that you charge for. Traditionally these are metrics like: - users - storage - transactions - leads - bookings ... Choosing your value metric is key. A powerful value metric combines the following 3 characteristics: âœ… Easy to understand âœ… aligned with the customersâ€™ value of using your product âœ… Scalable and grows with customersâ€™ usage of your product To keep it simple choose 1 value metric. And not 2 or 3. 2ï¸âƒ£ Packaging If you follow a value-based pricing with 1 value metric, you need to decide if you charge: - for every single unit of the value metric (aka. usage based pricing) or pre-package them (aka. tiered pricing). Example: Charge 5â‚¬ per unit vs. 100â‚¬ for up to 20 units. 3ï¸âƒ£ Price point Patrick Campell said â€œIn the beginning, the actual number you're charging isn't that important. There are some exceptions, but for the most part, you should first be figuring out the range you're in: a $10 product, $100 product, $1k product, etc. Don't waste time debating $500 vs. $505, because this doesn't matter as much until you have a stronger foundation beneath you.â€ We did the following 2 things: âœ… Competitor benchmark --> They operated in a crowded mature market. So checking direct competitors for reference was a good indicator. âœ… Calculation for value (10x rule) --> We did a calculation on the value the product provides. The 10x rule said that you should charge 10% of the value. While we fully focused on pricing, the founders realized that pricing is part of the overall GTM strategy. Because we always talked about: ğŸ‘‰ Who are you selling to ğŸ‘‰ What are the alternatives & direct competitors ğŸ‘‰ How are you different from them ğŸ‘‰ How do you sell (PLG vs. Sales led) If you want to learn more about pricing, check out my full SaaS pricing guide for early stage SaaS products.

Positioning means knowing what other options your client has. It's about knowing 3 things ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Building the clusters --> What options do your clients have to do the job/usecase. Usually, you have 2-3 different competitor buckets. --> direct competitors --> Manual process/patchwork of tools --> legacy tools 2ï¸âƒ£ Know their pros & limitations --> acknowledge what they can do well so you can honestly recommend best solutions to your prospects. But of course, know their limitations. Things that matter to your ICP 3ï¸âƒ£ Know how you fix the limitations --> Communicate why you are different and how you fix the limitations. The competitive alternative clusters is part of my SaaS messaging framework. You will find it on my newsletter.

Messaging is about 2 steps. 1ï¸âƒ£ Why they need a specific product --> introducing the product category 2ï¸âƒ£ Why they need your product --> Explain why your product is the best in the competitive landscape of this product category. Today I had a GTM advisory session with a SaaS founder who has 146 clients but struggles with their ICP. They could not clearly articulate who their ICP is. Why? Because they have 146 clients, but never really started to analyze them. So here is what we did. Enrich their client list with relevant data. In this case it meant: 1ï¸âƒ£ contract value 2ï¸âƒ£ payment schedule (monthly, yearly) 3ï¸âƒ£ title of decision maker 4ï¸âƒ£ amount of user 5ï¸âƒ£ sales cycle (in days) 6ï¸âƒ£ product usage 7ï¸âƒ£ source 8ï¸âƒ£ industry 9ï¸âƒ£ size of company ğŸ”Ÿ what they used before The goal? To find segments that show good indicators to be our ideal customer segment. And then double down on these. And try to find more of them. After the strategy session, they found 2 segments that performed better than others. Now they will run tests to see if these 2 segments will show better results in their marketing & sales activities. ğŸ‘‰ How do you analyze your clients?
"We are an all-in-one tool for prosumers, SMBs, and enterprises worldwide"

How to find your best-fit customers ğŸ‘‡ 10 criteria to spot them ğŸ¯ Well, it all starts with analyzing... Create a list of your customers (& churned customers). And add the following criteria: 1ï¸âƒ£ Company Size --> If you serve different segments --> Analyze what type of companies you serve 2ï¸âƒ£ Industry / Region --> What industry and region --> See differences in how happy they are? 3ï¸âƒ£ Buyer persona(s) --> Who bought your tool? 4ï¸âƒ£ Users / Champion --> Who is using the product (roles) --> Who was your main contact person? 5ï¸âƒ£ Tech tools used --> If you serve clients from different segments (e.g. Shopify vs. Shopware) but also: 6ï¸âƒ£ ACV --> How much they pay you? --> maybe even LTV 7ï¸âƒ£ Sales Cycle & win rates --> See a difference in length? --> See a difference in win rates for specific types of clients? 8ï¸âƒ£ Product usage --> How they use the product --> How active they use it 9ï¸âƒ£ Usecases --> The main 'job' they perform with your SaaS ğŸ”Ÿ Churn reason --> Why they stopped using Bonus: --> NPS scores --> Support ticket volume --> Lead source / how they found you to learn what channel works best This is a non-exclusive list. But you get the point. Your best-fit customers have: âœ… high product usage âœ… lower churn âœ… faster sales cycle & higher win rates âœ… higher ACVs Find patterns of your most successful clients. Double down on them.

9 actionable social selling tactics for 2025 1ï¸âƒ£ Value-comments on relevant creator's posts --> make a shortlist of 5-15 relevant experts Be one of the first who value comment on their posts. You can add a link to a resource (of yours) that add value. You can combine this tactic with 4ï¸âƒ£. 2ï¸âƒ£ Auto-connect campaigns with ICPs --> Set up a LinkedIn connect campaign. Check tools like lemlist or lagrowthmachine. Import ICPs from Sales navigator to the sequence. It can be a 1-step campaign (only connecting). Or you combine it with tactic 5ï¸âƒ£ 3ï¸âƒ£ Revenue-focused posts --> If you want to create pipeline via LinkedIn, focus on content that is highly relevant for (high-intent) ICPs. So start with BOFU content. Talk about pain points, usecases, specific product features, capabilities. Share case studies. I have a full list of content topics you can start with (DM if you want the list) 4ï¸âƒ£ Engage/reach-out to ICP commenters/likers --> Your content gets traction. Awesome. But don't stop here. Respond to every single comment. Reach out/ connect with people from your ICP. 5ï¸âƒ£Value-first outreach campaigns --> Connect and DM people from your ICP. You share with them content that (with a high chance) might be relevant for them. No pitch. Just sharing value. If your product/service is relevant for them, they will let you know. 6ï¸âƒ£ 'Comment-below' lead magnets --> You share highly relevant content on LinkedIn. In order to get the asset, they need to comment & like your post. You get huge organic reach + long list of (ICP) people. They get highly valuable content for free. Then you send a DM (or sequence) with the asset to all commenters. 7ï¸âƒ£ Turn your profile into your homepage --> A lot of founders have more profile impressions than website traffic. So include the key aspects of a powerful homepage on your profile. I have a full guide on the perfect SaaS homepage. (DM if you want it) 8ï¸âƒ£ CTAs in your featured section --> Make it easy for people to move forward. This can be a free trial, book a demo or download your lead magnet. 9ï¸âƒ£ Group of early-supporters --> Have a small group of people who engage with your posts. Ideally, they belong to your ICP. This way LinkedIn will promote your post organically to more people from your ICP. Encourage them to value-comment, not just liking. ğŸ‘‡ What social selling tactic is missing? --- To learn more tactics like this, check out my free GTM newsletter for SaaS founders on their way to 1â‚¬ million ARR.

I hate competitor lists. Better: Build clusters of competitors Let me explain ğŸ‘‡ Most companies have an internal looong list of competitors. But this list is barely used. Because itâ€™s unstructured. So if sales and marketing talks with prospects about the competitive landscape they share a bunch of other direct competitors. Maybe adding some pros and cons of each. Mostly focused on features and price. But this leaves the prospect alone. Alone in doing the hard work to completely understand the different options they have. The different approaches to solve their problem. But thatâ€™s hard. So do this INSTEAD. Build competitor clusters. A cluster is a specific approach to solve the problem. Here are a few ways to think about it: 1ï¸âƒ£Direct competitors â€”> doing the same as you do â€”> here you need to be clear on your USP and specific positioning 2ï¸âƒ£ Indirect competitors â€”> solving the same problem, but with a different product Here is an example. Letâ€™s say you help companies hire talents faster. And your product is a recruiting software. Then within the direct competition you will have all the other recruiting software tools. And indirect competitors are: - recruiting agencies - freelancers - HR fairs â€¦ Differentiating your product from indirect competitors is rather easy. But most struggle to communicate clearly why they are different to other direct competitors. Aka. Your USP/positioning. Build buckets = unique approaches. Some examples: ğŸ‘‰some focus on smooth HR tool integration ğŸ‘‰ some focus on maximum reach with having the most jobplatform integrations ğŸ‘‰others focus on specific roles, eg. Making technical hires easy as they embed technical assignments and AI filtering of unqualified candidates ğŸ‘‰ others leverage AI to write outstanding job description to attract fast best talents ğŸ‘‰ some focus on small/large companies â€¦you get the point. You help the prospect to understand their options. So instead of saying why xyz is bad and you are better. You educate the prospect and say: â€If you care about x, then z is the best option for you. And if y is relevant for you, consider p. But if a is important to you, then we are the best option for youâ€œ How do you think about your competition?

Here's your post discovery-call email templateğŸ‘‡ The email comes with 6 sections: 1ï¸âƒ£ Email opener 2ï¸âƒ£ Recap discovery --> describe the status quo --> mention the discovery pain --> add the desired goal/outcome 3ï¸âƒ£ Value Proposition --> Remind them about what you do --> for who you are (ICP) --> What benefits they have --> social proof Please don't go into details. No feature lists. 4ï¸âƒ£ Call out of blockers / objections --> Adress potential blockers proactively This can be specific questions about the product, e.g. features or integrations. Or more budget-related. ROI calculations. Or social proof like case studies. 5ï¸âƒ£ Next steps --> Talk about the mutual agreed roadmap. Usually, this includes a scheduled demo + who will join (stakeholders). 6ï¸âƒ£ P. S Section / Secondary CTA --> add additional relevant info here This can be a case study, a short video or documentation. ğŸ‘‡ Let me know what you think. P.S. 9 actionable tactics to drive pipeline via LinkedIn. For most early-stage SaaS founders LinkedIn is a relevant channel. But very few know how to drive pipeline (aka. generate relevant leads) from LinkedIn. So here are my 9 actionable LinkedIn Selling tactics: 1ï¸âƒ£ Value-comments on relevant creator's posts --> make a shortlist of 5-15 relevant experts Be one of the first who value comment on their posts. You can add a link to a resource (of yours) that add value. You can combine this tactic with 4ï¸âƒ£. 2ï¸âƒ£ Auto-connect campaigns with ICPs --> Set up a LinkedIn connect campaign. Check tools like lemlist or lagrowthmachine. Import ICPs from Sales navigator to the sequence. It can be a 1-step campaign (only connecting). Or you combine it with tactic 5ï¸âƒ£ 3ï¸âƒ£ Revenue-focused posts --> If you want to create pipeline via LinkedIn, focus on content that is highly relevant for (high-intent) ICPs. So start with BOFU content. Talk about pain points, usecases, specific product features, capabilities. Share case studies. I have a full list of content topics you can start with (DM if you want the list) 4ï¸âƒ£ Engage/reach-out to ICP commenters/likers --> Your content gets traction. Awesome. But don't stop here. Respond to every single comment. Reach out/ connect with people from your ICP. 5ï¸âƒ£Value-first outreach campaigns --> Connect and DM people from your ICP. You share with them content that (with a high chance) might be relevant for them. No pitch. Just sharing value. If your product/service is relevant for them, they will let you know. 6ï¸âƒ£ 'Comment-below' lead magnets --> You share highly relevant content on LinkedIn. In order to get the asset, they need to comment & like your post. You get huge organic reach + long list of (ICP) people. They get highly valuable content for free. Then you send a DM (or sequence) with the asset to all commenters. 7ï¸âƒ£ Turn your profile into your homepage --> A lot of founders have more profile impressions than website traffic. So include the key aspects of a powerful homepage on your profile. I have a full guide on the perfect SaaS homepage. (DM if you want it) 8ï¸âƒ£ CTAs in your featured section --> Make it easy for people to move forward. This can be a free trial, book a demo or download your lead magnet. 9ï¸âƒ£ Group of early-supporters --> Have a small group of people who engage with your posts. Ideally, they belong to your ICP. This way LinkedIn will promote your post organically to more people from your ICP. Encourage them to value-comment, not just liking. ğŸ‘‡ What social selling tactic is missing? --- To learn more tactics like this, check out my free GTM newsletter for SaaS founders on their way to 1â‚¬ million ARR.

Successful content requires consistency. Plan your content programs with the free Content Calendar Template for SaaS ğŸ‘‡ A single post on each stage or topic wonâ€™t get you far. Prospects need to repeat the same thing over and over. Across multiple angles and touchpoints. When approaching your first content production, you need to think in terms of series or programs vs. single pieces. What does this mean in practice? 1ï¸âƒ£ Pick one outcome vertical in your stage of awareness map Select the vertical that is the most painful, urgent, and widely recognized by your prospects or customers. 2ï¸âƒ£Devise a series of X content pieces Each piece within that outcome vertical at your selected awareness stage. 3ï¸âƒ£ Building a tight syndication and distribution muscle Share one core piece across multiple placements and/or turn it into multiple micro-pieces syndicated on social. By doing this, you will also build topical authority and brand credibility around your customer outcomes; and position your company and how it can help prospects achieve that outcome. Once you have picked your first content program, you can plan production and distribution across a content calendar. Feel free to copy our template below (it contains all guidelines inside the template). ğŸ‘‰ You will find the free Content Calendar (Figma) with the link in the comments. hashtag # saas hashtag # contentmarketing hashtag # startup

The 'problem section' is something that most SaaS companies forget about. ğŸ‘‰ I believe this is a big mistake. Why ğŸ‘‡ The problem section should be the 3rd section on your SaaS homepage. It comes right after the: ğŸ”¸ Hero section and ğŸ”¸ social proof section With this section, you set the context. You connect with the visitor and present them with the â€˜shittyâ€™ status quo they are in right now. All before you introduce your product as the right solution. This section mainly has 2 reasons for existing: 1ï¸âƒ£ Tell the visitors about their â€˜shittyâ€™ status quo, so they know they have a problem (thatâ€™s worth fixing). 2ï¸âƒ£ (dis)qualify visitors --> if they do not resonate with this section, thereâ€™s a high chance that your product is NOT relevant to them. If you ignore this section, you assume that your customers know about their shitty status quo. 10-point checklist to know if LinkedIn ads are the right channel for your SaaS. ğŸ‘‡ LinkedIn ads are a great channel, but not for every SaaS company. Together with Christoph Schachner we worked on a LinkedIn Ad Guide for SaaS startups. Here are 10 things you need to consider: âœ… You have product-market fit using LinkedIn ads as a research channel is very expensive if you have not nailed your target audience, core offer, price point, or value proposition yet âœ… Your target audience is active on LinkedIn active is important since just because you can target them, does not mean they actively use the network - and thus see your ads âœ… ACV > $8.000 LinkedIn ads can be quite expensive and sales cycles quite long, so it is important that your pricing can support this investment âœ… A decent website/ landing page that already converts âœ… Budget of $3.000 over 3 months CPCs are high and exposing your audience to different messages and impacting the buyer journey takes time âœ… Other performing marketing channels SEA, SEO, Email, Affiliates, Organic Social and you use LinkedIn ads as part of your overall marketing strategy - not as the sole driver âœ… LinkedIn company page is well set up posts, information, 1.000+ followers âœ… You have a CRM Once you have established that you fit the minimum requirements, you can check if you fulfill the bonus points which improves the chance of success for your campaigns. Bonus points: âœ… One or more people at your company are already actively posting on LinkedIn âœ… You have a highly visual product ğŸ‘‰ If you are interested in a step-by-step guide on how to run LinkedIn ads for your early-stage SaaS startup, sign up to my newsletter and get the full guide delivered to your inbox on Sunday.

â€œWe need a free plan to grow fasterâ€ ğŸ‘‰ In 95% of the cases, freemium won't solve your problem. Instead do the following. Make a conscious decision if Freemium is a good idea for your business. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ­: ğ—–ğ—µğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—»ğ—´ğ—² ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³ ğ˜„ğ—µğ˜† ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¸ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—± ğ—® ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—² ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—» ğŸ”¸Option 1: If you fear that users would not pay for the product, then most probably you are not solving a big enough problem. So with a free plan, you would just â€šdelayâ€˜ the decision in the future, if you solve a big enough problem (where users are willing to pay). This is not a good idea. Because it hurts a lot if you spend months or years building something and then realize that no one wants to pay for it. ğŸ”¸Option 2: You want users to test the product (without paying). Then you still have the option to offer a free trial (for a limited period, e.g. 14 days). ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ®: ğ— ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—² ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—ºğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—´ ğ—²ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—´ğ—µ (ğ—ºğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—¶ğ˜â€™ğ˜€ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜) There is a good article from Jason Lemkin about it. It says that you need around 50 million active users to make Freemium work (if you want to build a 100â‚¬ million ARR business). Hereâ€™s the math behind it: âœ… Letâ€™s assume a 10â‚¬/month subscription (or 100â‚¬ per year). âœ… So you need 1 million paying users (each paying 100â‚¬ per year). âœ… With a 2% conversion rate from active to paying users, you would need 50 million active users for your product ğŸ‘‰ this is not the case for most SaaS products So Iâ€™m not against freemium at all. I just believe that most early-stage SaaS startups (that are not attracting millions of users like Zoom, Canvas, and Linkedin of the world) are better off with free trials.

3 ways to track your ICP ğŸ‘‡ You want to know your ICP. But depending on your stage, the way to identify the ICP is different. If you're pre-revenue it's different than post PMF. With every customer touchpoint, you try to validate or invalidate. 2) post revenue --> Analyze your CRM and identity winning segments Bigger ACVs, shorter sales cycles, lower churn, higher NPS... 3) Review continuously --> Label your leads/deals if they are ICP or not So you can easily compare their performance. ğŸ‘‰ How do you know your ICP?

I lost 80 subscribers in a single day. I'm shocked ğŸ¤¯ Wanna know what happened? ğŸ‘‡ I recently saw a drop in my newsletter engagement. The open rate dropped from around 50% to 40%. So I dug into my subscriber list. I saw that there are quite a few subscribers that have 0 engagement. So I decided to clean my subscriber list. Because I want to keep an engaged audience. So here is what I did. 1ï¸âƒ£ Filtered for subscribers with low engagement --> Subscription date: after 01/03/2024 --> Emails open (last 6 months) < 1 --> Posts viewed (last 6 months) < 1 --> Activity < 1star Using multiple criteria helped me to only filter for the INACTIVE ones. 2ï¸âƒ£ Export CSV file 3ï¸âƒ£ Upload to Zerobounce --> Understand why they were inactive. --> Filter for the ones with INVALID Email 4ï¸âƒ£ Remove subscribers with Invalid Email Now I lost 80 subscribers. What I learned: ğŸ”¸ Most are company email addresses ğŸ”¸ Lots of them had engagements, but not in the last 6 month I guess the reason is that they changed jobs. So their email address becomes invalid. ğŸ‘‰ This is just the first step of my cleaning process. I will soon send emails to subscribers with low engagement and valid emails. And try to find out if it's a tracking issue or don't want to receive my newsletter anymore. If they don't respond, I will remove them. ğŸ‘‡ But... "Alex, We need to close 800kâ‚¬ in the next 12 months. Can you help us?" One of the best things you should do: start reverse engineering plan ğŸ‘‡ The power of reverse engineering is breaking a hard-to-grasp goal into very specific short-term goals. Something you can work on within your daily operation. Hard to grasp âŒ We need to close 800kâ‚¬ in the next 12 months vs. Easy to work within your day-to-day business ğŸ’ª We need to contact 200 leads per month and have 10 demos per month If you want to get a template, follow the link in the comments.

AI is not a benefit âŒ AI is a feature âœ… Every SaaS talks about that they are AI driven. But just that isn't enough. Customers care about the benefit. Like what does this AI feature? You still need to explain what the product does. And most probably it's: ğŸ”¸ Doing the thing 10x faster ğŸ”¸ Doing the thing 10x more accurate ğŸ”¸ Understanding the thing faster ğŸ”¸ Learning the thing easier etc. The AI feature empowers the user to do something they could not without. Features are powering capabilities. Capabilities can be for example: ğŸ”¸ Writing personalized emails in seconds ğŸ”¸ Summarize long form faster ğŸ”¸ Analyze huge data ğŸ”¸ Create landing pages without coding skills ğŸ”¸etc. TLDR: AI alone is not enough. You still need to explain the capability and benefit of it.

5 variables when testing outbound ğŸ‘‡ Running outbound campaigns involves constant testing and experiments. Outbound campaigns are more than just 1 cold email. If you want to learn what works and what doesn't, you need to experiment a lot. Designing a campaign is not trivial. 5 variables to test: 1ï¸âƒ£ Persona --> Build segments based on role --> can include signals/triggers (e.g. recently joined) 2ï¸âƒ£ Company Type --> size of company --> industry, etc. 3ï¸âƒ£ Problem statement / usecase --> especially if your product offers multiple usecases --> if you are pre-PMF and want to identify the problem of your target audience 4ï¸âƒ£ Messaging --> Includes the content and words --> Trigger/Signals/Icebreaker 5ï¸âƒ£ Campaign design --> Multi Channel? Email? LinkedIn? --> Steps in the sequence --> Frequency & Timeline? Of course, in each of 5 variables there are multiple sub-variables to play around and test. These can include: ğŸ”¸ Subject Lines ğŸ”¸ CTAs ğŸ”¸ Offers/Content But especially pre-PMF it's about testing the main 5 variables. ğŸ‘‰ How do you design your outbound campaigns? hashtag # saas hashtag # sales hashtag # founders

I want to tell you a story. And it was brutal. I wanted to stop ğŸ˜¡ This week I had an intro call with a super smart founder. He was interested in working with me. So I've asked him a few questions. ğŸ”¸ What SaaS product are you building? ğŸ”¸ What problem do you solve? ğŸ”¸ Who has the problem? ğŸ”¸ What's the usecase of it? And the founder was super visionary. Talking about his long-term vision. All the things they will solve in 3-5 years. And how they will dominate a huge market. Every company will use our product. You can use the product for 100s of usecases... It took me over 45 minutes to understand what they are doing. ğ—§ğ—›ğ—˜ ğ—£ğ—¥ğ—¢ğ—•ğ—Ÿğ—˜ğ—  He said they tried 100 things, but none work. And the problem is ğŸ‘†. Customers don't care. They don't understand. They don't spend 45 minutes investigating whether the product is for them. This is also the reason why customers don't buy their product. Their messaging is not resonating. It's too visionary. It's the messaging for investors. Not for potential customers. So we will work on messaging now. Getting specific about: ğŸ”¸ What are the capabilities of the product? ğŸ”¸ What use cases do they solve TODAY. ğŸ”¸ Who can benefit from this NOW. ğŸ”¸ Why they should care? ğŸ”¸ What are their current solutions? ğŸ”¸ And the problem/limitations of them. ğŸš¨ If this is you, you're not alone. Messaging is one of the key challenges for early-stage SaaS founders. ğŸ‘‰ Check out my Ultimate SaaS Messaging Framework (link in the comments) or send me a DM, if you need 1-on-1 support. P.S. This is the number 1 myth I hear over and over again. "My product sells itself, I donâ€™t need marketing/sales." Is this possible? I doubt. And here is why. You can have the best product in the world but if nobody knows about it, how will it sell? Let's say you have great features. Features that are making the lives of your users easier. Let's say 10x easier. It's still about how you present these to your customers. You need to tell them about how these features enable them to do things that could not have been done without your product. And this is the job of marketing and/or sales. ğŸ‘‡ A great product will keep the user. A good GTM attracts users. So you need to have a good GTM to attract users, and a good product to keep them. And yes, even you are PLG.

Using a sales qualification method comes with a few benefits: âœ… Gives you and your (growing) sales team a structure to follow âœ… Improves the quality of your discovery âœ… Improves your pipeline quality & forecast accuracy âœ… Foundation for a shared common understanding and language (internally) Regardless of the exact framework youâ€™re following, I see 5 dimensions of qualification: 1ï¸âƒ£ Ideal Customer 2ï¸âƒ£ Need - Situation - Problem & Pains - Implications 3ï¸âƒ£ Decision Process - Stakeholders (Champion / Economic Buyer) - Roadmap 4ï¸âƒ£ Urgency 5ï¸âƒ£ Competition / Alternative Solutions If you want to learn about the 4 sales qualification frameworks I highly recommend, check the link in the comments. hashtag # saas hashtag # sales hashtag # gtm

"Focusing on one segment just limits our growth." I hear things like this all the time. And It might be true, that long-term the product could be used by "everyone". Different types of companies, from small to enterprise. But this is not where you start. Each segment, is a different GTM motion. And each GTM motion requires resources. And resources means â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬. And that's normally a limiting factor for early-stage. And a strong ICP is also more than Role + Company Industry + Region For me a powerful ICP is the combination of: 1ï¸âƒ£ Ideal Personas (User + Buyer) 2ï¸âƒ£ Ideal Company And here you need to go deep. Iâ€™ve actually created a ICP framework that includes more than 40 data points. The data points includes: ğŸ”¸ Jobs to be done ğŸ”¸ Pains & Challenges ğŸ”¸ Metrics ğŸ”¸ Daily activities ğŸ”¸ software they use ğŸ”¸ content they consume But also very important: ğŸ”¸ Trigger Events / Intent data ğŸ‘‡ Check out the Link in the comments to get your ICP Framework.

Using intent data/trigger events to your prospecting (outbound motion) will 3x the success of it. By nature, outbound has a lower success rate than inbound or referrals. But it's also easier and faster to get started. But instead of doing 'cold' outbound, you should use intent data to make it only 'semi cold'. Intent data (trigger) are a proxy/indicator that they will face the issue/problem you are going to solve for them. When you combine intent data with my TAPSA framework you will see good results. You connect trigger events with a correlated (assumed) pain. Here are a few of the intent data: ğŸ”¸new hires ğŸ”¸change in leadership positions ğŸ”¸promotion/new role of persona ğŸ”¸Headcount changes (growth or decline) ğŸ”¸Open job postings/ads ğŸ”¸Revenue growth (or decline) ğŸ”¸Funding events ğŸ”¸ M&A activity (Mergers & Acquisitions) ğŸ”¸ Press, media & news about the company ğŸ”¸ Bad/good reviews: ğŸ”¸ New Product/Feature launched (e.g. on Producthunt, Company Blog, Helpcenter...) ğŸ”¸ software/tools they are using ğŸ”¸ offered integrations (e.g. Zapier, Salesforce, Notion, etc.) and much more You will find the TAPSA framework and all intent data in the link below.

Messaging doesn't need to be complicated. Here's my messaging 101 flow. 0. Set the stage. What's the context? ğŸ‘‡ 1. Who is the audience of the product? ğŸ‘‡ 2. Who is the champion? ğŸ‘‡ 3. It's 10x easier to create a long list of all features compared to creating a short list of the top 3 features. Why? Because you need to decide what's key for your ICP. Focusing, niching down, and getting specific is always harder than being broad, vague, or generic. And that's why it's an excellent exercise for any saas founder. Decide on your top 3: ğŸ”¸ Features and ğŸ”¸ Capabilities Once you know them, you can update all your customer-facing communication ğŸ˜œ But the good thing. You will see a 10x in all conversions. People will finally understand what you are doing. They know how your product helps them. They know what they can do with your product. And you can finally explain your product so that they get it. And you don't overwhelm them with feature lists. hashtag # saas hashtag # saasmarketing hashtag # messaging .

Way to often I see demos that feels like going to the cinema. Or like watching a movie. Most demos are like product trainings. And I get it. It's tempting, because you love your product and what to show them everything. But, a good demo focus on the most important pain points/challenges of your prospect and show them only the features that improve/change this. A sales demo is actually more a meeting. It's not 'purely' screensharing. If this would be a demo, you could replace it with a product video on your website. A demo is not a product training. The goal of a demo is to get them excited/hooked, to invest more time/energy to try the product and see the overall value of it. Donâ€™t make it complex for them to follow. Few things that will improve your demo already by 10x: 1ï¸âƒ£ Follow a structure: ğŸ”¸ Intro & Outlook Make it clear what's the expected outcome of the session + whatâ€™s happening the next 45 minutes ğŸ”¸Discovery Either a recap of Disco or doing the Discovery. Depends if you follow a 1 or 2 step sales process. If you split Demo & Disco or have it in one meeting. ğŸ”¸ 'Actual Demo' The part where you show the product. Show feature, tell story, engage, then move on to next feature. Do this 2-4 times. So you keep the focus on the key features and capabilities. ğŸ”¸ Summary and next steps Summarize the key aspects (pains & gains). Align on mutual next steps. 2ï¸âƒ£ Make it 2-way Engange with your prospects. Ask questions. It's not a 1-way presentation. Aim for min. 50/50 - not one-way presentation hashtag # gtmstrategy hashtag # sales hashtag # b2bsales

Every startup faces 3 types of competition. If you don't, I would be worried. Not having any direct competition would be a signal that you're building a product that's not solving a real/big enough problem. So having some direct competitors is a 'good' sign. If founders say: "We don't have any competition" My answer is: "This is not true" Every (SaaS) company faces competition. I like to separate between 3 types of competition ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ The DIRECT Competition Companies, that do the same. This is what most understand when talking about competition. 2ï¸âƒ£ The INDIRECT Competition Also called Alternative Solutions. Other ways you can achieve the same result/ fix the problem. This might be: Excel, Manual Work, Hiring someone, patching together non-purpose tools Shootout to April Dunford who explains this very well in her book. 3ï¸âƒ£ Status Quo / NOT DOING ANYTHING Prospects stick to what they do right now â€”> no 1 lost reason So when you position yourself in the market, you need to think about these different types of Competition. Because this is how prospects will evaluate you and compare you with 'others'. ğŸ‘‡ More about the 3 types of competition in my newsletter. Link in the comments.

Is this you? "We only lose deals because we are too expensive" The truth is, that is rarely true. Let me explain... First, in theory, this could be true of course. But what I see most of the time, is that â€šbeing too expensiveâ€™ is not among the top lost reasons. Itâ€™s rather the opposite. I see a lot of startups under charge for their product. To get a clear view about your true loss reasons, few things to consider: ğŸ”¸ Track your lost reasons (dropdown in your CRM) ğŸ”¸ Reach out to them and ask for real reasons ğŸ”¸ For PLG: add a custom cancellation flow/survey in your cancel flow or if they donâ€™t convert in the free trial, ask them in a quick survey Being too expensive means the prospect did not understand the full value of your product. â€”> This is then a problem with Messaging, Sales, How you do demos, and communicating the value. And not a Pricing issue.

Your Investors care about the FUTURE. But your customers care about TODAY. So you as a founder have 2 audiences. Being a founder means selling the company to 2 types of audiences. 1ï¸âƒ£ Your (Potential) Investors 2ï¸âƒ£ Your (potential) customers The problem: Your message can't be the same. Customers care about their situation TODAY. And how you can make it better TODAY. Investors care about the FUTURE. How your company can look in the FUTURE.
