"We don't want to focus on one segment, because literally anyone can benefit from it. Why should we? This just blocks us from growing..." I hear things like this all the time. And It might be true, that long-term the product could be used by "everyone". Different types of companies, from small to enterprise. But this is not where you start. Each segment, is a different GTM motion. And each GTM motion requires resources. And resources means â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬. And that's normally a limiting factor for early-stage. And a strong ICP is also more than Role + Company Industry + Region For me a powerful ICP is the combination of: 1ï¸âƒ£ Ideal Personas (User + Buyer) 2ï¸âƒ£ Ideal Company And here you need to go deep. Iâ€™ve actually created a ICP framework that includes more than 40 data points. The data points includes: ğŸ”¸ Jobs to be done ğŸ”¸ Pains & Challenges ğŸ”¸ Metrics ğŸ”¸ Daily activities ğŸ”¸ software they use ğŸ”¸ content they consume But also very important: ğŸ”¸ Trigger Events / Intent data ğŸ‘‡ Check out the Link in the comments to get your ICP Framework.

Don't get me wrong. I love PLG â¤ï¸ And I advise most founders starting now, to build the product in a PLG capible way, but here's the thing... I believe every SaaS need to build/add a PLG motion sooner or later. For founders starting now I would also encourage them to build the product in a way, that it enables self-service. But this does not mean, that you should always rely on PLG. Here's why: âŒ In the early stage, there is nothing more valuable than talking to potential customers daily. So doing demos & onboarding calls with prospects gives you a lot of feedback. âŒ PLG is not equally suitable for every SaaS product. Generally speaking PLG works better if: 1ï¸âƒ£ rather lower MRR 2ï¸âƒ£ fast time to value 3ï¸âƒ£ low complexity 4ï¸âƒ£ works in a single player mode

I've shadowed demos from 20+ SaaS companies the last 24 months. Most demos are like product trainings. And I get it. It's tempting, because you love your product and what to show them everything. But, a good demo focus on the most important pain points/challenges of your prospect and show them only the features that improve/change this. A sales demo is actually more a meeting. It's not 'purely' screensharing. If this would be a demo, you could replace it with a product video on your website. A demo is not a product training. The goal of a demo is to get them excited/hooked, to invest more time/energy to try the product and see the overall value of it. Donâ€™t make it complex for them to follow. Few things that will improve your demo already by 10x: 1ï¸âƒ£ Follow a structure: ğŸ”¸ Intro & Outlook Make it clear what's the expected outcome of the session + whatâ€™s happening the next 45 minutes ğŸ”¸Discovery Either a recap of Disco or doing the Discovery. Depends if you follow a 1 or 2 step sales process. If you split Demo & Disco or have it in one meeting. ğŸ”¸ 'Actual Demo' The part where you show the product. Show feature, tell story, engage, then move on to next feature. Do this 2-4 times. So you keep the focus on the key features and capabilities. ğŸ”¸ Summary and next steps Summarize the key aspects (pains & gains). Align on mutual next steps. 2ï¸âƒ£ Make it 2-way Engange with your prospects. Ask questions. It's not a 1-way presentation. Aim for min. 50/50 - not one-way presentation hashtag # gtmstrategy hashtag # sales hashtag # b2bsales

Let's face the elephant in the room. Prospecting on LinkedIn works, but not if you send Emails on LinkedIn. 6 differences between Email and LinkedIn prospecting. LinkedIn is a social platform, so you need to adapt your prospecting approach based on the channel. Itâ€™s not enough to simply copy & paste your email sequence to LinkedIn. Here are a few differences I see on LinkedIn (compared to Email): âœ… shorter messages (only 1-2 short sections) â€”> Make it easy to read on the rather small chat window on LinkedIn âœ… no signature â€”> Thatâ€™s why you need a good LinkedIn profile, itâ€™s your signature. âœ… less formatting (no bullet points, empty lines, bold text, etc.) âœ… more informal language (itâ€™s more of a social chat) âœ… itâ€™s okay to use greetings like â€œHey (first name)â€ - instead of (last name) âœ… messages split into multiple smaller messages When it comes to building the actual campaign (the steps and messages), Iâ€™ve seen some very good results in â€˜splittingâ€™ my beloved TAPSA framework (for Cold Emails) into multiple separate LinkedIn messages. This means TAPSA becomes TPPSSB. TPPSSB stands for: ğŸ”¸ Trigger ğŸ”¸ Pain ğŸ”¸ Pain ğŸ”¸ Solution ğŸ”¸ Solution ğŸ”¸ Break-Up 7-Step LinkedIn Prospecting Sequence Framework (TPPSSB) Step 1 - LinkedIn Connect Step 2 - Trigger Message Step 3 - Assume Pain Step 4 - Emphasize Pain Step 5 - Teaser Solution Step 6 - Emphasize Solution Step 7 - Break Up ğŸ‘‡ Check the link in the comments to get the TPPSSB framework.

It's not true. The more the better is not the case. It's rather the opposite. "We want to grow faster, so we try to do it all at the same time. SEO, PPC, Outbound, Events, Affiliates..." This is something I hear quite a lot when talking with SaaS founders. "Weâ€™re not growing, so we need to add more channels." But the truth is, each channel works differently. Each channel takes time to master. Each channel requires resources. And all this means â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬. But â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬ is whatâ€™s mostly limited in the early stage. So Itâ€™s better to focus on 1-2 channels that work and do more on these. Of course, to find those 1-2 channels that work, this could mean doing smaller tests for different channels. Keep in mind. Some channels take longer naturally to get results (e.g. SEO, Partnerships) while others get instant results (Google Ads, Outbound). ğŸ‘‡ What channels do you use?

Churn is like a â€šleaky bucketâ€˜. You keep adding new customers on top but lose them at the bottom. This means youâ€™re not growing, youâ€™re just burning moneyğŸ”¥ And keep in mind. Churn compounds over time. If you save a few customers from churning this month, you are NOT only saving the revenue from this month - but also from the following month. So keep this in mind when prioritizing growth initiatives. And if your churn rates are bad, it's a bad sign. Good retention is a great indicator of PMF. So focus on fixing your leaky bucket, before you add more on top. I would always advise founders to: 1ï¸âƒ£ Track their churn rates So you know if you have a retention of acquisition problem 2ï¸âƒ£ Work on retention, if they see unhealthy churn rates. Because if you donâ€™t do that, you will burn a lot of cash. Cash you spend to acquire new customers, but if they donâ€™t stick your CLV will be low and never really start to grow.

"We only lose deals because we are too expensive" I doubt. Let me explain... First, in theory, this could be true of course. But what I see most of the time, is that â€šbeing too expensiveâ€™ is not among the top lost reasons. Itâ€™s rather the opposite. I see a lot of startups under charge for their product. To get a clear view about your true loss reasons, few things to consider: ğŸ”¸ Track your lost reasons (dropdown in your CRM) ğŸ”¸ Reach out to them and ask for real reasons ğŸ”¸ For PLG: add a custom cancellation flow/survey in your cancel flow or if they donâ€™t convert in the free trial, ask them in a quick survey Being too expensive means the prospect did not understand the full value of your product. â€”> This is then a problem with Messaging, Sales, How you do demos, and communicating the value. And not a Pricing issue. hashtag # sales hashtag # gtmstrategy hashtag # saasmarketing

"We donâ€™t have any competition" This is not true. I like to separate between 3 types of competition: 1ï¸âƒ£ The DIRECT Competition Those are companies, that do exactly the same as you do. And here it might be true that you only have a few direct competitors. Bonus: If you don't have any direct competitors, this might be a sign that you're on the wrong track. Not solving a relevant problem. So having a few direct competitors is even a good sign. 2ï¸âƒ£ The INDIRECT Competition These are alternative solutions. Heard about this term the first time by April Dunford Those are other ways your customers can achieve the same result/ fix the problem. This might be Excel, Manual Work, Hiring someone, or patching together non-purpose-made tools. 3ï¸âƒ£ Status Quo Competition It's about NOT DOING ANYTHING. Your prospects stick to what they do right now. This is the no. 1 lost reason. ğŸ‘‰So when you need to position yourself in the market, you need to think about these different types of Competition. Because this is how prospects will evaluate you and compare you with.

If you solve a big enough problem, users will pay for your product. 2ï¸âƒ£ ğ—³ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ˜„ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜† ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ That's a fair point. But you can simply offer a free trial. Limited for a specific time (e.g. 14 days free trial). 3ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¡ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—´ ğ—²ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—´ğ—µ ğ—ºğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜ Freemium only works if you target a super large market. My product sells itself, I donâ€™t need marketing/sales. Is this possible? I doubt. And here is why. You can have the best product in the world but if nobody knows about it, how will it sell? Let's say you have great features. Features that are making the lives of your users easier. Let's say 10x easier. It's still about how you present these to your customers. You need to tell them about how these features enable them to do things that could not have been done without your product. And this is the job of marketing and/or sales. ğŸ‘‡ A great product will keep the user. A good GTM attracts users. So you need to have a good GTM to attract users, and a good product to keep them. And yes, even you are PLG. hashtag # gtmstrategy hashtag # saasmarketing hashtag # saas

Are you Team 'Feature Gating' or Team 'No Feature Gating'? I'm team NO feature gating. Here are 3 reasons why. ğŸ‘‡ I believe feature gating is NOT the best strategy for early-stage SaaS I know, the big successful companies all do feature gating in their pricing. They mostly combine 2-3 value metrics and have 3-4 plans. Mostly something along like: - user limits - feature limits (aka feature gating) - product specific metric (e.g. emails, spaces, resources, projects, etc.) While this is obviously awesome, it's also really hard. It's hard to know what are the right limits. And what customer type needs which plan. So I advice early-stage SaaS companies to do value-based pricing on 1 (or max. 2) value metrics - and not feature gating. Here's why.ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ ğ—œğ˜'ğ˜€ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ --> With every new feature, you need to decide if this is now a premium or basic feature. And also how this affects the overall product experience. Without a lot of customer data, it's really hard to know what features only a specific customer type needs. 2ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¨ğ—½ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ—³ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—± --> In order to use premium features to upgrade users over time, you need a good understanding of your different customer types. Most early-stage startups don't have this. 3ï¸âƒ£ ğ——ğ—¼ğ—»'ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¸ ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜€ --> Your ultimate only goal should be to improve your product and build the best possible tool for your customers. Don't think of how to 'limit' it in terms of features for them. Instead, add features fast to make them happy. What do you think? ICP, Positioning, and Messaging come as a GTM triangle. It's your foundation for growth. Messaging is one of the key elements of a powerful go-to-market strategy. Positioning lays the foundation for your messaging. And the ideal customer profile defines the right way to communicate to/with them. Without clear messaging, itâ€™s really hard for you to communicate consistently to your ideal customers - and most probably your message does not resonate with them. Thatâ€™s what we call Message-Market fit. Your messaging is the foundation to build your key assets like: âœ… your homepage âœ… your sales deck âœ… your email sequences âœ… your product onboardings âœ… your product demos âœ… and much more... Work on your GTM strategy. Without, you will just spend â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬, but barely win new customers. ğŸ‘‡ Grab my free GTM Workbook.

Message-market fit is like Love â¤ï¸ If you found it, you just feel it. And for all of you who prefer specifics. You hit message market fit if: 1ï¸âƒ£ 15%+ response rate on outbound messages 2ï¸âƒ£ "Ahh, that sounds interesting" - something you will hear from prospects 3ï¸âƒ£ High CTR on Ads (2-5%) 4ï¸âƒ£ High Website Conversion Rate (above 1%) It's time to work on your Messaging. Without messaging you will win 0 clients. ğŸ‘‡ Check the link in the comments and start working on messaging with my SaaS Messaging Framework

There are only 2 reasons why you can't sell your product. 1ï¸âƒ£ Your product is bad or useless 2ï¸âƒ£ Your messaging is not resonating with your target customer. Number 1ï¸âƒ£ is when you don't have product-market fit (PMF). Number 2ï¸âƒ£ is when you don't have a message-market fit. To be successful, you need to have both.

Do you have a churn problem? If so, 2 things you should do right away ğŸ‘‡ If you're seeing high churn rates, it's time to analyze your data. You need to figure out: 1ï¸âƒ£ Who is churning? Are specific types of customers churning? Specific plans? Geographies or user types? New customers or rather long-term users? 2ï¸âƒ£ Why are they churning? What are the reasons? It's good to use dropdown options to make it easier to analyze the data. Is it pricing? Missing features? No need anymore? Switching to competitor? Once you know WHO and WHY you can start to work on churn prevention initiatives. These insights can be then used in: âœ… Product âœ… Customer Success âœ… Sales Miguel Marques add your wisdom please ğŸ˜€ hashtag # saasmarketing hashtag # churn hashtag # gtmstrategy

Do you want to increase your ARPA? Instead of increasing your price plans, consider removing one plan. If you want to increase prices, everyone naturally thinks about increasing the actual â‚¬ for your plans. While this is a solid strategy (that I highly recommend every startup do because most startups underprice their product... ...But that's worth a whole different post ğŸ˜€) there are also different ways to increase the average revenue per account. One way is to decrease the value metric per plan (e.g. instead of 100 X included, you decrease to 50 X included). Another way is to drop one plan. So customers don't have the option anymore. This could be your cheapest plan, or also one of your 'middle plans'. ğ—˜ğ˜…ğ—®ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¹ğ—²: ğ—¬ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—µğ—®ğ—± ğŸ° ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€. Basic: 99â‚¬/month Standard: 199â‚¬/month Premium: 399â‚¬/month Ultimate: 999â‚¬/month Now you drop your standard plan (or basic). So you end up with only 3 plans. ğ—˜ğ˜…ğ—®ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¹ğ—²: ğ—¡ğ—²ğ˜„ ğŸ¯ ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€. Basic: 99â‚¬/month Premium: 399â‚¬/month Ultimate: 999â‚¬/month Doing so will nudge customers to different plans. * before you do this, you need to analyze your current customer base. Build segments based on how they use the product and see if this strategy makes sense. hashtag # saaspricing hashtag # saas hashtag # startup hashtag # founder

I want to tell you a story. Last week I had a call with a super smart founder. And it was brutal. I wanted to stop ğŸ˜¡ We wanted to work on messaging. So I've asked him a few questions. ğŸ”¸ What problem do you solve? ğŸ”¸ Who's your target user? ğŸ”¸ What are the usecases? And the founder was super visionary. Talking about his long-term vision. All the things they will solve in 3-5 years. And how they will dominate a huge market. Every company will use our product. You can use the product for 100s of usecases. It's so horizontal... ğ— ğ—² Trying to go deep. To figure out what you exactly do. What are the capabilities of the product? What usecases do you solve TODAY. Who can benefit from this NOW. Why do they care? What are their current solutions? And the problem/limitations of them. But I DID not understand it. It took me more than 60 minutes to figure it out. And this is also the reason why customers don't buy their product. Their messaging is not resonating. It's too visionary. It's the messaging for investors. Not for potential customers. ğŸš¨ If this is you, you're not alone. Messaging is one of the key challenges for early-stage SaaS founders. ğŸ‘‰ Check out my Ultimate SaaS Messaging Framework (link in the comments) or send me a DM, if you need 1-on-1 support.

Examples: - The Ultimate Guide to reduce SaaS churn rate - How to reduce your sales cycle with mutual action plans ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ¯: ğ—•ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¸ ğ—±ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ—» ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—´-ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—º ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´/ğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—« ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜„ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ Break them down into new, more specific, and shorter versions. Here are a few examples of titles: - Best tips on TOPIC (e.g. Best tips to reduce sales cycles with mutual action plans) - Top 10 tips on TOPIC (e.g. Top 10 tips to reduce your SaaS churn rate) - X steps framework/guide to TOPIC - X reasons why TOPIC is important/hard - Best books/events/influencers/reports for TOPIC ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ°: ğ—§ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—» ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ˜€ğ—² ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´ ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€/ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—« ğ—ºğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—Ÿğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—±ğ—œğ—» ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€ Play with different formats. 6 LinkedIn posts styles: - text-only post - carousel - listicle - 1-page cheatsheet - video (e.g. 5-minute highlight video of the new blog post) - screen recording video (Loom video) Always link to the long-form blog post (but not in the post, better as a comment on your post). So letâ€™s quickly do the math: 9 articles x 6 LinkedIn post formats = 54 LinkedIn posts. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ±: ğ—–ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğŸ¯-ğŸ± ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—²ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—Ÿğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—±ğ—œğ—» ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€ A hack big creators like Justin Welsh leverage perfectly. You create slightly different versions of each post. e.g. changing the hook or rephrasing it a bit, but keeping the message the same. Quick math: 54 posts x 5 versions = 250+ posts ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ²: ğ—¦ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€ ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—® ğ—§ğ—®ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—¼/ğ—£ğ˜‚ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—µğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—¿ğ—µğ˜†ğ˜ğ—µğ—º Now you have 250+ posts ready to use. I would recommend using a tool like Taplio or Publer and schedule your posts. Every 2-4 weeks, you can post about the â€˜sameâ€™ topic again. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—²ğ—½ ğŸ³: ğ—¥ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜„ ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€ + ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ—º ğ—®ğ—´ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—»/ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—½ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ—² Analyze your posts. Identify what worked. Reuse and schedule a new post. Topics that are relevant to your ideal customers are not getting â€˜old. You should repurpose them over and over again. With only 1 content topic you can end up with 250+ posts. Now with this framework, you will never run out of ideas ğŸ™‚

Get roles and teams clear if you want to grow your SaaS. The good thing: SaaS only has 5 roles ğŸ‘‡ Note: If you have a dedicated person for each role or even team depends of course on the stage of the company. Some bootstrapping founders run all roles in 1 person (or small teams). Other heavily funded startups have teams and multiple people. But either way, every SaaS needs the X roles covered. 1ï¸âƒ£ ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ Being close to the customers and deciding on how the product should work. Build roadmaps and work with the engineers. 2ï¸âƒ£ ğ—˜ğ—»ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ Building the product and being 'in' the code. 3ï¸âƒ£ ğ— ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ Responsible for driving traffic to your website and generating new signups (PLG) or leads (SLG). 4ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¦ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ Responsible for converting those leads into revenue (and doing outbound to drive extra revenue). 5ï¸âƒ£ ğ—–ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—¦ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ & ğ—¦ğ˜‚ğ—½ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ I know these are 2 different roles. But in the early stage combine these 2 roles in one. Customer Success is responsible for onboarding new customers and making sure to make them happy (and expand revenue). Support is rather responsive and makes sure to fix the issues of customers. ğ—”ğ—±ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ On top of the core 5 roles, you will need sooner or later people who take care of HR, Design, Legal, Operations, and Finance. ğŸ‘‡ Which structure do you have? hashtag # saas hashtag # founder hashtag # startups

The Demo Follow Up Email TemplateğŸ‘‡ After every sales demo you need to send a follow up email. But what should you include? Here's an ultimate template for you. The email consists of 3 parts: 1ï¸âƒ£ Quick Summary This includes key aspects of your discovery. The status quo, the identified pain points, the challenge and the desired goal. Plus key features that solve the pain and deliver a specific benefit. 2ï¸âƒ£ Open Questions / adressing objections Answer open questions. Address objections. It's better to practively include them than to hide them. 3ï¸âƒ£ Next Steps Here you set the next mutual steps. This can include a proposal, test account and next meeting. Bonus: Some of the variables can be pulled from your CRM. hashtag # sales hashtag # emailtemplate hashtag # saas hashtag # gtmstrategy

Educating the market about a new product is hard. Don't build a new product category until... Until you are later stage. Here's why. Let's start with a conversation I had last week. Founder: We are not a CRM, we are XHFG Me: What is a XHFG? Founder: It's a CRM, but with XYZ Me: So, you are basically a CRM. Founder: Yes, but we want to be different. Tip ğŸ‘‰ If you are an early-stage startup, Do yourself a favor. Don't build a new category. In 90%+ you are not a category. You add something new to an existing category. AND belonging to a product category, has a lot of advantages. Customers get faster what you are. They attach specific criteria to it. You don't need to explain everything. Customers assume specific things. Based on the product category. This makes your marketing and sales 10x easier. Because educating the market about something completely new is hard. Hard means Expensive â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬ and normally startups don't have â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬. ğŸ”” Once you are later stage. and have more resources. You can create a new category. But please don't if you are early stage.

So trial users would automatically convert to paid clients (if they don't cancel). It's basically an opt-out free trial. Example: Miro ğŸ®) ğ—™ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—² ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—–ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—± Here trial users can test the product without adding their payment details. Example: Lemlist ğŸ¯) ğ—¥ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—² ğ—™ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—² ğ—§ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—¹ During the trial period, you give trial users access to your premium plan. Do you want to raise your prices but are worried about what customers say? Think about the following: Instead of increasing the â‚¬, decrease the value metric for your tiers. Example: You are a newsletter software. You charge based on subscribers. Right now you offer 4 plans: - Lite: 9â‚¬ for up to 1000 subs - Standard: 19â‚¬ for up to 10000 subs - Premium: 49â‚¬ for 10000+ So instead of increasing your prices. You can change the value metric. Example: - Lite: 9â‚¬ for up to 500 subs - Standard: 19â‚¬ for up to 5000 subs - Premium: 49â‚¬ for 5000+ You will see more clients in your Standard and Premium plans. You will increase your ARPA. ğŸ‘‰ Check out my Ultimate SaaS pricing guide for more infos. (Link is in the comments) hashtag # saas hashtag # pricing hashtag # saaspricing

How you know it's time to scale? 3 scale-readiness indicators = your friendğŸ‘‡

Cold email sequence with a 30% response rate and 8% interest rate. How can you do the same? 1ï¸âƒ£ Follow the TAPSA framework --> Your first email needs to follow the TAPSA framework. This means having a relevant trigger event to reach out. The rest of the email follows the structure: 1. Trigger = email opener 2. Assume Pain = second section, connected to the trigger 3. Solution= third section; 1-sentence pitch how you solve the pain 4. CTA = interest based soft CTA 2ï¸âƒ£ Campaign based on 5 emails Five emails over 30 days. This is obviously audience-specific. As this audience is a bit more conservative and 'slower' we decided on 5 emails over 30 days. You can also do 6 emails over 21 days. 3ï¸âƒ£ Email 2 to 5 were all pain focused We made sure that we 'pitched' the pain. And not our solution. 4ï¸âƒ£ We did A/B tests for the subject line Add A/B tests to your campaign. But always only test 1 variable at a time. e.g. subject line, CTA Last but not least, we designed the campaign around our ICP. This means, the copy of the email is laser-focused on the pain of the ICP. Plus we made sure that we only added leads that fit our ICP. ğŸ‘‰ The link below brings you to the TAPSA framework. ğŸ’¡ What are your secrets for a successful outbound campaign? hashtag # saas hashtag # founder hashtag # sales

There are 2 types of growth. But only 1 is scalable. Product-Market fit shows you if your product is valuable for the market. Channel-Market and Message-Market fit tells you if you found the right channels with the right message to acquire new customers in a repeatable and profitable way. So do you have a clear answer to: âœ… Do you know which growth channels work for you? âœ… Can you consistently create pipelines and new clients? âœ… Do you know how much it costs you to acquire and retain new customers? If yes, then you're on a good track to repeatable growth. ğŸ‘‰ Wanna learn about the 3 scale-readiness indicators? Link in the coments.

Your job is to set the context. The context of what you're doing and why this is relevant. Do you think positioning is only relevant for big companies? I DISAGREE For me, positioning is a key step in your GTM strategy.

Small tip, massive impact. Talk about (competitive) alternatives instead of competitors. They are different ways to solve the problem. So instead of bashing competitors. Acknowledge them. You're basically guiding your customers. Consulting instead of selling. It's educating the customer and giving them different options to fix the problem. If you value X, then Y is a good choice for you. If Z is important to you, then I believe W is best for you. And once you care more about P, then we are the best for you. But if you care about P (and hate the limitations of the current solution), we are the best fit for you. Doing so will set you apart from them. Not being in the same bucket. ğŸ‘‰ What's your take on this?

The #1 mistake in cold calling ğŸ‘‰ Pitching right away. The most common mistake in cold calling is pitching way too early. Pitching before you understand the situation of the prospect. Pitching before you know they are qualified. Pitching before you know there is a pain/problem or at least desired land. Instead: See cold calling as 2 separate steps. Step 1: Discover Step 2: (High-Level) Pitch After you find the right moment (discover a problem) it's time to pitch. ğŸ‘ or ğŸ‘ ? How do you cold call?

Founder: We are not a CRM, we are XHFG Me: What is a XHFG? Founder: It's a CRM, but with XYZ Me: So, you are basically a CRM. Founder: Yes, but we want to be different. Tip ğŸ‘‰ If you are an early-stage startup, Do yourself a favor. Don't build a new category. In 90%+ you are not a category. You add something new to an existing category. AND belonging to a product category, has a lot of advantages. Customers get faster what you are. They attach specific criteria to it. You don't need to explain everything. Customers assume specific things. Based on the product category. This makes your marketing and sales 10x easier. Because educating the market about something completely new is hard. Hard means Expensive â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬ and normally startups don't have â‚¬â‚¬â‚¬. ğŸ”” Once you are later stage. and have more resources. You can create a new category. But please don't if you are early stage.

3 reasons why feature gating is NOT the best strategy for early-stage SaaS ğŸ‘‡ I know, the big successful companies all do feature gating in their pricing. They mostly combine 2-3 value metrics and have 3-4 plans. Mostly something along like: - user limits - feature limits (aka feature gating) - product specific metric (e.g. emails, spaces, resources, projects, etc.) While this is obviously awesome, it's also really hard. It's hard to know what are the right limits. And what customer type needs which plan. So I advise early-stage SaaS companies to do value-based pricing on 1 (or max. 2) value metrics - and not feature gating. Here's why.ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ ğ—œğ˜'ğ˜€ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ --> With every new feature, you need to decide if this is now a premium or basic feature. And also how this affects the overall product experience. Without a lot of customer data, it's really hard to know what features only a specific customer type needs. 2ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¨ğ—½ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ—³ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—± --> In order to use premium features to upgrade users over time, you need a good understanding of your different customer types. Most early-stage startups don't have this. 3ï¸âƒ£ ğ——ğ—¼ğ—»'ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¸ ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜€ --> Your ultimate only goal should be to improve your product and build the best possible tool for your customers. Don't think of how to 'limit' it in terms of features for them. Instead, add features fast to make them happy. What do you think? 5 ways to ask for referrals/intros without feeling ğŸ‘‡ ğŸ‘‰ It's about HOW you ask them. First of all, I believe you can almost always ask for referrals. Not only customers but also prospects. Here are 5 scenarios ğŸ‘‡ 1ï¸âƒ£ Prospect is disqualified --> 'Okay I see that there is not a good fit between you and us. That's fine. But now you know what our product can do, especially for companies with (criteria 1,2,3). Do you know companies we should talk to?' 2ï¸âƒ£ Prospect is interested --> 'It's awesome to see that you like what we're doing. I'm pretty sure you know 2-3 other companies, that could also benefit from us' if you already know who you want an intro --> 'It's awesome to see that you like what we're doing. I saw you're connected to X,Y and Z. Do you think they would also benefit from it? Could you introduce us to them?' 3ï¸âƒ£ Customer signed --> 'We're very happy to have you onboard. As you might know, we grow a lot through referrals. What are 2-3 companies you believe we need to talk to?' 4ï¸âƒ£ Customer fully onboarded --> 'It's great to see how you already achieved X. Now that you experience the full potential of our product, who do you think are 2-3 companies that can benefit from it too?' 5ï¸âƒ£ Support issues solved --> 'So good to see that everything goes well again. Feedback like yours is really important for us to always improve our product and serve our customers the best way. Talking about customers: Who do you know, that can benefit from our product/ the new fixes?' ğŸ’¡ Do you ask for referrals/intros?

Jobs to be done are what your customer is trying to achieve. Help them to 'do their job' and they will love your product. Your product (hopefully) helps them to accomplish the jobs (or at least makes it faster, cheaper, better, easierâ€¦). hashtag # jobstobedone hashtag # saasmarketing hashtag # messaging

Who's your competitor? Most startups face 3 types of competitors. But direct competitors are... ...mostly not the biggest competition. Most of the time your customers don't take a decision. They stick to the current status quo. They had an overload of information, but did not understand why they should care. So in order to compete against the status quo, make sure that your positioning covers the status quo. What is it that you observe about the status quo, and what is the resulting problem for the customer? What's the problem for the customer? Why should they care? Once they understand that the status quo is not ideal for them, it's time to tell them how you can change the status quo. What's in for them? What's the value for them? Until this point, you don't talk about your features at all. So don't make the mistake and compare yourself too much with your direct competition. There's a high chance that you don't lose customers to your direct competitors. But there is a high chance that you lose them to the status quo. Or to alternative solutions that also solve the problem (in another way). And that's fine. As long as you make it clear why your product is the best solution for a very specific customer type. Different solutions fix a problem. And every solution might be the best for a very specific customer profile. How to build a new category? Creating a new category requires a lot of resources. Money, but also time. 2 things that most startups don't have. My advice: Don't try it as an early-stage startup.
